Weich, geschmeidig an der Zunge, im Abgang und im Nachhall reichhaltige Rauchnoten. Dezente Hopfenaromen im Hintergrund. Alkohol nicht spürbar. Absolute Spitze im Rauchbiersegment!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2015 Bottle: deep amber red. White froth. Very complexed nose. Obviously smokey. Roasted malt. Single malt peaty profile like an isle Whisky. Glaced Aromatics. Caramel. So many layers. Rich palate. Dry but rich. Moderate but balanced bitterness. Not sour. Balanced great weight. Long. Clean. Layers. Isle single malt of beer. Rich, intense but refreshing. A lovely beer.

Imported bottle. I dont recall the brewpub having this particular style in Bamberg.

Just a bit lighter in color and smoke than the original. A nice smoke beer.
Bottle. The look is amber in color, beige colored head, and clear. The smell is smoke, bacon, wood, bbq, pepper, and layered. The taste is smoke, ashy, wood, touch of caramel sweetness, and good.
Bottle. .Pour is caramel with a thin fading head..nose is Caramel, smoke, toffee, sweet, spice..Taste is caramel, mint, smoke, dry, sweet, cherry, toffee..

Pours brown amber and mainly clear with a well-built yellow-white head that mainly fades but leaves some lacing. Aroma is a deep and richly smoky wood fire with notes of bacon or smoked meats. Taste is less smoky than the aroma but is sweet caramel and darkfruits with a balance of smoky malts. There are noble hops on the finish with just a bit mild bitterness. Alcohol is totally disguised. I really like this beer and am a big fan of these incredibly unique smoked beers. Perhaps not for everyone, but there is no denying the craft. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
January 2011. From bottle. Dark amber color with a tan head. Sweet aromas of caramel, malt, dark fruit and of course smoke. A masterpiece of a beer.

16.9 oz. bottle. Purchased at Gabriels Superstore. San Antonio, TX. It pours a golden amber color with a fine head. The aroma brings some lovely campfire. Its almost like I am camping, though I am in my living room right now. Its smoked meaty aroma gives off the impression of smoked meats, in particular, sausage. The taste has some more smoke but it seems to compete evenly with the taste of some sweet malt. That brings some flavors of honey on the back end. It also has a moderate bitterness that I am not used to from Schlenkerla smoked beers. Its definitely not the smokiest that they offer.
AMber color, light for style. Thin head, medium carb. Very strong smoke aroma. Excellent taste, but, again, smoke dominates. Shot palate that thins and stays. Not my cup of tea.

16.9 oz bottle pours brown with a off white head. Aroma is smokey and malts. Taste is malts and only a hint of smoke.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

one of those beers that sounds amazing on paper but disappoints... i mean the schenkerla maerzen is great, the urbock is even better, so therefore this should be unbelievable - but it doesnt necessarily follow because once lagers get up over 7% it gets so much harder to make them work. for one thing the head here disappears in a second, hinting at fermentation issues. add in a strange medicinal oak smoke flavour to the alcohol flavour, and you get a big mess with the smoke and the hops and the sweet caramelly malt as well. what a shame, but at least they still make the urbock with the beech.

500ml bottle. Pours a hazy burnished amber, with lots of floating sediment and a small off-white head, which lasts reasonably well and leaves good lacing. Savoury bacon notes mix with smoke, cashews and some sweeter, spicy notes to create the aroma. Mild spice hops up front mix with a touch of smokiness. A sweeter, nutty flavour comes in next, with bacon and jamon iberico flavours dominating the mid-palate. These cured meat flavours persist into the finish, where they are joined by more smoke and an almost floral sweetness. This is much more balanced than Aechts other beers. The oak smoke seems to have a little more sweetness to it than their regular beech smoke. The balance gives lends this beer a little more complexity than many smoked beers, and makes for a very impressive beer indeed.

Dark brown pour with an off-white head. The aroma is full of oak smoke and ash with some toffee thrown in. The flavor is also quite smokey. I really like how the sweet oak smoke notes mix with the toffee and caramel. There is also a bit of grass and earth. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Great smoked beer.

Bottle from Choice Beverages McKinney. Pours a deep mahofany brown with a medium off white head. The aromas are bacon, oak, dark fruit. The mouthfeel is sticky and watery with a medium body and lots of carbonation. Great beer!

Bottle sample at a tasting at kerenmks place. Thanks DSG. Pours rusty orange with a nice head, aroma of smoked fish, wood, smoked sausage, flavor is slightly bitter and sweet with smoked fish and wood, medium to full bodied, very nice
Imploding head reveals amber fluid, Aroma is subtle, but smoky - very nice. And it's oak smoke, quite nice. Taste is quite learn for a Doppelbock but The smoke takes care, it won't be boring

Tap at GBBF 2013. Aroma is smoked sausage maple. Murky orange red colour with a persistent off white head. I think this on has gone bad. Tart raspberry tangy finish. Smokey nalt. Putty this one is bad. Will have to re rate.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2013 Pours deep amber into a half liter dimpled mug. Aroma of smoked sausage and bacon. Nice small head that lingers around with no lacing. Slightly sweet malt taste with a little salt. Medium body with a lot of smoke. Filling finish. Perfect for a smoked backyard cookout. Ive been waiting 25 years to try this beer. . Visited Bamberg before I learned of great beer.

Pours a medium gold with an off-white head and lots of lacing. It has a strong aroma of smoked oak, a bit of dark fruit, and a surprising aroma of baked ham. The flavor is smokey and some dark fruit up front, with a smoke and slightly salty finish over a smooth body.

Bottle at De Paas, Den Haag. Poured a cloudy dark amber with a thin white head. The aroma is smokey malt leading to a very weak sour flavour with loads of smokey bacon and yeast on the super smooth palate. It was like drinking a liquidised pig! Very different!

Bottle shared @ de paas. Pours a clear amber beer with a very thin, off white head. Aroma is woody, bacon, barbecue and typical campfire smokyness. Flavour is quite sweet, slightly herbal, loads of smoke in the back. The smokey presence in this beer is just great, filling and backing up the palate in such a great way. This is a well balanced, greatly crafted brew.

Bottle shared at De Paas. Pours clear bet with a small off white head. Aroma is smokey, ham, some wood, BBQ, caramel and a little dark fruits. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter, a little saltiness like with a good ham. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. A beautiful smoked beer.
Bottle to glass. Amber pour with a thin head. Nose is mild smoke with malt body and oak. Really smooth body, Taste is Smokey with some oak, ham, caramel. Mild bitter finish/aftertaste.

2/10/2011: Aecht Schlenkerla Eiche Doppelbock (Schlenkerla Oak Smoke Double Bock)... Aroma: Has that wonderful, trademark Schlenkerla smokiness (a true rauchbier!) along with a caramlized fruity maltiness that I can only describe as being like heavily caramelized corn on the cob when cooked in the husk over an open fire; this beer smells GREAT! Appearance: Golden yellow color with only a slight haze; roiling carbonation creates a hypnotic effect; dense and lasting head of beige foam. Flavor: Meaty smokiness that nicely balanced with a moderately sweet and malty bockbier; I get some of that caramelized corn on the cob as well (this is meant to describe the nice caramelization and fruitiness; Im not saying that there is any corn in this beer nor does it have any cereal graininess or corn like found in American macro lagers) - actually, maybe a better description is smoked cheese rind!; finish is slightly dry and the alcohol strength is firm, but not overwhelming. Palate: Very smooth and even a bit creamy; medium-full body; good weight and mouthfeel; slightly oily. Overall: Delicious! More smoke is always appreciated, but this is a nicely balanced and approachable smoked beer for those new to the style; the Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen is still my favorite though!
1 pint 0.9 fl. oz. bottle (8.0% Alc./Vol.) from Belmont Party Suppy near Dayton, Ohio. Rating #592 for this beer.

From bottle. Pours amber with small cream head and very slight lacing. The smell alone is worth buying this beer for. Rich smokey aroma, big oaky notes as youd expect, with some smoked pork or ham. Its got a sweetness to it which is lovely. Flavour is like smoked ham hough, wood, dark malts and a caramel touch. Id liken the aftertaste to smoked honey roast ham, which is a high achievement indeed. Medium body and very enjoyable.

Thanks to kiwianer for sharing! Pours slightly hazy brown/orange with a loose tan head. Huge wood and smoke nose - I can huff this stuff! Taste is similar to the nose. Huge wood & smoke with some fruit ending dry. Nice medium body, a bit oily. Great stuff!!

Slightly darker amber color, large head, decent lacing and retention. Rich smokey aroma with notes of bacon, light oak, light vanilla, light caramel. I could smell this shit all day, its fucking glorious. Medium bodied, silky mouthfeel, dangerously drinkable. Ive had dozens of smoked beers, this is my absolute favorite. Nothing matches the balance and flavor components here. A great doppelbock with a flawless smoke presence with some oak aging characteristics. Why yes please Ill have another. Inject this shit into my veins, this is a world beater.

Bottle sample at a tasting at our place, thanks DSG. Clearish amber. Deep smoky wooden aroma and something slightly fruity and sweet too. Smoke, a little sweet and fruity in the mouth. Bitter smoky finish. Balanced and amazing.
Deep amber with a cream head. Nose is beef, BBQ, liquid smoke, light wood, and sweet. Great on the palate, smooth smokiness, malts, wood, BBQ, beef, fantastic.

Bottle shared at a tasting at kerenmks place. Slightly hazy deep amber. Great smoked sausages aroma with some wood. Malty flavor, rather sweet, with caramel, a bit of nuts, lots of smoked meat, and a drier finish, smoky and woody. Medium-bodied, oily and pretty rounded mouthfeel. Very good.
Huge smoke notes in the aroma. Thin head with some lace. Taste is like a hot dog or smoked ham. Easy drinking with a medium mouth. Hands down one of the better smoked beers Ive had in the style.

Bottle shared - cheers Steven! Pours a clear reddish brown with thin white head. Big nose of smoke, burnt wood, brown sugar. Taste follows through, less bacon-y than the beech smoked beer. Some sweetness on the finish which is very nice.

Pours a red/copper with not much head to speak of. Instantly, the smokey nose hits you. Smells like a campfire mixed with a smoker at a BBQ restaurant. Nice malty character with the smoke character just right. Rich and robust brew. I bet this would be awesome with some ribs.

Bottle. Reddish brown beer with a head that dissipates to nothing. Aroma is great, reminds me of Bavarian smoked cheese, without the cheese (contradiction I know) and wood. Taste is smoked sausage, wood, yeast and some sweetness to counterbalance the whole thing. A beer with a great aroma and very good taste.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle at Amundsen, march 26th 2013. Clear amber body, with a small disappearing light brown head. Aroma of campfire, bacon, caramel and fruity hops. Taste is smoky with burned wood, bread, rye and a solid dose of caramel. Very pleasing balance. Aftertaste of smoke and dark fruits. A good one!

Bottle at Edelweiss Restaurant in CO Springs. Brown in color with a small beige head. Aroma is of smoke, salt, malt, caramel, and a hint of chocolate. Taste is of smoke, light peppers, brown sugar, cured meat, and a hefty malt backbone.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2015 Intenso e limpido color granato con un fragile strato di schiuma biancastra. Aroma affumicato con sentori di legno, cenere, fumo e zucchero bruciacchiato; gusto mediamente dolce e caramellato, perfettamente in sintonia con note di legno affumicato, cenere e malto abbrustolito. Morbidissima al palato, corpo medio lieve e rotondo, effervescenza debole, struttura meno "ruvida" della Marzen... in sintesi ottima per il sottoscritto!
Poured a reddish color with a big foamy head. Aroma of wood, smoke and BBQ. Flavor was very nice; not over the top smoky. Wood, caramel, wood, some yeast. Soft on palate

Ruby color with almost no head. Aroma of smoked meat, ash, malts, brown sugar, bananas, clove may be. Taste is light to medium sweet, smokey flavor, a bit sour. Medium body creamy texture, soft carbonation. The ABV is very well hidden.

500ml bottle brought back home from NWAF 13 in Manchester. Enjoyed in company of Finn at his place. Beige bubbly head leaving fragile lacing behind. Crystal clear, brown coloured body. Prominent smell of sausages and burnt wood. Barbecue sausage in flavour with a nice touch of oak vanilla behind. A little roastiness to a semi-sweet ending. Enjoying (Tromsø, 08.05.2013).

Nice amber/orange color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of rich smoked meat, & burnt oak; Flavor of smoky sweet malt, caramel, dark fruit, syrup, and spice; Nicely balanced; Cant get enough of the aroma and smoke - not as good as their Urbock but still quite nice.

Bottle: &nbsp Amberish, dirty, hazy, little to no head or lacing. &nbsp Strong band-aid and smoked aroma. &nbsp I am hoping its a bit better because the band-aid smokiness is something I cannot stand. &nsp On the tongue its much 

better, smooth, smokey, very clean, with only minimal amounts of band-aid. &nbsp Smoked aspects are minor to moderate. &nbsp For a Doppelbock it seems a little weak. &nbsp Has a bit of sweetness to it. &nbsp Not very big in body and 

mouthfeel, fairly average. &nbsp Soft band-aid and smoked malts on the finish. &nbsp A bit more plastic like than I prefer, but its smooth with a nice maltiness. &nbsp As it warms, the band-aid comes out a bit more. &nbsp Dont drink 

this one while its warm folks! &nbsp I was expecting a bit more from this one.

One of the great rauchen beers from Bamberg, Germany.  This one made with Oak smoke (hence Eiche).  Dopplebock, and 8% alcohol.  Probably the best of its class.  Taste reminds this southern boy of barbeque!

Poured from the bottle into a trumpet glass to drink.  The beer had a wet, hazy rusted copper/light brown color with a deep rust hue and a modest bubbly and foamy off-white head with shorter retention, very little cling, and light lacing.  The aroma had a very strong smoky oak character, with a whiskeyesque quality, and some earthy, grainy tones; only a light hint of caramel malt.  Its taste was also fairly strongly smoky and oak-dominated, with a light undertone of sweet caramel malt.  The body was fairly light with low carbonation and not much body or mouthfeel, with a watery consistency.  Very interesting beer, unlike any I remember having with the smoky characteristics.

Kleine Bierstube, Aarhus, DK.
Bottled, 180413.
Brown with beige head. Aroma of smoke and malt. Flavour with some caramel/nuts and more smoke

Bottle from Tomlinsons, Inverness [280413]
Caramel brown, frothy off white head that dissipates to nothing
Aroma - Massive smoked wood, very aromatic, burnt bacon, grilled smoked sausage, phenolic, far too much smoke 
Taste of woody smoke, smoky bacon, caramel malts, burnt edges of sausage, im not liking the smoke, caramel malts, dont get the hops, bit phenolic, the smoke flavour isnt great
Palate - Thin to medium body, soft carb, quite sweet malts. Finisd as main flavour, lingering strong smoked wood, phenolic, way too smoky
Overall - This is a Marmite beer. Its way too smoky - really has to drunk with smoked cheeses and sasusages...but to be honest id rather have a beer less smoky

UPDATED: APR 20, 2013 Deep copper with an amber glow but no head.  This has an extreme peat smoked aroma with a wooden smoked aftertaste.  It has a sweetness in its taste and is a little sticky in its texture.

Pours amber with a white head.  Aroma is smoke, wood, earthy and more smoke.  Taste is tart smokiness into sweet finish.  Medium bodied, very nice smoked beer.  It just kept getting better as I drank it.

A mid orange-brown coloured beer with a very weak head. A strong, smoky aroma, drifts immediately from the bottle and only gets more potent as its poured! In the glass, the woody nuances of malt are more apparent, along with the usual Aecht Schlenkerla meatiness, smoky bacon and sausage. Full-bodied mouthfeel. The taste buds are bombarded with a potent smoky flavour, charred barbecue meatiness bring a certain bitterness to the taste that is perfectly balanced by a smooth, medium-sweet maltiness that has a touch of burnt sugar about it. There is a tiny suggestion of sourness in the finish, but this is allow a brief appearance before the smokiness once again takes centre stage!

Pours lightly hazy copper / orange with a small off white head.  The aroma has lots of smoke (big surprise), lots of woody character, somewhat sweet malt and almost a little bit of candy and caramel.  This one doesnt really have a meaty character like I was expecting and is fairly smooth and integrates the flavors.  Medium / full body with a modest amount of semi-sharp carbonation.  Flavor starts out with some peaty / oaky woody smoke, caramel malt (not as big as expected from the a doppelbock), some spice and toffee.  The finish shows a hint of meaty smoke ~ dont care for that, but its not overwhelming.  Theres also a touch of spicy hops.  All things considered I liked this a lot more than I thought I would.
Draught at Faucets, Tokyo. Amber brown colour with a white head that leaves some lacing. Sausage aroma. Flavour of sausage and burned wood.

Le liquide est ambré-cuivré,sans col avec un anneau de mousse léger.Au nez,une douceur de fumé de bois des plus mémorable et une odeur fine qui me fait pensé à de la mélasse.Au goût, des notes de raisins, de caramel,de fumée intense avec une fin légèrement sucré.Quelle découverte,une bière des plus façile à boire malgré ses 8% dalcool.Jadore la marzen,mais celle là je suis tombé en amour.Vive Schlenkerla !

0,5l bottle. Pours dark copper with nice creamy beige head. As someone already sad super smoky aroma. Woody, smokey flavor with a bit of sweetness and a hint of bitterness at the end. Very good smoke beer.

Une bouteille de 50 cl partagée par Ben.  Un gros merci!  Une robe ambrée et limpide qui développe un col respectable.  Un nez qui se dévoile très rapidement.  La fumée sévapore dans latmosphère.  Il y a du bois dur et du jambon dans cette bière.  Il y a aussi des effluves de sucre dérable et de sucre dorge.  Ces parfums sont tellement prenants et fabuleux : mon pif se perd pendant un très long moment et rêve de figer dans le temps ce moment assez unique.  Sur les papilles, les saveurs sucrées dansent une longue valse avec des malts fumées viandeux et boisés.  Lalcool est bien maîtrisé et apparaît sous des cultivars poivrés.  Un véritable délice pour les sens.  Je crois reconnaître des notes fruitées derrière ce vibrant ensemble.  En bouche, le liquide montre un corps splendide.  Les bulles sont parfaitement maîtrisées et la texture est huileuse.  Sa finale permet aux notes maltées de se fondre totalement dans un amalgame de notes amères, fumées et piquantes.  Un plaisir fumé, malté et houblonné.  Vivement une autre bouteille.

Bottle. Pours a mostly clear amber color with a smallish off-white head. The nose is definitely super smokey, with some good meat elements in it. Taste has an immense note of smoke, but a very slight amount of sweetness on the back end.

Not bad as a doppelbock and also not bad as a smoked beer, but this combination didnt really work wonderfully for me.  When Im able to get past the overwhelming smokiness to really taste the malty sweet flavors of the doppelbock, I really enjoy this beer.  But all too ofter the smoke dominates the flavor and the pairing really isnt as nice as Id like.  Maybe its the strength of the oak smoke that does it, but Id prefer a lighter smoke flavor (by about 1/3) to allow those doppel flavors to come out stronger.

Thin head which dissipates quickly.  Wonderful salty smoked aroma with loads of smoked ham, terraki and maybe even some smoked fish.  Smoke is prominent but is accented by lots of other flavors.  Deep copper brown in color.  Strong malt backbone which is expected in a dopplebock but then more salty smoked ham comes through in the flavor.  This brew would be a perfect compliment to lots of food dishes.  Right now it is the perfect compliment to the Wales vs England match for the 6 nations championship.  GREAT MATCH!!!  Light bitterness and dryness in the brew.  Minimal alcohol presence.  A very good smoked beer.  Not overpowering but still very prominent in the flavors.
Oak smoke was a disappointment compared to their beechwood smoke. Lack of smoke means a sweeter malt taste.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2015 May 2012 - An old favourite of mine.  Of course, the main flavour is smoke.  Tastes a bit like cured meats.  Most of the flavour is in the aftertaste.  Has a sweetness that balances the smoke. A really good sipping beer.  (4.0)
June 2015 - Bottle shared at Pauls.  Always nice to revisit.  Dark orange, still, small white head.  Aroma is smoked ham, chorizo, light copper pipe.  Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation.  Taste is smoked ham, soft malts, light bitterness.  Stands the test of time.  (3.9)

Bottle. Pours dark amber, with a big creamy head. Aroma is marvellously smoky, with peat, camp fire and oak, as well as a nice caramel. The body matches the aroma perfectly, with its full creamy texture and soft carbonation. Flavour is sweet with burned malts, smoke, oak barrels caramel and a nice and fitting hint of alcohol sweetness in the finish.

(draught 0,5l @ Netopýr (Brno))
Smoked ham aroma. Clear dark amber color. Medium white head. Medium sweet, strong smoked flavour. Creamy texture. Dry, smoked finish. Good smoked beer.

Amber beer with a lasting very nice offwhite head. Malty aroma, smoked, soot, sweet, toffee notes, maybe some vanilla. Malty smoked flavor, roasted, bready, toffee, spicy notes, salami. Malty toffee finish. Smoke is as always hiding some other flavors, but this is good.
Bottle. Pours mostly clear amber with decent tan head. Aroma is malt, smoke, honey, sugar candy. Flavor is sweet, malt, honey, smoke, hint of licorice.
Smooth, BBQ type smoke which is well integrated with the beer. Quite characterful fermentation character too, which may be out if style. Overall a fun beer.

Deep mahogany color. Big nose of caramel, chocolate and smoke. The body is rich, sweet and smokey, but the smokiness seems to battle with the bigness of the Dopplebock and neither side seems to win. Additionally, the beer is a bit too sweet for the style. Drier bocks work better with smoked beers and lower ABV. Still not a bad drop, but I would rather stick to some of Schlenkerlas conventional offerings.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark copper brown with a quarter finger of instantly settlng off white head. No lacing. Aroma is smoky, woody, earthy, oak, bacon, peated malt. Flavor is sweet, smoky, oak, with a strong smoky finish that lingers, hints of bacon. The oak is definitely smoother and sweeter than the beechwood. Very smooth carbonation, medium body, and mildly chewy texture. A rich, smooth, and delicious smoked beer.
Bottle pours a dark amber with a very thin white head. Tastes smooth and smokey. Lightly carbonated. Hints of oak and bacon on the palate.

Pours a clear cherry red brown, no head and a very light carbonation. Smoky aroma, some bacon, a bit of burnt wood, fruity flavours of cherries and berries. Lots going on but really works well. Unusual, well balanced sweet and smoky. Memorable.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 Botella de 500ml. Copa Pokal. Saboreada en feb´13. Color ámbar con tintes amarronados. Apariencia cristalina. Espuma bronceada que crea una capa tupida, de burbuja minúscula, con buena retención. Anillos en las paredes. Intenso aroma de humo con maltas caramelo subyacentes y matices de cuero. El delicado malteado de la entrada es atacado por un limpio amargor pero el gentil toque Bamberg aporta sensación cremosa. Cuerpo medio y carbonatación suave/moderada. Textura denso/aguada. Notas florales y terrosas en el intermedio permanecen en el seco y amargo final. Leve madera quemada en el retrogusto. El ABV parece bien camuflado pero sube a la cabeza con rapidez.
500ml Bottle. Pokal glass. Enjoyed on feb´13. Brownish amber color, clear appearance. Tan froth creates a close, small bubbled crown. Good retention & rings left on sides. Intense smoky aroma & caramel malts underneath, leather hues. Delicate malty upfront is attacked by clean bitterness but gentle Bamberg touch provides creamy sensation. Medium body. Moderate to low carbonation. Oily to watery texture. Floral & earthy notes in the middle linger into a dry bitter finish. Slight burnt wood on the aftertaste. ABV seems to be well masked but it quickly climbs to your head!

Aecht Schlenkerla Eiche has essentially no head, just a few big, soapy, off-white bubbles. There is no lacing. The appearance is hazy and rust-red, with gray-white sediment floating about and some tiny bubbles that race to the top. The araoma is of smoked pork, and the flavor is of the same, with some underlying malt sweetness, caramel, and a decent amount of hop bitterness in the bottom of the sip. Mouthfeel is watery, and Aecht Sclenkerla Eiche finishes semi-dry, mild, and odd. Overall, I rate this unusual Christmas beer very high, even though it takes some getting used to. Check it out! RJT

Pours amber reddish with medium beige head, minimal lacing.
Aroma -smooth, rich compared to "Urbock". Guess what- smoked :) a bit earthy, a bit mushroomy, a bit toasted-roasted. Cant catch malt or hops notes. Very nice, complex flavour. 
Taste is mild sweet with pleasant medium bitter from smoked/toasted malt and a bit more bitter from hopping. My favorite astringency from hopping and maturation is also sensible, mild hops bite on tongue. Close to full body, thick but smooth texture, soft carbonation. Almost no dry finish, sweetish aftertaste. In conclusion - fact that tried two in a row is measure of good or better :)

A nice deep copper body with a off white head that had good retention and lace.  Aroma had a strong smoke aroma upfront, mostly oak but there was an alder like presence to it too.  Some sweet malt notes in the back.  Flavor was mostly similar.  Obviously there was a strong smoke flavor to it.  It kind of reminded me of liquid smoke. Good smoke flavor with a savory note.  Sweetness of the malts came through a little more than the aroma indicated.  Finish was slightly dry and the mouth-feel was decent.

Bottle @ Home. Pours dark amber with a offwhite head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel notes, lots of smoke, bacon and campfire. Flavor of malt, campfire smoke, smoked ham, bacon, caramel, little dark fruit, light booze. Medium body, soft carbonation. Very easy drinking for the intense flavor and ABV. 240213

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2017 2013-02-22: 7,3,6,314 = 3.3. Tap. Clear red amber with a medium off white head. Aroma is smoke wood, dry tobacco, caramel, bacon. Taste is medium sweet, hardly any bitterness. Light/medium body, watery/oily texture, soft+ carbonation. Smokey bacon finish. Perhaps Ill learn to appreciate this more sometime.


Bottle. Clear bronze with a medium sized creamy off white head. Taste impressions are the same, but I like the texture much better this time around, and I dont get why it found it watery on tap, as it now it feels really soft and full. Light herbal/dry flowers from the hops as well. Some light alcohol warmth. Learned to appreciate this in about a year it seems.
On draft at Churchkey in DC. Pours a clear amber with s massive off white head.  Aroma of apple wood smoked spareribs.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Flavors of toast slight bitter finish. Exceptional.

Didnt like this one as much as the Urbock.  It had very similar tasting notes, but the drawback to this one was that the mouth-feel was kind of thin and lacking compared to the Urbock.  This is just a preference of mine.  See my review of that beer for more info.
Bottle. Pours amber brown with off white head. Nose and taste of lots of smoke, smoked pastrami, smoked deli meat, bacon fat, oak and smoked caramel. Slight hop bitterness in the finish. Medium body.

Light brown colour with a small, quickly dissipating head. Aroma: like the classic Marzen but a bit sweeter - plenty of smoked meat, camp-fire, toast, caramel. Taste: again, similar but smoother - plenty of bacon, smoke, dark fruits, honey, some earthy notes. Bitter-sweet finish. Low carbonation, smooth mouthfeel. No idea where the 8% is hidden. Delicious, but the more assertive Urbock just beats it for me.
Beautiful mahogany color. Aroma is pure smoked ham and bacon. Flavor is smoked meats and lush malt sweetness. This is rauch heaven.

500ml bottle from Tomlinsons. Appearance and Aroma: Pours a flat medium brown body with a bit of fizz and a slight head. A whiff of smokey bacon, charred oak and sandalwood.  Taste: Not heavy, fairly gentle. Its certainly got a woodland taste about it. Palate: Smooth, a bit oily and soft around the gob. Overall: Amazingly, it doesnt taste anything like 8% - most likely because of the unusual tastes.  Its good, but not quite as awesome as their Rauchbier.

Clear märzen-like amber/copper orange. Semi faint nose of metallic campfire smoke, toast, and a whiff of bacon grease. Nice full palate but the flavor potency was oddly medium. Semi-sweet body with some light smokiness and some honey, and a very gentle ham tone.
Bottle. Dark golden yellow color, small white head on top. Nice smoked bacon, slight woodyness, malty notes in aroma. Rubber, smoked wood, malty, straws, rye in flavor. Quite drinkable brew.

500ml bottle from Hippo Beers. Medium brown colour, not much head. Smokey bacon aroma & flavour. A bit flat, malty aftertaste. Would go well with crisps decent but not outstanding. Does not feel like an 8% beer.

Clear reddish amber with medium white head.
Aroma.. intense smoked, quite malty, wood, smoked bacon
Sweet.
I like smoked meat and I like beer, thou these two things together wont work for me.

Bottle. Pours clear amber with airy white head. Dark aroma of roasted malt and caramel. Delicious, smoky flavour of malt, caramel and roasted nuts. Dry aftertaste. Perfect carbonation. A really, really good thing.

Thanks to Mads K for this nice beer. Clear amber body with a medium creamy offwhite head. Aroma is smoke, wood chips, caramel, malt. Flavor is caramel, smoke, wood, alcohol notes, dark fruit. Medium carbonation. Smooth. This is really good.

Deep brown with a red tint and a thick, frothy, lacy, lasting, off-white head. Smells of caramel and toasted malt, wood, smoked meat with some glazing on the roast. Medium oily body. Sweet caramel malt with caramel/maple sweetness with a roasted/toasted malt middle with a woody bitter  leading to a  smoky finish. I cant taste the 8%. Not complex but super easy to drink. Very sweet and malty.

Bottle. bonus to drink it with a fireplace going. Pours a coke clear brown with very little head. Armoa is a smokey, meaty, sweet flavor. almost barbeque ish in nature. very smooth taste. Definitely have had smokey beers but this compliments the dopplebock very well. almost tastes thins and makes you really wonder how they pack 8% in to it. really nice smoked.
Tap @ wildeman. Clear copper pour. Aroma full of smoke, eel, bacon and oak. Flavor is sweetish malts, perfectly smoked. Great balance, decent body. Subtle, yet huge brew. Amazing.
Draft @ wildeman. Aroma is deep smokey schlenkerla malt, big eel and toher smoked goods. Awesome. Lovely smoky goods ,slight bitterness, big creamy malt sweetness with caramel. Awesome beer.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2014 Kobber klar skum brunlig lidt lang 
Røg malt tømmer karmel nød
Bitter lidt sød moderat 
Cremet sirup livlig 
@home f50 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear red amber colour, off-white head. Aroma of smoke, wood, malts, caramel, furniture wax, oak chips, smoked Black Forest Ham, warm winter fire. Sweet malty flavour, smoke, light ash touch, caramel. Finish smoke, wood, sweet, almost cloying, light hop touch, bacon.
Great beer!! I do love this.
(From 0.5L bottle @ home)

~Sweet smoked ham/bacon aroma with wood and caramel, bread.
~Pours hazy amber color with quickly disappearing off white head.
~Woody smoked hickory bacon dominates the flavor with a huge caramel sweetness and rich melanoidins.. The sweetness is a bit cloying. 
~Med full bodied with med CO2, sweet smokey lingering finish.
~Enjoyable brew to sip slowly. Love the smokey flavors. Way too sweet for my taste though. It would be tough on my stomach to drink a pint of this to myself.

Bottle - pours dark crimson-brown, small whitish head, bubbly and diminishing. Very fragrant aromas of subtle smoke, wood and bacon. Very subtle. Beautiful fruit on the taste, light smoke, smooth malts, nice long finish with BEECH flavor. Medium-light bodied and silky smooth. Very nice for the winter months.

29/12/2012 Ma che siete venuti a fà (tap). Ambrata intensa, scura, quasi miele di castagno, limpidissima, schiuma biancastra abbondante e abbastanza persistente. Al naso è straordinaria, malto, caramello, con note affumicate intense. In bocca è magnifica, caramello e affumicato si fondono insieme in maniera mirabile, un esercizio di stile, eleganza ed equilibrio incomparabile. Corpo medio, carbonazione corretta, alcol non pervenuto. Altro magnifico capolavoro di questo immenso birrificio!

Bottle.  Pours a clear orange amber color with a small off white head.  The aroma has a big smoked component that shows smoked meats and charred oak, caramel, hints of peat and small dabs of honey.  The flavor is smoked meats, charred oak, caramel, honey, light peat and a hint of spice.  This is one of the better smoked beers Ive had.

12 oz draft at Swagger Waldo in Kansas City, Missouri.  The pour is a hazed brown orange, with a smallish off white head.  Nice lacing on the glass.  The aroma is soft char campfire smoke, with smoked meats, toasted malt, and a bit of herbal honey sweetness.  The taste is the malt sweetness of the Doppelbock initially, moving quickly to the smoky campfire meat, and finishes clean with the bready grassy malt.  The palate is medium bodied, soft natural carbonation, the smoke and sweet finish the beer cleanly and nicely.  Nice one.

The beer is a light orange hue and transparent. The head is a light khaki shade with a soapy consistency, fading to a thin layer clinging to the perimeter of the tulip. 

The aroma brings campfire, sausage, bacon, smoke. 

The flavor is peaty, smoky, but less wonderful than the standard trio I often drink from this brewery (Urbock, Weizen, Marzen). Grilled meat and a touch of sweet malt.

My biggest complaint is the body, which is quite thin. The feel is smooth on the palate, with low carbonation. 

Overall, worth a try, but I wouldnt choose this over the standard rauch offerings from Aecht Schlenkerla.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-30-2012

Pours a gorgeous, clear, dark amber color with a two-finger off-white head that doesnt hang around too long. Some lacing left on the glass. The aroma of smoked ham, (whoa!) and toasted bread with a grainy earthiness to it. Smoky flavor up front, then the sweet caramel malts come forward. There is a nice earthy hop flavor and some dark fruity flavors that linger. A hint of alcohol in the finish. Definitely a dopplebock and the smoke flavor doesnt cover it up. Nice balance. Medium body and a nice low level of carbonation, smooth and silky. Overall a very drinkable beer at 8% ABV, and a very good and unique version of the style. The oak-smoked malt is definitely more subtle than their beech-smoked offerings. I have to say this is my favorite from Aecht Schlenkerla; I highly recommend this beer, even if you didnt like smoked beers youve tried before. I didnt.
Medium brown with cream head. Definite smoke aroma- smells like gouda. Smoky flavor, too plus toasty sweetness.

Another good smoke beer from this brewer.  Not much of a head but the color is beautiful clear mahogany.  Nice smoked flavor, aroma, and palate.  Always find these unique and enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2015 Loved it! Deliciously smoky aroma that is not overwhelming at all, with smoked ham, honey, sweet caramel malts, oak, and a minor herbal hop noise. The taste is sweet, woody, and smoky, devolving into a drier finish. Theres a minor suggestion of alcohol, but its overwhelmed by the sweet malts and smoke. Medium mouthfeel with adequate carbonation and a smooth body. I found it more drinkable and engrossing than the Urbock.
Smoke aromas and a touch of sweet malt. Deep brown with a dissipating head. Smoky sweet flavor. Full bodied and with a smoky finish.

50 cl. bottle split with Kraddel. @ room temp. Gusher, standard burned sugar amber, instant gone head. Smoken bacon nose, sticky caramel, caramelized, lovely smoked, light campfire and smoked wood. Sticky caramel, toffee, brown sugar, caramelized taste followed by wood, sticky smoked ham mixed with caramel, syrup, cough syrup. Sticky, oily, lower carb. Yummy.

Cant get enough of this fantastic smoked doppelbock.  Pillowy head.  Huge nose.  The perfect taste of smoke and sweet deep malts.  Rauchbier is an acquired taste for most.  Once you acquire it youll feel like youre in a secret club.  Schlenkerla makes rich and profound beers.  They are among the best.  I drink this beer in 500 mL usually three at a time.  Its fantastic.

Keg @ Port Street Beer House. The pours deep, rich brown with a small tan head. The aromas of rich smoked ham, brown sugar, charred wood, smooth leather. The taste is much the same. Rich, toasted malts, wood, ham. Delicate sweet smoke and a bit of syrup. Some roasted nuts. Supple and smooth body. Wonderful vitality. Overall, I dont like smoked beers much, but credit where its due. This is a genuinely well-crafted beer.

bottle pours a slightly hazy dark reddish brown, with somewhat thin off-white tan head.  Im familiar with Aecht Schlenkerla rauchbiers, but the aroma on this one is off the charts.  Woah!  Roasty, smoked barbecue flavors - pork, smoky vegetable stew, sweet hickory, campfire.  Also some wood aroma, birch.  Also beneath the dominating smoke is still a readily distinguishable doppelbock aroma, caramel, brown sugar, wet leaves, soft fruit.  Theres also a nuttyness.  You can really get different aromas out of this on almost every sniff as it warms.  Medium bodied, light for 8% (in a good way), nicely warming.  While the same tastes are present in the flavor as in the aroma, here the doppelbock style dominates over the smoke, while both are still distinct.  Finish is lingering smokyness.  Overall an excellent brew, and probably my favorite from Aecht Schlenkerla yet, which is saying alot.

Bottle: Poured a deep clear brown color ale with a medium size foamy head with good retention and some light lacing. Aroma of smoked malt is powerful though well balanced by some caramel malt. Taste is a great balance between some caramel malt with some light sweet notes and a good level of smoked notes. Body is not as full as expected with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Well brewed and not as smoky as expected since the malt really cut through some of the smoke.

Aroma is interesting, smoky, like a ham scent, but sweet with caramel. The apperance is copper, one finger light brown head. The taste is weird. It tastes exactly as it smells. It holds qualities with a doppelbock and finishes tasting like a honey baked ham. Initially you get a caramel sweetness but it slowly turns into ham. Its wild stuff. The mouthfeel is great, very malty, soft carbonation, goes down smooth. Overall, its fascinating and worth a try!

This is the best smoke beer I have had.  But I still dont get it.  Pork rind flavoured beer anyone?  Is sweeter and more approachable than the beech variety.  Too much like medicine enfused with rancid bacon for my tastes.

Half-litre bottle, just out of date when poured into my Abbot Ale glass tankard on 14 Nov 2012 @ home.

Good clear amber body with a creamy tan coloured head (for twenty seconds), the head sadly soon turned into a wispy covering and collar.

Smoked German ham came straight into my mind as I poured the beer and the aroma left the bottle. This beer is a liquid version of smoked ham that has been infused with dark, sweet, malty molasses and wraped in hops.

Really enjoyed this beer: Ive been to Bamberg a few times and have struggled to embrace the whole rauch scene in general, wish Id found this during my visits, it might have changed my view of smoky brews: oak obviously does it for me rather than the beech!

poured into a dimple glass it produced barely  any head. it had a nice amber color. A nice smokey aroma hit my nose. the flavors were malt forward with a subtle hint of smoke. its paired well with my cheese and cracker snack

Aroma is very smokey but very inviting. Amber colored. Taste is smoky but it is very smooth.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nearly clear copper pour with a 1 finger, creamy, soapy beige head. Aroma is definitely recognizeable as oak smoke, some light caramel, tobacco (not smoke), old capsite, wet grass, spice and a bunch more awesome smoke. Flavor is sweet and smoky up front, some caramel and malt sweetness, toffee and bready notes, a decent dose of planty and spicy hops and some grilled fruit and bread to the finish. Medium body with a creamy, oily feel throughout and an all around light to moderate carbonation. Pretty tasty stuff, I really need to buy more Schlenkerla beer for the cold months.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Pours a lighter orange color with a white head of foam. The aroma has some hefty bacon presence on top of a light malt bill. This one isnt as heavily smoked as Ive experienced from this brewery in the past, but I think its for the best, here. Nice sipping beer, and would double nicely as a marinade on some pork chops.

I think Im having an affair with Oak. Oak is ok, I think though that the elm is a sexier tree. And as for the silver birch, well, move over Ms Berry, your time is up, the silver birch had better not have an owl hole in it or it is gonna be violated. Oh god, someone put me out of my misery. Classic Schlenkerla if a little less smokey bacon. Thats good for me.

Bottle at Bow. Clear copper brown, thin layer of white bubbles on top. Big big sausage smoke, spicy oak, huge smoke, soft roast, soft boozy treacley malts on the nose. Surprisingly restrained palate, sweet treacle, soft toffee, smooth smokey oak underneath, meaty smoke comes back in the finish, along with a touch of warmth. Nice.

From Capones.  Wow, this is the first new Aecht offering Ive had in years.  Pours hazy deep copper with minimal off-white head.  Nose is huge rauchy caramel malt, oaky camp fire smoke, and bacon.  I smelled this one as soon as I popped the cap.  Tastes actually somewhat sweet, with a medium body, a lot of smokiness and oakiness, and quite a bit of earthy and fruity flavors (figgy fruit).  Finishes smoky, malty, fruity, and oaky, with a lot of caramel flavor.  This one is unique and excellent.

Poured into a perfect pint. The first time I had one of these (the marzen), the smoke was just too damn strong. Since then Ive grown to love the smoke.

3.5 A: Lightly hazed orange amber color. Just a finger of frothy beige head. Retention is below average, but a small ring of lacing is left.

4.5 S: When you smell this, your nostrils get porked. Slow roasted and smoked pork, bacon, campfire all in great balance, but not without plenty of power. Not much else can get passed the smoke, but thats fine since it smells so wonderful.

4.0 T: Again big smokiness with both porcine and campfire components. Sweet caramel from the base along with a robust neutral maltiness and toastiness. A little less smoky than the nose (I can taste the base) but still quite potent. A bit boozy, but nothing out of hand.

3.5 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Light creaminess and a bit syruppy.

4.0 D: This brand is the one to go to when you want slapped silly with smoke. Very tasty.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-03-2012 02:54:51

Location/Date:Bottle on October 5th, 2012. Dual rating with Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Urbock
Appearance: Pours a almost clear brown copper. 
Aroma: Smoke, some bacon/pork, lighter/sweeter than the Urbock.
Taste: Smoke, not a ton of pork/bacon, faint hop, sweet maltiness underneath, possibly from beech smoke, faint caramel.
Palate:Medium medium light body, quick finish.
Summary:  Another solid smoke beer from Brauerei Heller.   I think of the bottled versions Ive had, prefer the Marzen version the most as of now.

Aroma: The smell is clearly smoky, a bit of tar and peat, some wood. Very much like a traditional wood sauna.Appearance: The brew is clear amber, an off-white rather small head, some lacing and some curtains.Taste: Upfront sweet, brown sugar, sweet bread, smoked meat, sweet sour bitter nuances (mango chutney?).Palate: Low carbonation, soft and oily, a rather dry finish.Overall: A pleasant moderated rauchbier.Note: Bottle. Reviewed 2010-12-03.

500ml poured into Schlenkerla pint.  Pours a nice amber with a 2-figer thick head.  Particulate residues are present.  Aroma is smoky but less than the urbocks, and the fact that they are using another wood (oak) to smoke their malt is apparent.  Were also definitely in doppelbock territory!  Another thing to be noted, and a bit strange, is the strange perception of "salt" in the aroma...never witnessed this before!  Taste is medium-light sweet, less sweet than the urbock, and only slightly bitter.  Body is is medium and texture is slick and hmmm...maybe a little oily.  But it doesnt have the body that the urbock has thats for sure.  Carbonation is soft, very small bubbles here, and actually pretty pleasant.  Finish is medium-long with some bitterness and ashy feeling.  Overall a really good offering from Schlenkerla, once again!  The alcohol content is treacherous, you dont feel its 8% abv at all!  A really comforting drink on a chilly autumn or winter evening.  No wonder they brew it in winter...!

Christwagons this is good stuff. amber body with a white head that does not last. strong smoke nose that is meaty and salty. flavor is rich sweet fruit and bacon grease. wood lingers and makes me go back for more. smoked salt and pork with caramel fruit. this so damn good that i must have more.

July 8, 2011 - with blankboy, joemcphee, jerc and mabel.  Hazy orange with minimal frothy white head.  Light campfire aroma, a little iodine, good solid sweet fruity backing malt, and a strong whiff of funky barnyard - a near 8.  Taste - very nice - iodine and wood ash to the fore, sweet malt way, way to the back - funky cowbarn.  Light body, slick, some carbonation, a little astringent from the smoke, leaves a funky burnt dried cowpat linger (in a good way)

An avalanche of smoking doppelbock embers on the nose, no-nonsense off white head and decent . Greasey gammon initial taste and a more deft mouthfeel than I expected from a Rauchbier allowed seeping charcoal onto the palate and grilled pineapple to trickle through for a neat and sweetfinish. 
A more enjoyable take on things than Im used to, with the brown lemonade vibe ticking the refreshment off that I wasnt expecting and the ABV is certainly well masked throughout.
Bottle, Tourmalet, Edinburgh

Bottle at friends - 27/08/12.
Clear reddish brown with a very thin cream head that soon dissipates entirely.
Nose comprises smoked ham, dark fruits, sweet malts, wood and more smoke.
Tastes backed by a caramel malt undertone allied to dark fruit, smoked bacon, frazzles and wood.
Medium to full bodied with a slick smoked finish with a slight alcohol warming element.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Gedronken in de Wildeman in Amsterdam, Ruikt naar gerookte spek, bacon, ei. Kleur is bruin/oranje helder. Smaakt ook naar spek met ei, heel speciaal!

500ml bottle. The smoke aroma is subtly different than the smoke character of the domestic smoked porter I just finished; the smoky, hammy character is there, but there is also a sweetish, fruity smoke aspect paired with+ a strong malt backbone. The flavor is multifaceted and comes in waves, the malt is up first and it is melanoidin-rich, followed by a nice hop bitterness and a touch of floral and somewhat earthy hops flavor and then a bit of smoke on the end, strong at first but diminishing with each sip. There always seems to be linger of smoke on the end. Balanced and easy to drink. This is very nice.

Pours a hazy, orange-nut-brown with a large tan head.
Aroma is deeply smoky.....a little ham...
Taste is smoky oak,  caramel....more smoke.
A nice, easy sweetness blunts the smoke down to a pleasant backdrop instead of overdriving the point.
Brauerie Heller.....yet another fantastic beer.....thank you!

4 oz. poured into a snifter at Churchkey. From notes.

A: Pours a dark tawny color with low clarity. The head is a one finger offwhite color with a thin ring sticking to the sides of the glass.

S: Smoke. And lots of it. Really, you have to expect that coming into something thats from Bamberg. But other than the smoky notes, theres an underlying oak quality to it - and overwhelming plasticky phenols. Quite good, apart from the strong phenolic aroma.

T: I half-expected this to be one massive smoke orgy. I didnt expect it to be so impressively balanced behind a caramel malt backbone, oaky tannins, and the damn phenol notes. The finish is more smoky than the beginning, but never overdone. Each subsequent sip helps to balance the firepit-esque smoke with the maltiness increasingly. Would be great if not for the plasticky flavors.

M: The texture is pseudo-creamy with a dry, tannic finish. Lower carbonation and decent drinkability.

O: Wasnt sure what to think at first, but I started to enjoy this more as I got near the end of my little sample, suggesting this is something that needs to be savored in larger quantities. An acquired taste to be sure.

Bottle - Pours clear amber with a thin filmy light tan head. Nose is a beautiful array of lightly charred wood, smoked bacon, faint sweet bread, and a touch of dark fruit. Wow. Taste is pretty gentle and restrained for an 8% smoked doppelbock. Starts with the big sweet bread malt, rich and grainy--then transitions into a smoked jerky meatiness. Cherry cordial sweetness peeks through the smoke as it gets through the finish, ending with a sweet smokiness, real dry. Warms the belly. Medium to thin bodied, with a slickness and a bit of biting carbonation. I dont like overly sweet smoked beers, and I was worried this was going to go that route. Surprisingly it doesnt--awesome beer!

Pours golden amber red with a little off white foam. The smell is smoky and familiar like cooking ham. The taste is smooth and grainy with more of a roasted gouda taste than ham. The smoke is light and friendly and compliments without distracting. The extra lagering time comes off in a super smooth draw and light floral and berry undertones. Very easy to drink and the uniqueness of the smoked malt gets easier to palate as it goes down. Solid by itself, really nice with many foods. Traditionally simple German lager taste but done very well, unable to taste anything near 8%.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of roasted, nutty and caramel, moderate resin for the hops, light to moderate smoked gouda for the yeast, with smoke, brown sugar and bacon in the background. Head is small, fizzy, off-white with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is clear medium brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finish lightly to moderately sweet and faintly bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, slick in texture and has a soft carbonation. A thoroughly enjoyable beer. Easily one of the best Smoked beer Ive had.

Sampled on tap
The beer arrives with a hazed, amber color and is topped by a wispy, tan tinged head. This has a full on meaty, smoke character that is apparent from a distance. There is a phenolic character to the smoke here, it is definitely more spicy than the standard Beechwood Rauch malt. Touches of woody hints at barrels (am I just imagining this). There is a fruity, rich malt character in the aroma that is just barely noticeable, but really this is all about the oak smoke.

The beer tastes sweet, though there is not a lot of this, there is lots of smoke though and the middle has a richness to it, but this is not overly heavy in texture. There is a more smokiness in the finish, as well as a touch of drying, woodiness. The rich malt really showcases the richness of the smoke character. You can sense the strength of this beer, but the alcohol is not overly noticeable. This is quite smooth, it has a heft to the body, but it is not too heavy; rich, but not cloying, and it finishes quite clean.

The oak smoke is definitely dominant here, this is great if you are into that (and I am). Interestingly, the oak smoke is definitely a bit rougher than the standard beechwood character, and it is quite distinct.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2013 Gravity at Machester Winter Beer Fest - Extremely smoky aroma... Like smoked sausage... Deep mahogany red to brown in colour... Flavor is like the aroma, very smoky in character but more subtle than you would expect from the aroma... Very tasty beer..

Appearance: deep amber  like the inside of a freshly cut cedar tree. Orange pithy head fades into a thin collar of tight tiny bubbles. Swirls average.

Nose: oak and cedar gets in your face and never leaves. Umami savorance. Applewood smoke and applewood smoked bacon. Brief presence of toasted nuts in the middle. Apple cores. Spicy melted caramel in the back.

Palate: smoky, sweet, melted caramel, and nutty toffee in the back. Caramel brittle. Starts out sticky then finishes dry which induces thirst for more, thirst I am happy to oblige. Caramel coated applewood smoked bacon brittle delights. Orange oils. Charred oak in my breath. Honeycomb.

Final Thoughts: magnificence in a glass. Aecht Schlenkerla never disappoints. Never. Like sours and Bretty beers, smoked (Rauche) beers are an acquired taste but once you fall in love, you fall in love forever.

I know that I am Biased, I LOVE smoked Beer! Schlenkerla Urbock is one of my favorite all time beers, so i was excited to try this one. Pours a dark but translucent brown with a medium head. Lots of Wood, some meaty goodness and tons of smoke in the nose, I love the way these beers smell and this was no exception. Tasted of wood and smoke as well as bacon but not as intense as the smell. a slight sweetness marries with the smoke perfectly and goes beautifully with food (smoked German Sausage in this lucky mans case!) Smooth and rich on the palate but also light and fluffy as it does not leave any intense flavors in the mouth. Over all a great beer that I will have again but may not love as much as the Urbock.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy amber with a slick of off-white foam.  Aroma is rich, layered smoke with light char, bacon, and some sweeter underlying malt peaking through.  Taste is heavily smoked up front with char and ash before giving way to a very pleasant contrasting sweetness which is the richer malt and raisin from the doppelbock and even some hop bitterness on the finish.  Even, creamy mouthfeel.  A-grade smoked beer!

Pours a translucent, copper (light for the style) with visible carbonation and a frothy, white head that fades. Minimal lacing. Mesquite aroma, appropriate for a rauchbier. Full, creamy mouthfeel. Strong but not overpowering smoke flavor (like drinking a bag of BBQ potato chips).  Sweet but not too syrupy finish. Good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours copper hue with a thin layer of beige head. Smoky accent blended in nicely in a sweet malt flavor. Good drink.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Draught at Zly Casy, Prague. Amber beer with a lasting very nice offwhite head. Malty aroma, smoked, soot, sweet, toffee notes, maybe some vanilla, ash, raisins, brunt wood. Malty smoked flavor, roasted, bready, toffee, spicy notes, burnt wood, grapes, raisins, some ash. Hugely drinkable beer with a great body.

Pours dark amber with a small head.
Nose shows smoked malt, but theres a distinct oaky character to it as opposed to the usual campfire and smoke ham. Underneath is sweet caramel.
Similar oaky and smoky flavours along with more sweet malt, this time with syrupy and bready characters. Seems to be missing a little of the usual complexity.
Body is a little undercarbonated.
Not quite on par with the others from this brewery. Too sweet, and the oaky smoke and sweet malt seem a little discordant rather than complimentary as youd find in the urbock/marzen. Still really enjoyable though.

Amber-brown, yellowish highlights and oozing a spectrum of colors in between. Crowned with an airy caramel head with big bubbles separating the foam. Starts with a big wood-smoked nose. Beef jerky notes quickly emerge. Likewise beef jerky dominates the body along with maple syrup nuances. Sweet smoked jerky finish.

Aecht Schlenkerla Eiche Doppelbock is not for the faint of heart with an aroma and taste that hits you right upside the head. The key words in the description are "oak smoke". There is no mistakening the smoke aroma and the taste (more smoke) is nice with the earthy, oak flavoring mellowing it a bit and adding a distinctive character.  There is just enough alcohol bite to satisfy but not so much that it interferes with the flavors.  Its not for everyone, but a good specimen of the style.

Poured a clear deep orange color with a thin white head.  Aroma is very smokey like salami.  Taste is also quite smokey and spicy.  Still tastes like drinking a salami.  Flavorful and slightly on the sweet side with not many hops.  Very interesting and well balanced.

Orange-amber in colour with a thin but lasting off-whtie head, good lacing.  The aroma is quite smoky, lots of wood, smoked malts, some caramel, beachwood.  The flavour has some sweetness, lots of smoked malts, woody with some bacon.  Smoky mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long, smoky, rather nice.

I have a soft spot in my heart for Schlenkerla beers, this is no different.  The masters of smoke do it again.  Unreal.

500ml bottle from the Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.
Opened on December 28, 2011.
No date.

Ett öl som blivit stående då jag inte kunnat hitta ett bra svar på frågan: När dricker man en söt och stark rököl? Idag blev det i a f dags till en grillade biffar med grillad söt paprika. Trodde att sötman hos paprikan skulle matcha väl och det funkade hyfsat. Sötman var inte heller så kletig som väntat och rökigheten drog verkligen tankarna till korvgrillning i skogen. Helt okej.

16.9 oz bottle.  Pours clear copper orange with a small frothy off white head that goes to a thin film and leaves some lacing.

The aroma is nice sweet caramelly smoke (campfire and BBQ), but quickly gets subdued.

The flavor is some sweet caramel malt and bitter smoke in the finish.  The mouthfeel is a bit thin.

Overall, I probably liked this one the best of the 3 I had.  It was pretty one-sided but had no off-notes I found in the others (marzen and urbock).

10/12 0.5 l bottle on Pivkan fest, Zagreb. It poured copper body with smaller head. Nice smoked ham aroma with weaker hop spices. Flavor was dominated by the same smoked ham character, however, as usual, there was much more other things happening. Cheese, butter, some yeast, herbal hops to balance it and I guess I forgot something. Herbs make it feel a bit more watery though. Medium in body with pleasant, long finish that was only reflecting the flavor, ending as sweetish malt and delicate ham. I liked this one for sure, although admittedly not as much as other exquisite beers from this brewery. I did set my expectations too high.

Pretty much a random pick up.  This should say "campfire" on it because it reminded of all the good aspects of one.  Beautifully smokey, with plenty of hops and malts to make it interesting and balanced.  Bacon.  some dairy.  smooth.  good.
Big smokey, woody aromas. Pours a deep amber with no head. Taste is both sweet and mildly bitter, smokey. A nice earthy, smokey beer.

I thoroughly enjoyed this Doppelbock chose it on a wim. Pours reddish amber color yet  clear, minimal head, has a nice smokey taste a bit like bacon,mouth feel is a little dry and lightly bitter, lightly sour with medium body, thin feel, average carbonation, long finish. A bit woodsy and very smokey. I would definitely revisit this Dopplebock.

Pours a lot lighter than I expect in a doppelbock.  Heavy smoke in the aroma.  Flavor starts sweet with some caramel, vanilla, and toffee.  Smoke and a little bitter hops in the aroma.  Im not a huge fan of smoked beer, but this is good.
Smoky woodsy aroma. Nice sweet malty taste, even some hoppy bitterness and smoke. Reddish colour with not much head. Good rauchbier.

Bottle to stange glass.
Smoke aroma is brilliant with a pear, caramel and bacon. Pours a clear deep amber with no head. Taste is of roasted malt and ham.

Bottle - Smells like a campfire and some sweetness.  Islay scotch drinkers dream.  Clear amber with little to no head.  Smoke and peat doesnt  translate into taste, but a nice sweet roasted malt flavor.  Banana notes and very smooth.  Grate beer to finish the night.

500 ml bottle purchased almost 1.5 years ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($5.99).  Pours an orange-amber hue with a finger and a half of white foam.  Aroma of wet leather, oak campfire, and smoked meats (beef jerky and burnt bacon).  Flavor of smoky caramel, old leather, smokehouse meats, and soy sauce with some good honey and fruity notes.  Finishes very dry with some lingering mellow sweetness.  ABV is well concealed.  Not quite as good as Schlenkerlas Urbock, but I still enjoyed this one.  (461, 704)
Reminded me of my father-in-laws smokehouse... Smokey and meaty.  Pretty good, but being a dopplebock I had expected perhaps a little more going on than just the smokiness.

The head is robust, the body is brown red. it smells very intensive smoky-ham. The taste is very intensive smoky, oak, a bit alcoholic and ham. In th aftertaste a bit sweet. Very intensive and very good beer! 12/12/12/13/13/13

50cl bottle pours a crystal clear amber with thin white head. The aroma offers up yummy loads of dried smoked pork and some smooth smoke wafting about a tiny ring of date meat. The taste has classic dry smoked pork goodness and then it picks up only more heading to midway. Behind the smooth smoke are modest levels of sweet dates and sweet maltiness with a dash of ripe sweet cherries. Im not sure I notice the difference in wood type used here. Good stuff.
Sweet and meaty aroma. Dark amberish body; thin head. Flavor same as aroma, sweet and meaty. Cant tell the difference between beech and oak.
Pours a beautiful translucent mahogany with a small light colored head. Aroma of hunting lodge campfire. Tastes like it smells and no dissapointments.

Oh my this beer is awesome.  Smells like ham, jerky... like an orgy of smoked meat covered in a malty sweet glaze of love.  The smokiness on this beer makes it taste like bacon.  I love bacon, who doesnt, but the sweet malt taste, the bacon and the nuttiness are beautiful balanced.  highly enjoyable.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A.
Rated on 20110627.
Pours clear dark red color with small head. Aroma of very strong smoky ham, sweetish malts and dark fruit notes. Flavor of ham, mild liquorice notes and malts. Slightly bitter palate and even some sourish notes. Nice smoky brew but doesnt quite meet my expectations.
4425

Rating #734, bottle from Fish N Beer. Lighter appearance than expected and ok head. Aroma is quite subdued, smoke, caramel and malts. Flavor is smoky at most, but also caramellish and sweet malty. Only a touch of the bitter finish, and alcohol is very subdued for the 8%. Round and thick palate.
500ml bottle from knightly spirirts. FL VC #21. amber small white head. low carbonation. big smoke nose. well made bock with nice smokey accent. not my fav from this brewer.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a medium, lasting ivory head, over a clear light brown (SRM 17) body.....nose is light smoke, toffee/caramel....taste is smoke, toffee/caramel, hints of sweetness, finishing with a light bitterness....mouth feel medium, carbonation low. This is a milder smoke than others from this brewery. It is a pleasant, easy drinking beer. BJCP 8/3/14/4/7

Bottle. Pours a hazy brownish orange with a small bubbly off-white head that doesnt last long. Even though they have used a different wood to smoke the malt this still has that particular smokey aroma distinctive to this brewery with notes of smoked ham, ash, caramel, beef jerky and almonds. Flavour is about the same as the aroma: smokey, meaty, nutty, malty and slightly sweet. Mouthfeel is thick and oily with restrained soft carbonation and a long smokey finish. Despite being a fan of the beers from Schlenkerla, I have to say this one really comes together: superbly balanced with perfectly integrated alcohol and exhibiting the best flavours and aroma this style has to offer.

Hoooo boy! This is a full rack of baby backs in a glass. Deep amber pour, with a fizzy, dissipating head. Serious smoke on the nose, with cured meats that make this really smell like a butcher shop. Burnt brown sugar and molasses lie behind, lending a note not too unlike a good scotch. Thick mouthfeel, with just enough carb to keep it from being sticky, and the style (smoked doppelbock) keeps it just a bit on the sweet side. Guess that makes this a Kansas City brew, not a Carolina brew. This beer makes me want to develop a drawl, then undercook and devour a giant steak. Ron Swanson doesnt always drink beer, but when he does, he prefers the Schlenkerla.

Clear amber color with a little white head. Big aroma of bacon. Heavy smoky malt flavor but cant really pick up the doublebock profile. Was hoping for some more maltiness to counterbalance the smokiness.

16.9 oz. bottle- Pours autumn amber with a thin off white head that reduces immediately to a collar, there is sediment floating around. The aroma is smoked pork, very campfire like, I love that aroma. The taste is similar, it tastes like ham, smoked ham, wood, malt presence, dry ash. Body is medium, carbonation is medium low. Overall I really liked this beer, a meal in a glass.

Purchased at Armanettis in Chicago, IL; enjoyed on a cold early May Friday afternoon before seeing the Avengers.  I tried to get this when I was at Schlenkerla in Bamberg, but found it in a store near home thousands of miles from there.  Go figure.  Appearance is a very cloudy golden amber with a very small white head that rims around the glass.  Aroma is very burnt, almost more burnt than the marzen, more of a ham presence than bacon, kind of smells like a burned out campfire the following morning.  Taste is definitely potent, not as smoky as the marzen in flavor, its still pretty smooth.  Im convinced that ham fat is brewed into the beer.  Its not particularly malty but there is a presence of malt.  This is an excellent beer, one of the best doppelbocks Ive had for sure.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle is dark reddish with thin off whtie head, aroma is a smack in the face of smoke, oak, woody notes, hints of chocolate, bacon and campfire, salty pork and slight caramel.  Taste is much more balanced, sweet caramel covered bacon, earth, dark cocoa powder, big campfire and salt pork notes, finishing fairly sweet, dries out well.  Holy moly, I have been missing out.

500ml bottle in a lager glass.  Pours copper with a lacy, cream-colored head.  Aroma of barbecue and smokiness, some caramel and nuttiness in the malts, and floral hops.  Flavor about the same.  Average texture.  Not bad, but I dont know if its one of the best smoked beers.

On tap at Qbrick. Dark orange-brown, thin head. Cant really tell the difference in aroma between the regular beech smoked ones and this oak smoke brew, but the taste is remarkably different. Coca-Cola dark translucent brown. Initially this seems milder than the regulars, but it the sweet deep maltiness kicks in. Sweet, smooth, with a mild aftertaste. Ramped up stuff. Couldnt be smoother, but it might stand just a little less sweetness.

Eeeeeooooo. All I have to say is smoked salmon. 

Bottle from bev warehouse

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Pours cloudy reddish orange color with a small 1 finger dense light khaki head with good retention that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Some minimal lacing on the glass.  Aromas of big wood, smoked meat, charcoal, raisin, molasses, caramel, toffee, banana, apple, and herbal spiciness.  Very nice and well balanced aromas with good complexity.  The smoked aspect compliments the standard doppelbock aromas nicely.  Taste of caramel, molasses, raisin, smoke, wood, ham, toffee, biscuit, pepper, light citrus, and herbal spiciness.  Lingering notes of smoke, caramel, molasses, biscuit, and fruitiness on the finish for a good bit.  Great balance of flavors, with more standard doppelbock flavors going on; without the smokiness becoming too overwhelming.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a nice creamy and fairly slick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed at all.  Dangerously smooth to drink for 8%, but is definitely great to sip on.  Overall this is an excellent and highly enjoyable smoked doppelbock.  Great balance of flavors, without the smoke being over the top.  Great stuff.

Poured into a pint glass. Transparent amber color, only the faintest head.

Rich malt smell, lots of smoke, but a "clean" smelling smoke with a crispness to it.

The smoke is first in the taste, followed by the traditional doppelbock maltiness, then the smoke overpowers the malt again. It is really a smoke show here. Fairly sweet throughout too.

Soft texture, medium body, low carbonation but still tingles the tongue.

The doppelback flavor is lost in the smoke and the appearance was average. Still a good drink.

16.9 oz bottle. Aroma is nice and smoky, as expected; reminds me of smoked fish. The wood comes through, too. Pours hazy copper with a medium collapsing off-white head; collapses into a collar of big-bubbly foam. Taste is sweet and smoky with a light tang. Flavor is a bit appley. Carbonation and body are medium. Another great smoked beer. I prefer the weizen and the marzen over this, but this is really good. All taste buds still present and accounted for.
Oh sweet lord gross. Tastes like tree bark and burnt bacon. Whoever rates this beer high better check if they still have taste buds.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2013 Bottle @ Abseits, Bamberg. Very nice rauchbier, very strong but easy drinkable. Full of taste: smokey and some fruity sweetness (port), nice strong aftertaste.

Shared with Dutchdrebus @ In de Wildeman, Amsterdam. Clear orange to copper color, small white to off-white head. Smell and taste malts, smoke and an incredible lot of bacon. Average carbonation and body. Not my thing at all.

Bottle. Head is initially small, fizzy, light brown, fully diminishing. Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, toasted bread), lightly hoppy (apricot), with notes of smoke (ham, salmon, ash), band-aid, alcohol, fish sauce, cake icing. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, fizzy carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. This is my second experience with the bottles that just showed up in CO, and I did this review with glasses of Maerzen and Urbock (also new batches that just arrived) side by side for comparison.  The Eiche has the most meaty smoke character, and its even fishy, which is both neat and icky...under the smoke, not much, just some caramel and bread really, some band-aidy plastic and maybe some apricotty hops which are pleasant on their own but dont mesh very well with the meaty smoke.  Some weird candy-cake smell comes out at times too, which also clashes.  So, some good aspects, but really jumbled and messy.  The Maerzen is ridiculously ashy this time, like a cigarette ashtray...unpleasant even, almost like a carpet fire, some yucky phenols perhaps (plastic/rubber).  Its usually not like that, but its the worst aroma of the three.  As is usually the case in bottle form, the Urbock wins.  Ive had better batches, but its got the usual nice woody and lightly meaty smoke (turning ashy the less liquid that remains in the glass), rich bready malt, some dark dried fruit (dates), and nice herbal hops.  Both the Maerzen and Urbock offered solid lasting heads (Urbock being the largest and creamiest), whereas the Eiche head disappears completely almost immediately.  The Eiche is also the lightest in color by quite a margin (Urbock being slightly darker than the Maerzen), although that doesnt affect the score, just an observation.  In the mouth, the Eiche is the biggest loser...overly sweet and quite fizzy, absolutely no fun to drink.  Gotta say Im surprised and disappointed in the Eiche...expected way, way, way better. But even the mighty Urbock isnt quite up to par this time, so it was probably just an off time at the brewery in general (and hopefully temporary, gulp!).

Clear rufous. Small eggshell head soon dies after decanting. Simple but fairly pleasant aromas of wintergreen, smoked grass clippings, petroleum jelly, prosciutto and light manure. Takes a vigorous swirl to coax the mineral and characterful lager yeast. Some muted fruity esters, as well. Curiously scant carbonation. Sturdy residuals are countered by that signature Heller-Trum cleanness which gives way to oily prosciutto and petroleum-jelly-tinged smoke. Firm base of woodiness is tastefully incorporated, as its clean to the point of exuding with a ghostlike presence yet manages to deepen some the "greasier" rauch character. Secondary grains barely exude with a dry and cookielike twinge, yet are simultaneously bouncy with vague notions of straw. Delightfully luscious and hearty bock character gracefully buoys the wood-laden smoke. After a few sips, the drinkability suffers as things teeter on the brink of medicinal due to the alcohol combining with the unfermented sugars. Little in the way of mineralic snap to be found, though the yeast compensates nicely to add lift as well as character. Gentle ashy scratchiness provides a welcome contrast to the slippery esters. Closes with a fleeting glimpse of biscuity Munich malt and fruity slickness, with a floral and vaguely peppery hop zing along with sweeter dabs of red licorice and brown sugar. As one can expect from this brewery, this is exceptionally clean and devoid of flaw. But with appropriate levels of carbonation along with a better showing of some dusty dextrins, this likely would be downright divine. Otherwise, as is, this is just a tad sweet/sugary.  Pretty nice, though.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a copper amber with minimal head and lacing.  Aroma forward with smoke, caramel, and sweet malt.  Flavor is actually a lot more complex than the aroma let on.  If more smoke beers were like this one, I could definitely start enjoying the style a bit more.

#1339 draught; Nose is some sweet apricot, medium sweet smoke, red apple, sweet alcohol whiff, feel is medium, carb Is mediumweak, taste is quite heavy cedar, sweet mediumweak smoke, cooked vegetables, then sweet, broad malt,
Clear copper colour with a small white head. Smells bacon, bacon and bacon. Tastes bacon, malts, wood and smoke. And bacon. Nice carbo, medium body.
Considering that Rauchbier is my favorite style, this is the best Rauchbier that Ive ever had,

Pours a slightly hazy copper amber color with a tiny white head that quickly dissipates into nothing. Smells like smoked cheese and cured meat, with some toffee. Taste is very smokey with sweet malts, barely, caramel, toffee, faint citrus notes from the hops, and some booze. This is almost a smoked barely wine. Texture is very smooth and creamy. After taste is clean and warm from the alcohol. This ones dominant character is the smokiness, but it has a lot of other complex flavors and a lot to enjoy.
Bottle. Clear amber7brown with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, smoke, meat and a little caramel. Flavour is malt, smoke, oak, medium sweet, meat, little caramel, little toffee.
Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, wood and rather smoky - bacon. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 130312

Bottle: Another gem from oakbluffs cellar during my latest Winnipeg tasting. Pours hazy orange, with a tawny hue. Thin off-white head, spotty lacing. Nose is bacon, campfire, cedar smoke, and prunes. Great nose, really jumps out of the glass at you. Flavours of tar, creosote, bacon, sweet fig, so much smoke, and so very good.

.5l bottle from Kuca Piva in Zagreb. Pretty, golden deep orange, clear, with light soapy bright white head. Low carbonation, and loses it quickly. Aroma of champagne yeast, oak, light smoked ham. Great body, alc weight and the smoke go so well together, finishes crisp and relatively dry. Slightly oily and smooth. light wood smoke, ham/pork. A bit tame in the end for the brewery, but very nice.

This needs a bit of concentration. The initial aroma is over powering smoke. However, the smoke seems a little basic, without any great complexity of aroma. The sweetness of the aroma reminds one of smoked salmon or pancetta initially. Eventually, after a few mouthfuls this character dulls allowing the bitterness of the hops comes through, but not to any great extent. Ultimately you are left with a stodgy mouth feel of smoke that screams sausage! Normally Im a fan of smoke, but in this context, it seems not to evolve in the way that an Islay malt does or a whisky matured beer might - try peat next time! :)

16.9 oz bottle from Spirits Red Bank. Poured a clear super deep amber brown body with a tiny tight foamy light beige head. The aroma is really excepttional  for  a smoked, somewere between a campfire and smoked meats and fish along with a slight hint of and aid. Palate is a bit fuller and the carbonation is a little bit foamy than I was expecting. Flavor is very similar to the aroma but the complexity comes through a bit more and the flavor transitions easily between smoked meat, fish, and pure campfire smoke along with some smoked breads. Good stuff and if you can handle smoke this is a top beer.
