Clear deep amber pour smallish head but solid mild if any carbonation the aromas smokey cooked bacon caramel woodyness dark fruit that is smoked sharp notes flavours wow the tastes have come together so well the smoothest tasting smokey beer you could want the fruit comes up superbly lovely hop taste oak inflence like a tonic to better the already wonderful tastes sweet caramel malts light earthyness medium bitter the bacon smokeyness so good on the palate lucky kermit the finish a masterpiece by heller frun aftertastes of pure delight in smoked tastes the fruit hops maltiness superb oak influence it mixes so well with the smokeyness a sweetness and bitter of good balance a dopplebock to remember

The bronze colored body was clear, and the head that formed was a very small ring of bubbles.  While the looks were quite timid for a Doppelbock, the smell was anything but.  The smoked Bamberg malts were prominent, and gave this beer a smoky, sweet aroma evocative of pork ribs.  The taste continue the theme of the smell, with a real smoke laden flavor backed by good deal of sweetness.  The hops were there in the finish, but only provided a restrained drying note, instead of an overt bitterness.  The sticky and smooth feel on the palette and a drawn out smoky finish that ended each sip were both very classy.  The smoked malts seem to do very well in a Dopplebock style.  Now please brew a Trippelbock like Samichlaus with these.
bottle.   big potent meaty smoked salmon.  toasty, carmalized brown sugar.  sweet doughy malts.  nice clean meaty smoke focused beer.  nice.  alcohol well hidden.   pretty good stuff.

Draught @ The Rover. Pours hazy dark brown with a big off-white head that slowly dissipates while leaving lots of lacing on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet and full-bodied with smoke, sweet fried fruits like dates, prunes and raisins, dark bread, bread spices, wood and resin. Taste is slightly sweet, slightly bitter and tiny sour with wood, smoke, resin, plums, raisins, dates, figs, dark bread and spices. Mouthfeel is full-bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and slightly tart with sweet fruits and smoke. Amazing tasting beer!

Simply shimmers in the glass, a radiant, deep, ruddy copper with no evident carbonation. A little white atop, residual from the pour, and then nothing. Hints of toffee, steinbier-esque caramelised sugars, oak aged Whisky, stewed sweetened plums and rhubarb, and a hint of sherry sits under layers of smoke, heather, smoked pork and other meats, and charred wood. A light touch of vanillin over toffee and caramel starts it off in the mouth, its not sweet, but it edges it. Body is medium, the carbonation so very soft its got a barrel aged quality. The oak smoke gives a Whisky quality to it, the fruit of the aroma disappears under the peaty, smoked meat and ash notes. Long, dry, malty thick and smoky aftertaste, yields the alcohol well. Smooth, rounded finish. Nice hops, the Hallertauer placed so finely just as it slips past the tonsils, raches into the olfactories.  And interesting brew, so far from the rest of Heller Trum, but absolutely delicious none the less. Smooth, modest, and a little more subtle than the Märzen. Very good drinking! (50cL, no date stamp, Mane Liquor, Belmont)

Bottle 500ml from Purvis. Exceptional, super-malty beer. Aromas of smoke, caramel, nuts, liquorice, and oak. Taste is sweet, with light bitterness, and very long length. Palate is syrupy, and full bodied. Brown, with a frothy head.
UPDATED: MAR 29, 2015 Brown colour. Heavy smoke aroma. Sweet, Rich flavour of smoked meat, nutty, some caramel.

500ml bottle. Poured medium orangey-brown with a short, tight-bubbled smoked beige head. The aroma picked up sweet, smoky malts first and foremost, with nutty notes and a little vanilla beneath.. nice, but fairly one-dimensional. The flavor found toasted caramel and nutty notes at the core.. sweet, smoky malts everywhere as expected, picking up some leafy bitterness on the edges.. tangy oak notes showed on the finish, working well with the campfire smoke. Medium-bodied at most on the palate, with low carbonation.. really tasty stuff!

Wow! Thanks cesaro202 for sharing! Dark amber color with a minimal disappearing white head. Medium body, carbonation starts high, than slows. Slightly smoked aroma, caramel. Taste is sweet with a very pleasant smoked note which lasts on your tongue. Bittersweet

500 mL bottle from Sheffield Tap into a Jupiler Tauro glass at home.  Orange red with a short-lived bubbly head, generally a little gassy.  Smokey but not excessive, with some oak in there too, nice on the palate.  Must admit I didnt get the best out of the aroma because of a cold coming on.  Still, this is pretty tasty.
Tried this after some time in the fridge. Softer than expected. Amber colour, medium head. Not very bitter, but sweet maltiness well balanced by moderate smoke. Very smooth and likeable.

Bottle from Systembolaget, Sweden.
No head. Golden amber color. The most plesent and smoke aroma Ive experienced. Very oaky taste and a fresh bitterness.

I picked this one up because it said "Doppelbock" on the label.  As soon as I opened it, I said "WOW" for the first time in the last 20 different beers I tried. It is quite different than what I expected.  I call this one bacon beer.  It pours a clear dark amber/copper color with  a tiny off-white head and practically no lacing.  I first said "WOW" when I smelled it, and again on the first sip.  Nose, aroma  and aftertaste are all primarily smoked bacon or smoked ham. There is neither bitterness or sweetness on the tongue.  Perhaps it tastes a bit salty, but that is what I expect of bacon or cured ham.  It hides the 8% ABV well. (until after youve finished it).  Body is at least medium with a smooth mouthfeel and not much carbonation.  Ill very gladly try this one on another day when I skipped breakfast.  This is to doppelbocks what Hormel Cure 81 is to kosher foods.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 (0,5l Bottle)  Gigantic  smoke clouds  , of course its Schlenkerla call the fire-department and  that is why you pay your enterance money  $  firy  dark bronze with flakey beige that dies too soon;  probing smoked nose , ham, apple-wood chese and a genuine splintered  woodiness messhed together to make a powerful stench ....  on the palate  its got that  pronouced uncompromising smokiness ,with dryness both of the smoked and hopPed varity :  You get your ass smoked and the 8% isnt even there.!

Shared with evil stepdad. Deep amber with a dencet off-white head. Great wooden charcoal smoke aroma mixed with bread and baker goods. Smokey moutharoma aswell, thick sweet palate, sweet malty flavor.

Dark orange with fluffy beige head. Smokey but so well balanced like sweetcured maple smoked Bacon. Very nice
pours an amber orange with a flat head. Aroma is smokey and malt. Flavor is overly smokey with hints of banana. Has a bit of leather tasting finish.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2017 [1/12] Bottle. Clear copper with an off white head that fades. Aroma of smoke and toffee. Soft mouthfeel is just short of syrupy. Taste is rich and sweet but surprisingly delicate - lightened by creeping bitterness. Some dried fruit and spice in amongst the caramel. The smoke too is gentle - enveloping and less strident than the beechwood varieties. Lovely balance. [3.9] [4/17] And the sweetness lingers a little long for my tastes now. And the underlying malt is clean and lovely but perhaps not all that interesting.

0,5 l bottle as a gift.
Deep amber colored beer with reddish tones, small lacing tan head. Smoke and smoke, barbecue, sausages in the nose, ham and some caramel in the background. Easier body than expected, smooth mouthfeel. Caramel based flavor profile with a well balanced smokiness with oak, ham and burnt wood, cheese and sausage. Well made, fine and delicious

bottled, at klub malych pivovaru. good work by petr, getting another crate of this in and at a very reasonable 49 crowns per bottle. deep amber, small head; black forest ham aroma, faint butterscotch and tinny bitterness. no sign of the higher alcohol content except for a fuller body, excellent stuff

500 ml Bottle - shared with buds at Aarons German brew tasting last night.. Pours a cloudy deep brown with a thick beige head. Nose is all bacon and  smoked malts. Yummy smoked meat flavors with a lingering smokiness that lasts and lasts.  This is one nice beer.

Pours transparent copper with a small white head. Nose is burnt hot dog with a hint of candy sugar.  Grease from a French fryer. Taste is smoky, sweet with a small bitter finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy in the front with a sharp bite at the end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Light smoked wood and some soft fruit in the aroma. Deep amber with a thin head. Flavour is light bacon with plum and wood. Finish is smooth and leads to a long long palate
smoked blue cheese and ham. Rich body smooth mellow compared to their other beers. A bit of oak, cream cheese and cured ham. Lovely easy drinking sipper.

500ml Bottle - Amber with a slight haze and a foamy head. Dried apricot, smoked ham, ash and malt in the aroma. Smoky taste with notes of dried fruit, malt and smoked malt. Theres a lot going on here, but its still rather accessible and not too overwhelming.
Bottle. Amber pour with a very small sized head. Aromas were meaty and smoky. Tastes of the same with caramel, and ashy.

Sörspecialista, Budapest.
Gesztenyebarna színe van, ami erős fény elé tartva, borostyánkőként ragyog. Habja vékony, krémes, törtfehér és gyorsan, nyomnélkül eltűnik. Illata édeskés, juharszirupos, fás és füstöltszalonnás. Ízében nagyon szépen keverednek az édes, mézes és aszaltgyümölcsös jegyek, az égetett bükkfás, szalonnabőrös, dohányfüstös zamatokkal, a kesernyés komlóval és a magasabb alkohol tartalommal. Elég testes, de nemtúl sűrű, enyhén buborékos és a magas alkoholtartalom sem túl kirívó. Utóíze mint egy édesebb pipadohányé, kellemesen száraz, kesernyés és igen hosszan tart. Nagyon különleges és igen finom portéka, ami hiába erős, rendkívüli módon itatja magát.

Aroma is outrageously smoky, color is clear ruby red... Flavor is mildly sweet initially of caramel malts and slightly watery.... Finish is entirely smoky bitterness, slightly less flavorful and complex than I expected after having the Rauchebier, still pretty solid...

0.5L bottle, enjoyed @Amundsen, Oslo. Misty reddish-brown body. Low greyish blond head leaving fine laces. Sweet, refined bready malts to the nose. A touch of ash and meat, too. Prononced smoke and burnt wood tones in the flavor. Nicely balanced by a clean and rounded malt-sweetness. Pepper and mild bitterness underneath. Balanced and easy on the palate. An utterly complex beer with the smoke character very well integrated. Lovely!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2016 Bottle.  Dark brown beer with low carbonation.  Good smoke aroma, and good smoke flavor. Some caramel, and malt.  This is a great beer, but the palate is thinner, and the smoke flavor and aroma is less intense than the standard bock.

From bottle. Oaky smoky malt, caramel sweetness. Smoke-cured ham and sweet sausage, campfire. No hop aroma. Copper amber clear with thin foamy head. Medium watery body with medium carbonation. Starts sweet with doppelbock malty richness, followed by a big hit of smoky goodness thats not overpowering. Woody, oaky, hop bitter finish with lots of smoke. After is lingering caramel and smoke. Delicious and pairs well with chili and hearty meats or stews.

Clear amber color with fleeting head. Nice smoked hardwood, meaty,nutty,  toasted caramel aromas. medium bodied with soft co2. Smoked almond, caramel, woody, dark fruit flavors--but its mostly smoke--good stuff
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Brown color with a small, tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of smoked wood, some roast, caramel malts, and burnt tobacco. Taste of tobacco, smoked wood, meats, lighter caramel, tobacco, and sweeter finish.

500ml bottle.  Pours a dark orange with a small head.  Aroma is smoked ham and wood.  Taste has smoked ham to start and more on the finish, with some ash and wood.  Low carbonation but full in the mouth.

A dark copperbrown beer with a quite weak and blond head. Aroma is very temptating, tar liquirice, ham and smoke. Taste is similar than aroma, full and rich, smoke, tar liquirice and slightly drying aftertaste. Medium bodied, smooth and slippery, easy to enjoy. Feels lighter than alc. % tells. Very tastefull beer again from Schlenkerla, the battle is tight against Urbock. Balanced, even "light", very enjoyable beer.

poured from bottle into a stein. Pours a dark orange color with a small and foamy head

very smoked based aromas as would be expected from a smoke beer. Good aromas as well of navel oranges, malts and some caramel aromas as well

fuller bodied with lots of smoke flavors that are expected. Good flavors and a very nice feel with flavors of smoke, malts and dark oranges

I love the smoke flavors from aecht. This carries it through very well along with excellent flavors on both the aromas and feel.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2012 In bottle. Pours a dark golden colour with a white head that dies away early. Aroma of smoked fish, bonito flakes and caramel. Similar flavours with salty, fishy smoke prominent. More like a Marzen, I expected this to be heavier. A little sweet to finish with mild carbonation and light CO2 prickle. Lingering smoke. OK. (8,2,7,2,16). Had this again on cask at the 2012 NWAF, Manchester. Poured a golden brown colour with a fair white head. Aroma of smoked fish, sweet caramel and wood. Similar flavours with woody, smoked malt, caramel and oak notes that linger. Moderate carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. (8,4,8,3,16).

Pint bottle. Awesome mild hazy orange color, lots of fine particles suspended inside. Foamy off-white head fading to minimal. Huge smoke aroma, with an aftertaste that lasts and lasts. You can just sit there after a sip, for a half-minute, and think of nothing but that awesome savory taste. Very light, crisp and smooth carbonation, a great texture and mouthfeel. I love that campfire taste, and its hint of alcohol warmth. Awesome savory light sweet taste. The famous German smoked beer has yet to disappoint me.

From notes: Pours hazy orange-amber with a small bone-colored head.  Light, spicy smoky aroma.  Medium-bodied but deep.  Mildly smoky taste, with a nice bite to it that intensifies in the finish.  Light pine note underneath.  Very different from the Urbock, but I like it.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2012 Bottled, rating # 600:  Deep reddish beer with brown edges and a foamy, mostly stable off white head, leaving nice lacings. Aroma is soft smoke, chacuterie, malts, caramel, figs and noble hops. Taste is malty sweetness, campfire and notes of freshly smoked ham leading to dry, smoky, bitter finish.

Bottle. Deep red brown. Impressive nose. Kippers. Arbroath smokies. It tastes very particular and unique. I struggle with rauchbier though. I appreciate its individuality but just dont get a kick out of its flavour..

1 PINT 0.9 Fl OZ bottle from Finger Lakes Beverage, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Clear bright copper with a fair tan head.
  
Aroma:  That oh-so-typical Bamberger smoke  very meaty, sorta medicinal and metallic, my nose cant quite differentiate the oak vs beech  rich, fruity, sticky malts beneath the smoky vale, esters, restrained minty, cola-like herbals, this style stands up well to the smoke.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, relaxed effervescence.
  
Flav.:  The smoke is nicely integrated into rich, fruity, brown sugar, sticky malts, so much sweet malt, still some esters and faint minty herbals, quite interesting; fairly sweet with some bitterness and a long, somewhat smoky, rich malt finish.

Ive come to respect these brews quite a bit.

Complex smokey aroma. A bit like walking into old wooden mountain cabin that has a fire going, and fresh hops are drying by the fire.  Color is a flat pale copper, almost smoky haze. Upfront taste is small bite of hops followed by blast of smoke.  Finishes with melange of malt (Vienna?), hops, and burnt wood.  I think the smoke is bordering on overpowering.  I feel that if the smoke level could be reduced by 20%, it would improve the final product significantly. However, it is enjoyable and definitely one to try again.

Clear mahogany coloured pour with a small off-white head.
Sweet, smoky nose and aroma ruled by caramel, fruits and (not overwhelming) alcoholy sweetness underpainted gently by smoked wood and some hops.
The oily moutfeeled brew finishes warming and sweetbitter with toast, spices and citrusses.
Concinnated one with a well hidden alcohol content, which make it easy drinkable.

Dark caramel colored pour. No head to really speak of, no lacing left behind. Obviously. Huge bacony smoke bomb aroma. Theres really nothing else to try and smell in there. Like sitting next to a campfire and cooking pork butt all day long. Then drinking. Not as much smoke in the mouth on first sip, but after swallowing you can really taste the smoke reappear in your mouth. Delicious. A little bit on the thin side, and a slight bit of sweetness. But overall, very good.

Draft at the downtown tap, begrudgingly provided by the bar keep -- Deep, pitch black and slick in its goblet.  Pitch black, perhaps a bit thinner than you might expect.  Of course, exceptionally smoky of course, but woven well into a fair winter warmer.  (#4387, 12/2/2011)

From bottle. Pours a very nice copper/red/amber colour, zero head, nothing. Aroma of burning wood, caramel and toffee. Similar taste. The smoke is quite pleasant, bit too much alcohol. Sweet and sticky with an alcohol burn. Some interesting stuff going on mixed with some stuff Im not in to

Nice copper orange with ethereal off-white head.  Aroma smoked wood, jerky, faint sweetness in background.  Medium body, slight amount of alcohol.  Flavor is smoky but not as much as would expect from the aroma, there is also some malt, some butterscotch-like sweetness, and faintly vegetal background with dry finish.  Interesting, wouldnt have it every day but good for something different.

Bottle, from Trembling Madness, York. Copper gold, thin but lasting white head and gentle condition. Intially seems quite muted in the nose before a delicate but pronounced wood smoke note emerges backed by a gentle sweet burnt toffee aroma. Sweet and smooth mouthfeel with more toffee notes and a teasing wood smoke note that is quite dry. Lingering finish with a quick burst of sweetness before subsiding to a dry woody smokiness. Any suggestion of alcoholic strength is dangerously well hidden on the palate but soon makes its presence felt in the head.

Pours a fairly dark orange/brown.  The head doesnt last long.  Huge smoky aroma with a hint of sweetness.  The flavour has smoke, but not too strong.  There a vanilla and creme caramel in there.  Lovely.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours transparent deep golden.  Little lacing, low carbonation, and  medium body.  Taste is malt, smoke, some oak,, and a hint of meat.

Sörspecialista, Budapest. Tükrös, konyakra emlékeztető színe van, és csak nagyon kevés sárgás habot fejleszt, ami szinte rögtön el is illan. Illatában egyből megragad a füstölt húsos aroma, amihez nagyon jól passzol a fás, hordós és enyhén likőrös illat. Az ízvilágát egy fokkal komplexebbnek vélem, a hordós, füstölt húsos fő ízek mellett érett banán, édeskés likőrösség, gyümölcsös maláta és pillanatnyi ideig érezhető füves komló kerül a képbe. Olajos, igen testes ez a füstölt duplabak, amely a füstöltsége ellenére sem rendelkezik túl erőteljes ízvilággal, melynek köszönhetően egészen könnyen csúszik, ami annak is betudható, hogy igen magas alkoholfoka alig érezhető. Különleges sör, egyszer mindenkinek érdemes kipróbálni!

Bottle/500ml - Pours a dark amber in color with a very small off-white head that settled to a thin covering over the beer, but stuck around to produce a minor amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is strong of wood smoke and little else.  Flavor is reminiscent of drinking wood ashes, but in a much more pleasant way... I dont get the Hallertau hops descibed and there is just a bit too much smoke for me...

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2013 pours pale golden, slight haze, with a decent white cap, little retention. aroma is a deliciously complex smoked profile, bready malts, vinous, white port, yeasts. taste includes light but fairly present german noble hops, crisp but slightly sweet malts, biscuity. average to soft carbonation, medium body, mellow finish with fairly present grassy-citrusy hops. not boozy. plain (i mean complex) goodness!
Bottle.  Pours a clouded auburn brown color with a beige head. Tons of smoked meat in the aroma. Delicious flavor with a lingering mesquite smokiness.  Great aftertaste.
Pours a dark caramel color with no head.  Overpowering aroma of wood smoke-like a campfire.  Flavor is largely smoke with some underlying caramel malt sweetness.  A very nice beer.

Sampled September 2011; this Rauchbier brewed with Oak Smoke Malt aroma reminded me of a smell that would linger on your coat the day after being around a camp fire.   Strong head, amber, medium bodied, moss, earth and burnt oak all in the flavor.  My first taste of this beer I thought the smokiness was over bearing but it settled on my palate.

500ml bottle.

Pours a slightly hazy orangy copper with a thin wispy head.

The smell is lots of smoke. Smells like a bonfire with really no other smell being apparent. I love it!

The taste is extremely smoke-forward followed by an assertive bitterness that increases toward the finish. The smoke seems more pronounced and forceful in this beer compared to the others from Schlenkera. Very nice.

I love smoke beers and I have to say that the ones from Schlenkera are probably the best examples made. While I prefer the Urbock over this one, it is still exceptional. Just perfect for a fall evening.
Both the aroma and taste oozes with smoked sausage, smoked ham and roasted (and smoked) malt. A small minus is that the taste gets a little too sour in the long run. But otherwise a great smoke-beer!

(500 ml bottle from Global Beverage) Pours auburn-amber, bright and clear. Two fingers of level off-white head. Aroma of pure smoked meat - Easter ham and maple-cured bacon.  Mouthfeel smooth and meaty. Flavor of sweet smoked goodness over a nice thick caramel malt base. Its just a great balance here, the smoke is so beautifully integrated, and I love the 8%!  A smoke masterpiece.

bottle
This hazy amber pour had minimal carbonation. The aroma was of salami, uncooked bacon and other lunchmeats. Its nice and smokey.

Bottle and served in pint glass: Clean medium amber hue with a small and fading head and okay lace. The aroma is what you expected, smoky wood , tobacco and meat vapours run amok along with some nice caramel and pils malt notes. A touch of apple and rum raisin as well. The taste is a moderate smoked meat and earthy overtone with a sweet wood and caramel background. While this beer is a bit one note, it is a note played very well. Much like the nose, there is a subdued fruity quality I like as well. The mouth feel is smooth and a tad oily with an ashy finish, way under carbonated, nearly flat. Overall an okay brew but I prefer the Schlenkerla Fastenbier and Schlenkerla Rauchbier Weizen  much much more, my least favorite of the five Schlenkerla beers I have tried.

Bottle opened at my wifes 30th birthday party - courtesy of Bierkrug and shared with some locals. Bierkrug warned me that this was a great beer - he was right! This was the surprise of the evening for me, the smoke compliments the DB really well - balance is also good. Nice.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2013 bottle.  lightly hazed dull caramel body with a medium-sized off-white head.  requisite hearty and slightly-sweet smelling smoked pork belly nose complete with husky cracked and toasted grains, transparent yeast and indiscernable hop aromatics.  not having the ruachbier marzen side-by-side i cant make a clear and detailed comparison of the smoked oak vs. beechwood character, but the smoke is hearty and leathery, leaning a bit more towards sweet-glazed smoked meat with a lighter smoked wood / campfire character.  medium-full body, moderately chewy with a silken texture across the middle but showing some roughness on the edges.  a nice variant from one of the worlds great brewing treasures, but a proper comparison with the marzen and urbock would definitely help dial in the evaluation here.

huge smoke aroma and flavor.  the oak comes through in the nose, slighty sweet, light toasty bread, some raisin/dark fruit quality on the tongue.  smoky flavor makes you think it should be served warm, which makes the mouthfeel a bit dissonant when consumed.  legendary for a reason.

Very dissapointed in this one.  This by far is my least favorite Schlenkerla smoked beer..  NO head, NO lacing, and NO carbonation quickly bring sadness to me.  This is quickly exemplified by the poor toasted charcoal bitter flavor of the smoked bock beer.  This beer has very distinct alcohol punch, that when combined with the sharpness of the smokiness, creates an overall negative flavor and an even worse lasting palate.

Pint bottle. Snifter. Poured out much lighter in colour than I remembered, now being in a well lit apartment. Nearly clear rust orange colour with a minimal, scummy looking white head. Whatever, I bet this has been sitting on the shelf for some time. An intense smolder overwhelms the aroma, with some red pitted fruits mostly hidden in the background. A bit of licorice, perhaps even a bit of cherry cough syrup impressions come through, as well. The flavour is everything I expected from the nose. Thin bodied and not as severely smokey as the original rauch. Slick in mouthfeel, almost oily and gently carbonated. Earthy notes as well as smoked oak wood, cough drops and soy sauce impressions in the finish. Odd and not pleasant. I do love me some smoked beers, but this one just isnt doing it for me. Based on the appearance of the pour, my guess is this bottle is severely past date. Will definitely re-rate when given the opportunity to taste it fresh on draught.

500ml bottle from Bierkompass
BBE(?) 06/2011 - Pours dark brown with a medium white head. Aroma has notes of wood, smoke, ash, bacon and malts. Taste is quite sweet with notes of malts, bacon, smoke, oak and vanilla. Smooth, slightly sweet and warming finish. Great, well balanced smoked bock.

Lasiin kaatamallani oluella on valkea vaahto ja olut on kuparin värinen. Sen tuoskussa on mallasta, savua ja pekonia. Maku on makea, savuinen ja pekoninen. Nestemäistä savupekoniahan tämä. Suutuntuma on paksu ja täyteläinen.

Bit think for eight percent but has the awesome smoke that were all after big oomphs of smokey goodness

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 mL bottle poured into a dimpled Eichhof mug. Tips the scales at no darker than bronze, with a solid khaki head. Luscious smokey aroma, recalling smoldering bonfires and smoked cheese especially. Not quite as meaty as the other Schlenkerla offerings. Flavor is smooth and salty, plenty of ham/bacon notes, wood, black coffee, fire. An excellent smoked beer, full and nourishing on the palate.

Bottle. Amber body with an off-white head, slowly diminishing. Smoky aroma with notes of bread, oak wood, caramel and herbs. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture and lively carbonation. The smoke taste in this beer is not as meaty, bacon-like as their marzen nor was the beer as complex. Too, the smoke and oak taste clashed a little with the doppelbock sweet caramel characteristics, perhaps because theres a little too much sweetness. Still, an interesting smoke beer with lots of flavor.

Pours a dark off-amber color. Thin light tan head. Aroma is mild and smoky. Flavor is malty, some vanilla, oak and smokiness with some hints of fruit. Overall very good and worth a try. I personally prefer the Urbock.

16.9 ounce (500 ml) bottle.  Served in a mug, the beer pours a somewhat hazy dark golden/amber color with about a half inch off-white head.  The head sticks around for a little while, but there isnt much lacing at all.  Aroma is very smoky, the brew smells mostly like smoked meat, along with a bit of bready malt.  I just love the smoky, meaty aroma of this brew!  The beer tastes like smoked meat, bready malt and a little bit of caramel.  Theres also a nice lingering smoky finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit coating and has moderate carbonation.  I think its a pretty good overall brew.  For just $4.99 a bottle, Id definitely buy this again.  Its certainly one of the better (if not the best) smoked beers Ive had.

courtesy of Per - hazy red-amber beer with a poor head retention; solid aroma of smoked bacon; some light woody tones in the background; full-bodied and pretty heavy; a late tart bitter smokiness; the finish is slightly soapy with long smoky malty and late woody notes

500ml bottle.

Pours a slightly hazy deep amber with a thick off-white head that slowly recedes to a bubbly collar.

As a smoked beer fan, the aroma is heavenly.  Just a big smoky campfire in a glass.  Summer sausage, sweet caramel malts and a hint of earthy herbal malts.

The taste is more of the same with some bitter hops up front and a smoky presence thats a little spicier than the aroma.  The finish comes back to where the aroma started with a mixture of sweet caramel malts and heavily smoked oak and smoked meats.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied with strong carbonation and a bit beefier than some of the other beers Ive had from Schlenkerla.

I love smoked beers and Schlenkerla does them better than anyone on the planet.  This particular beer is one of the top smoked beers Ive ever had.  Its bigger and more complex than most and has the absolutely unmistakable Schlenkerla character.  Everyone should try this beer, but smoked beer lovers HAVE to get their hands on this one.
Bottle.  Woodsy smoky aroma with a hint of sweetness and malt. Amber with a small tan head. Wood smoke, bacon, earth, slight dark fruit flavor. Very light, pleasant bitter finish. Wow, Baby!

Pours a red copper color with a white medium sized head. Aroma of smoke (not as much smoked sausage as in the normal Schlenkerla, but more wood and tar) and malty toffee/caramel notes. Flavour is smoky with notes of caramel and dried fruits. Light bitter finish. Mediumbodied with average carbonation. Great.

Bottle 0.5l. A clear red amber colour with an average high, good lacing, off-white head. An aroma of malt, caramel, wood smoke and alcohol. The taste is medium sweet and medium bitter. A medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation and a long finish. A really nice rauchbier.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2016 Bottle. Amber, short to average and fully diminishing head.  Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, smokiness and some bacon, faint oaky vanilla. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, some smokiness and bacon, faint vanilla and alcohol. Finish is average to long, malty and sweetish, some smokiness and alcohol, faint bacon and vanilla. Nice smoky one from Bamberg  bit too sweet and too much alcohol in the finish.

Clean, bright amber with a ceamy tan head.  Aroma is a light, distant smokiness with slight cold-weather forest aroma in there too (from the oak?)  Flavor reveals a more refined, infused smoke flavor than the Urbock.  Crisp maltiness, light caramel, touch of super-clean bitterness, and a long and light smoke linger.  Very good.

Fine oak smoke aroma, with caramel, vanilla & a spiciness I suspect the hops. Beautiful red brown with a minimal head. Lighter in the mouth than expected, clean through. Smokes more balanced in the flavor, though a little blandly. Crisp finish
(500ml bottle) cloudy gold with a film of creamy head. Nose of mesquite, smoke. Taste of sweet, smoky, bacon fat, a bit of raisin and toastiness. Delicious. Not over powering, just awesome.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2016 First rating50 cl bottle from Systembolaget, BB April 2011. Sampled on September 4, 2011.Clear copper color, tan head. Smoke, peat, sweet, malty, lactic, wood scent. Smoke, alcohol, malt, peat, wood taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.Oh baby! Too bad we dont get this one more often, I need to buy more of it next time. Like it!9/4/9/4/18=4.4RerateDraught at Haket, Göteborg, on February 5, 2016.Clear copper to brown color, dense teal to tan head. Intense, smoked, campfire scent. Smoked, sweet taste. Smoked, slight metallic, then after a while cream, then a lot of smoke aftertaste. Fizzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.9/5/8/2/16=4.0

500ml bottle from WLV liquors.  Pours a light orange brown with some red in it and a creamy off white head.  Lots of smoke off that nose.  Wood, ash, earthy smoke, some meatiness, really appetizing.  Sweet malts that are bready and earthy with that wood and smokey flavor coming through.  Bitter in the finish with residual sweetness.  Really tasty.

50cl bottle, courtesy of and shared with Gnoff. 
Orangée, blanche.
Arôme de malt fumé, allant sur la bacon, sucré avec toujours ce côté fumé qui reste très agréable avec en retrait ce fini boisé de chêne. Le tout reste dans la lignée, copeaux de bois tel que saventurer dans un fumoir à viande des Ardennes.
Bière typique dans la lignée de Aecht, fumé à souhait, pointe de chêne, sucrée, malt avec en retrait le profile de houblon Hallertau rappelant que on a ici une bonne bière allemande pour une amertume légère rajoutant ce côté plaisant épicé du houblon.

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a clear amber color with a smooth off white head.  The nose is smoky, but doesnt have as much "meat" to it as the Urbock or Marzen.  The flavor has nice notes of barbecue, liquid smoke, a little malty sweetness, some bread, and a bit of drying alcohol on the back end.  Pretty well balanced overall and a nice change of pace from the Beech smoked brews.  You can definitely tell a difference.

I find this a perfect pairing for smoked pulled pork BBQ. Pours a dark amber hazy color with a thin head. The aroma hits you immediately with a strong smokey oak smell reminiscent of single malt scotch. Strong malted start with a very smooth finish.

Bottled.  A deep reddy brown coloured beer with an off-white puddle of head.  A superb smoky aroma with vanila oaky notes.  Same in the mouth.  Woody and smoky.  Bacon like.  Full bodied.  Alcohol well hidden.  A long smoky finish.  Very tasty.  Intense yet seems to be more friendly than the lower strength Schlenkerla beers.

Poured from a bottle into a Aecht Schlenkerla glass. Pours a nice amber color, lots of head, no lacing at all however. Smells of smoke and bbq. Smoke upfront on the taste, with a litle bit of sweetness in the finish. No alcohol on the palate, very easy drinker for 8%. Quality smoked beer!
Bottle at GBBF 11. Smells amazing! Tastes rich smoked genuis. Thin on the finish, but there is more than enough flavour before then.

Rich amber appearance, thin to light body. Off white head quickly diminishes with virtually no lace. Aromas of sweet wood smoke, toasted malts, slight honey. Overall very smooth brew with tastes of sweet and smoky caramel/honey sweetness. The finish is sweet, smooth, and smoky, with a tiny hint of alcohol heat.

Bottle in Yokohama, brought over from London.
I get a fair bit of oak and alcohol in the aroma.
Pours a clear light hazel colour. off white cream head fades fast.
Taste wise, I get a slightly cloying sweetness, medium bitterness,  high alcohols and oak are certainly evident. The smoked malt taste quite peaty alos in its strength, bordering on harshness. Very sweet (it Is a dopplebock, after all).  Sappy sweet  - tannins? Bitter finish with smoky oaky malt sweetness. Smoky oaky - I like that.
Soft carbonation, full body, thinnish syrupy mouthfeel.
That oak just seems like oak mixed with sap/syrup and sugar. Weird. I suppose that is what they went for, being a doppelbock (you may tell its not my fav style). Would like this one drier on the tongue, personally.
Not enjoying it as much as Id hoped. I guess beech smoked beers are more my thing. I thought I would go for this one.  Im not sure if the oak is overdone. I think the beer is a tad sweet, even for a doppelbock. Needs a fuller body to back up the sweetness or bump her up to 45IBU.
Improves as shewarms but the oak flavour increases also.

Bottle.  Pours a mostly clear golden amber with a moderate tan head that was gone after the second sip and left virtually no lace.  Very pleasant aroma that is filled with smoked meat along with a lesser amount of wood smoke and malt.  The flavor is similar and delicious with an ample amount of smoked meat and a bit less of wood smoke.  Malty as well.  Surprisingly smooth on the palate.  Really enjoyed this one.

Appearance:  bright orange, short off-white head, minimal lacing.  Aroma: sweet wood smoke, toasted malts, a whiff of vanilla and citrus (!?).   Taste: smooth, sweet and smoky, with evidence of toasty brown bread, some light brown sugar, with hints of cherry and (again) a hint of citrus.   Finish: mellow, lingering smokiness, with a bit of sweetness and restrained bitterness from the Hallertau hops.   Notes: The smoky character of this beer is much more restrained and delicate than in their other variants, but it definitely works.  The overall character of the beer is also lighter than what youd expect in a normal doppelbock as well.  It was really good.  Would probably be the perfect beer for barbecue, but I had it (wasted it) on pizza.

500 ml bottle.
Pours a beautiful dark brown colour with a small, thick, slightly off-white head on the edges. Aroma of lovely smoked wood, birch leaves, oak and quite heavy malts. Flavour of heavy smoked malts, oak, birch leaves and nuts. 8% abv is well hidden, no hint of alcohol what-so-ever. Full bodied, maybe a tad too thin mouthfeel with a long, smoked malty finish. I must say that this is one heavy beer and has everything that a smoked beer should have. Awesome.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful crystal clear reddish amber body under a one finger fizzy off-white head that faded to a thin covering.  The nose is as beautiful as ever for a Schlenkerla beer.  Sweet and smoky with a very clean aroma.  It smells pretty similar as far as the intensity of the smoke goes, but the quality is a bit more delicate.  The flavor is sweet up front, fading to a delicate yet intense smokiness.  I think I actually prefer the regular version, this one is a little softer and less in your face and not quite as bacon-y.  Medium to full bodied with a little bit of clingy sweetness on the finish.  Nice soft fizzy carbonation.  Still a pretty great Smoked, but Ill take the regular Marzen.

Bottle. Pours clear, golden amber with light off white head. Aromas of smoked ham, caramel, honey, roast and wood. Grainy, smoky malts, touch of hop flavour. Finish is semi sweet, lingering maltyness and smoked wood. Very nice.

50cl bottle. Pours clear, ruby-amber coloured, small to mid-sized lacy off-white head; sweet smoky ashy nose, mingled with aromas of caramel, grilled salmon and burnt furniture; solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium to full bodied, soft; aromatic hops show up in the caramelly-smoky and bitter finish.
On tap at the Rake, 7th Feb 2011. Rich amber appearance. Extremely strong  smoked meat flavour and nose. Similar to their Urbock.

Bottle at the Rake, RBESG 2011. Deep, dark, brown-orange color. Aroma of fruity caramel, bock-like rich malts, smoke. Sweet caramel flavor, oak, smoke. Mild, sweet, and rich. Very smooth, full mouth. Wonderful.

bottle thanks to bhensonb.  poured a goldish color with a white head.  aroma was lots of smoke and peat.  flavor was smoke, peat, caramel, slight spice, and some slight orange.  body was medium with nearly 0 carbonation.

Pint bottle.  Its hard to not rate a beer highly when it lives up to what it says it is.  As stated, deep amber color with a thin white head, but the smokiness is there from the first sniff, and the taste does not disappoint.  This was my first "smoke beer" and Im glad to say the smokiness is not overpowering yet very much evident, or I might have been put off by the style.  Very, very nice.

This was easily my favorite of any aecht beer Ive had. A nice not-too heavy smoke aroma, great red color.  This was really quite smooth with a great smoke flavor.  The only downside at all to this beer is that at 7 a bottle, its a bit pricy. but its really really good.

Bottle, labelled best before June 2011, sent my way from Nightfall to celebrate my son Charlie´s first birthday. Thanks Alex! Pours dark amber, clear, with a dense thumb-high, light brown head. Aroma of smoke, burnt wood, light tar, with creamy caramel in the background. Really great aroma, much more balanced  than in the Schlenkerla Rauchbier.
Taste is a bit of a letdown after smelling the beer. Still, it tastes good, burnt wood, sweet caramel, but with a light disturbing buttery note. Low to medium carbonation that works well with this beer, medium body. Definitely one of the better smoke beers I´ve had.

Hazy gold color with a large head (odd color for a doppelbock).  Smokey nose, full of resin.  A bit piney.  Rich smoke flavor.  Can definitely taste the difference between their Bamburg smoked and this oak smoked.  Like sticking your head inside a newly crafted oak end table.  Dry malt, light hoppiness.

500 ml bottle. Dark brown and crystal clear. Rich malty nose with a distinct roasted meaty smoke aroma. Sausages! Sweet malty body with a velvety texture. Rounded malty profile. Perfectly balanced with hops. The big brother of their märzen. An excellent brew.

pours lighter than I expected, but its a nice amber with a big head, though that may be a function of the bottle neck. The smell is smoke, and a ton of it, with some meat. The smoke is by far the dominating and overpowering flavor, but I do get some pork and there is a bit of sweet malt, too. Its like liquid bacon. Goes down quite easily, and there is no hint of the 8% ABV.

This is unlike any doppelbock Ive had. So if you think youll be getting something like Celebrator or Salvator, youre not. It is firmly a Rauchbier.

Overall, its pretty tasty, but the smoke really is a lot to handle. Be ready!

Pours red with a big foamy white head. Amazing red colour. Nose is smoked, woody and then bit of caramel malt underneath. Taste is beautiful smokey ham/wood with malty sweetness. Body is light, medium bodied and subtle.
Bias against smoky beers (quite strong here) clouds my judgment.  Nice presentation and aroma, unsavory for me.

Bottle procured at Half Time Poughkipsie.  Yup the 8% helped my aching self after the Zipline at Hunter Mountain.  Rich and sweet smokiness abounds in all aspects of this brew.  While my two compatriots appreciated the "meaty smokiness"  it was too large a critter for their NASCAR palates.  Nice to see some variation from this solid brewery.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 500ml bottle from Secret Santa. Thanks. Pours a translucent copper color with small off-white head that soon recedes to a fine film. The aroma is robust with rich smoke notes that conjure-up the mental image of a sausage smokehouse. The flavor compares favorably to the nose, rich tasty smoke at the forefront meets dopplebock in the middle with nice tangy bitter hops following up on the back end. The palate is full and satisfying with soft carbonation. The finish is long and dry with lingering smoke and hops. Overall: I love this stuff, I really must visit the Bamberg brewery someday and pay homage to the smoke beer gods. x

0.5l bottle @ Amundsen Bryggeri & Spiseri, Oslo. Pours a clear light brown/ruby-brown body with a small sidesticking bubbly head. Aroma is light maltish sweet with hints of caramel, some dark fruits and a quite clear note of smoke. Also some notes of forest and cortex in this doppelbock. Light oily to near sticky mouthfeeling, average to soft carbonation and medium bodied. Tastes also light sweet with good notes of smoke. Also some hints of alcohol and roses. Ends quite smoky with a ashy aftertaste.

Bottle shared by fred82, thanks! 
Man i love the beers from this brewery. Its like liquid bread! Deep amber pour, with an intoxicating aroma of sweet bready malts. Touches of sugar and smoke mingle amongst the great malts. A real treat! Sweet malty finish with a great bacon, sausage kick. Incredible beer!

Pours a cloudy orange with medium white head.  The smoky aroma is hitting me before I even get my nose to the glass.  The nose is all about NC BBQ.  Beautiful smoky aroma but not heavy or overbearing.  A little like a campfire in your mouth, but in a good way.  Can definitely tell the difference between the Oak and the Beech.  I am sure these beers are not for all but I really like.

[3807-20110708] 1pt0.9floz bottle. Smoky fresh sneaker leather aroma. Slightly hazy, orange brown body with a quick foamy off-white head. More smoky band-aid and slightly bitter flavour has something like a vanilla finish. Medium body. Not a fan. (6/3/4/2/11) 2.5
(w/ blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc, JoeMcPhee)

Bottle (500ml) shared with HogTownHarry, JoeMcPhee, jerc & mabel -- c/o JoeMcPhee. Pours a very bubbly golden-orange with a spare diminishing fizzy off-white head. Aroma: Whoa, thats a lot of smoke, along with some malt in the background, dark fruit and wood. Flavours nice and smoky along with toasted caramel malt, wood and dark fruit. Average to medium bodied. Very enjoyable and easy to drink.

2011-07-08. Golden body with a modest beige head. 3+  Very smokey aroma, malt is present in a secondary capacity. 7+ Flavour of malt with toasty accents, the smoke is more restrained and sophisticated than expected, building slowly as you go. Smooth average bodied palate. 3+ Light smoke lingers into the aftertaste. My favorite Schlenkerla by a large margin (Damning with faint praise?), it actually allows the underlying beer to come through a bit more than the others. Has some lovely highlights, but the smoke is still too much for me to drink this on my own. Bottle courtesy of JoeMcPhee

4 oz sample. Clear amber, nice big beige head. Aroma of smoke, oak, iodine, smoke, reminded me of the few scotches Ive had but without the insane alcohol and medicinal quality. Taste of burnt bacon, wood, caramel.
dark mahogany body, white head. Aroma of tar and some liquorice. Nice aroma, but not complex in any way. Flavour has malt, sweetness, some herbal hops and liqourice. Really nicely balanced.

Pour is a dark brown with a small white head.  Aroma is very smoky and meaty.  Flavor is the same super smoky and a total bacon bomb.  KInda gets old after a few ounces.  While I appreciate the time and effort to make a beer like this I can only have so much before getting a headache.  Smoked and meaty out the wazoo.

25/06/2011 1pt 0.9 Fl. Oz. bottle (so 50cl) @ Gentse Biervereniging: Proeverij nieuwe bieren 2011(just a little extra) - (2011-273) Thanks to Klaas for the bottle! 
Pretty clear amber to copper red beer, small unstable light beige head, non adhesive. Aroma: smoke upfront, no surprise. Also a bit sour, even fishy (?), bbq meat. MF: little to no carbon, medium body. Taste: sour notes, sweet malts, only then theres some smoke arriving. Aftertaste: bitter with more sour touches.

500 ml bottle. From bierzwerg.de.
Clear dark copper colour with small light tan head.
Balanced aroma of heavy smoke, Bocky malt and mild sweetness. 
Some sweetness, smoke and strong Bocky malt in flavour. 
Excellent.

50cl bottle, BBE 06/2011
A very pleasant aroma  smoky and fresh at the same time. Taste has some heavy smoke and strong salty liquorice. Also some hints of wood. Mouthfeel is rather dry.
Bottle 0,5ltr: Clear brown coloured brew, with an great smoked ham-like smell. The smokey taste is not so intense as the lower in alcohol beers of this legendary brewery.

500mL bottle purchased at Davis Beer Shoppe.  Prominent smoked malts, as expected in the nose.  Nice, pleasant char.  Some slight buttery sweetness is also there, but barely.  Transparent amber body with a smallish off-white head.  Pretty light in color, and a bit of a disappointing head.  Starts with a sweet, sticky start, before the roasted malts come through, giving this a big-time bacon and ham flavor.  Velvety body, and easy-drinking.  This reminds me of the smell of Easter at my grandmothers house as a kid with Canadian Bacon omelettes....

Lovely amber color and an aroma filled with sweet oak smoke. Luscious mouth feel with tiny bubbles and lots of malty sweetness. The smokiness is very much there all the way through to the not so very bitter end. Sure this beer isnt extremely complex, its all oak smoke and malty sweetness, but sometimes thats all you need.

Aroma is quite heavy on the smoke, notes of smoked sausage and ham, toast and rye bread.  Pours a clear amber, white head dissipates quickly to a thin ring of foam.  Taste starts with slightly sweet bready malts and strong smoke, toasty, oak, slightly spicy.  Minimal bitterness, moderate caramel flavors, alcohol is very well hidden.  Medium-full body with low-med carbonation.  Very interesting brew, quite strong smoke character but still drinkable.

pours orange-amber with a lasting white head and no lacing.  smoky aroma with hints of fruit.  taste is smoky but more subtly so than other rauchbiers Ive had.  fruit and hop notes are present and balance the smoke nicely.  finish is smoky and bitter but the fruitiness is hanging on.  This is a very well balanced and enjoyable beer, perfect for drinking with BBQ.

Pours a clear amber with a soapy lace - the oak lends a much more robust and earthy smokiness than is present in other schlenkerla beers, as well as a much stronger woodiness than the more understated beech - still a lovely nose reminiscent of a campfire - medium bodied - fairly sweet, with a smooth mouthfeel - the smoke is a bit more rough and even a little acidic in comparison to the beechwood in their other beers - the increased hoppiness adds to the moderate acidity - the other elements are a little one-dimensional, but hey, the smoke is why you drink this beer, right - in brief, it smells awesome, but the oak smoke lacks the smoothness and depth that the beech imparts to their other beers - still love it, though.

Bottle, thanks goes to Quack-Duck. Dark amber color with medium beige head. Aroma of bacon, maybe some wood. Taste is again strongly bacon, than malt, caramel and oak. Finish is strongly alcoholic, cognac like but with strong smoke end. Excellent.

Bottle. Clear amber colour with an off-white head. Loveley combination of smoke and malt. Sweet, but not over the top. A hint of balancing bitterness in the end. Dangerously drinkable with no hint of alcohol.

500 ml bottle thanks to yeahnatenelson. Pours a mostly clear orange/copper color with a medium white head that dies out. The aroma is sweet smoky malts, some caramel and sugars. The flavor is dominated by sweet sugary smoked treats, caramel, oak, rich candied fruit, some dryness. Very smooth and well made. Lots of oak here. A liter of this on draft would be awesome.

Fabulous ruby red color, with fine, flat head. Delicious aroma of bacon and smoke, a little more reserved than most of the other Schlenkerla beers. Starts with a pleasant smoky flavor, paired with bacon. The beer has a voluminous malt body, the alcohol is really not noticeable at any point. The aftertaste is very smoky, with less bacon aroma, again very weighty malty. In the further course the beer keeps his voluminous malt body. The bacon aroma goes back a little, the smoke flavor remains a strong presence until finish!

Simply a lovely beer, needed a longer lasting head and slightly more vibrant body to be a perfect-drinking dopple. Bottle from Quack-Duck, and a fantastic one at that. Deep brown with just enough amber to keep it translucent. Smells like caramel and molasses, and slightly like earthy fruits (raisin, plum). Wonderful smoky smell. Smoked flavor is medium-to-strong, iron and molasses sweetness (moderate-to-high sweetness) with a tinge of both sourness and of bitterness.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
In short: An abundance of smoked over clean, crisp sugary sweet malts.  Great beer even a tad too sweet/sugary
How: Bottle 500ml.  Consumed moderately fresh approximately 2 months after purchase
The look: Clear bright golden body topped by a medium off-white head with good retention
In long: Nose as smoky as you would expect from a Schlenkerla.  But far from the greasy smoky breakfast for their Urbock or the campfire & burning straws of their Marzen, the Schlenkerla Doppelbock proposes a cleaner smoke character with a distinctive smoked oak character.  Taste has a surprising amount of crystal-malt-like crisp sugary cereals.  Feels like caramel-color hard candies at times, borderline refined white sugar.  A bit too sweet imho to match the excellence and drinkability of the Marzen or even the Urbock.  Very clean and crisp.  No alcohol presence whatsoever.  I love a beers that have a nice smoky character.  I also like beers that dont.  Bottom line: I love beer.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2017 2016-12-25, bb 04-2011, 6 years old, 8-4-8-4-16=40Positive: smoke presence, malt depth, moderate sweetness.Negative: very low carbonation, a bit weak in the final.2014-01-16, draught at Ølbaren, Copenhagen, 8-4-7-3-15=37Amber color, clean, with good head. Strong smoke aroma, maybe too sweet; Japanese sauce. Full bodied, semi-sweet, smoked but cloying; the final is industrialized.2013-02-06, draught at Ølbaren, Copenhagen, 8-5-7-4-16=40The aroma is sweet and smokey. The flavor is smooth, round, very sweet, with a lot of smoke and just a touch of firewood.Very good, but I still find this one too sweet and less harmonious to compete with the Märzen and Urbock.2012-12-19, bottle, bb 04/2011, about 2 years old, 9-5-9-4-18=45Hazy dark amber color, with small head. The malt and smoke aroma is sweet and mature. Sweet mouthfeel, full bodied, with good malts, caramel, light fudge; the oak smoke is more pungent that the usual one, and it blends better with the thicker body; quite fat. At this age, its delicious.2011-03-27, bottle, courtesy of Papsø, 8-5-8-4-15=40Beautiful amber color; medium sized creamy head. Wonderful smoke and malt aroma. Good body strength; strong malt flavor; I find the sweetness to be excessively cloying; correct bitterness level, but contrasting the smoke. Very good, but excessive compared to Märzen and Urbock.2011-01-14, draught at Ølbaren, Copenhagen, 9-5-8-4-17=43Dark mahogany color with ruby shades; creamy head. The aroma is wonderful, deep; smoked sausages, sweet, with light presence of ashes. The body is not very strong, medium, but its quite round; good caramel flavor, sausage smoke, moderate sweetness, and a very light sour touch that increases the drinkability; but it misses the bite of the Märzen and Urbock also on draught. It has a correct bitterness, with a pleasant alcohol warmth, but too lean on the malts in the final.Excellent, Im having a second glass2010-12-03, bottle, 7-5-8-4-16=40Amber color with copper reflex; the medium-sized head is short lived. The fresh smoke aroma is very nice; but a bit later loses intensity. Full bodied, with a very good malt and caramel flavor; elegant smoke character, well blended; it has a good degree of sweetness, that contributes to create a biscuity touch. Very interesting, but less character than the Urbock and Märzen; anyway, a good number of bottles will find the way to my cellar.

Sweet malt and lightly robust smoky aroma. Clear orange color with a small tan head. Sweet beginning quickly getting a smoky finish with a noticeable medicine finish. This is one that I will have to age.

(Bottle) Amber colour, slightly hazy, with brief off-white head. Malty, smoky nose with dried apricots, Seville orange, orange peel, honey and oak smoke. Malty, smoky, slightly fruity taste with notes of orange, dried apricots, honey and smoked ham. Spicy finish with a gentle bitterness and just a touch of sweetness. More than medium body. Complex beer with lots more going on than just massive amounts of bacon. Smoke is more subtle than in the other Schlenkerla beers (well, theyre lovely as well), making this one excellently balanced. Lovely beer.

Poured clear dark copper color with an average light brown frothy head that  lasted with very good lacing. Moderate woody smoke malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet smoke flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish.  Good stuff

Weicher Rauchantrunk, die starken Raucharomen wirken dadurch so harmlos, dass das Bier extrem süffig ist. Unüblich ist zudem, dass zusätzlich dunkle Mlaznoten abseits des Rauchs präsent sind. Würzig-süßlich, wenig getreidig. Stimmiger Rauchbock, der erstaunlich weich daherkommt. Die Süffigkeit ist extrem! 11/11/14/12//12

Golden copper color with an off white head.  Nose is smoked meat with citrus fruit.  The flavor is even more smoked meat to start.  Then the hops kick in and add very interesting aspects.  They are citrus, sulfur, pine, and mildly bitter.  Then the smoke takes over again.  In general this is a sweet beer.  Oak is never tasted.

Remarkably smooth easy-drinking smoked.  The smoke is there but its understated under a delicious malt mix.  Its on my lips well after I have completed it.  It was great with BBQ. Greyish golden coloured body, small head.  Mild smoke aromas.  A tad above average mouthfeel.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a small amount of head.  Smokey malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle.  I am not a big smoked fan, but I gotta say, I enjoyed this one a lot more than the other Schlenkerla offerings, as the smoke is definitely not as -in-your-face powerful.  It is still very smokey, for modern American craft beer standards.  Plenty of bacon, but also plenty of sweet sticky malt.  Sweet, but not overly so.  If you are indeed a fanatic of smoked beers, I think you will quite enjoy this one.

Pours a minimal head that dissolves to nothing in under ten seconds.  Lacing is likewise minimal but definite though quick.  Body is a beautiful, clear copper.
Aroma is smoked bacon / ham.  Excellent!  Dont know how anybody could smell anything under this.  Wait, a little floral.
Taste is appropriately medium salty.
Palate is livevly on the lips and middle of the tongue with a definite, bitter finish.
There is nothing cloying or even sweet about this smoked dopplebock.  Love it.

500ml bottle.  Glad to finally score this one.  Big, ruthless, burnt bacon tinged smokalicious aroma.  Wow.  Complex.  Somehow keeps the drinkability of the Marzen while adding some depth.  The oaky tones really complement the smokiness.  Flat out phenomenal for the style, an awesome, classy addition to the Schlenkerla family.  Smooth creamy malt tones. Pungent, fruity, lager yeast tones which resonate in the aftertaste.

Das Flaschenetikett ist nicht wie bei den anderen Schlenkerla-Bieren in einem gelblichen Pergamentton, sondern ist in eichengrün gehalten. 
Im Duft sehr fein rauchmalzig und weniger robust als die buchenholzgeräucherten Biere. Antrunk schinkig-rauchig, eher sanft, gleichwohl sanft auf der Zunge. Mitte malzig und im Verein mit der wohlbemesenen Rauchigkeit sehr dicht und etwas schokoladig. Keine alkoholischenSpuren. Dunkelmalziger und schinkenrauchiger Abgang. 
Ein excellentes Rauchbier!

Bottle at the Battersea BF 11 and Keg at the Rake (of was it the C&K?) in recent months. Everything that youd expect from this brewery but for me a tad rich and cloying. I was in Bamberg last November and had hoped to try this then. Urbock was sublimely sessionable from the wood at Schlenkerla but the regulars there  warned us that this beer is considered far too sweet for  local tastes and I can see why now. Nevertheless a world class sipper..

A delicious smoked beer. Aroma was great. Smoky bacon and beef jerky. Pour was a nice medium gold with a few rising bubbles and a thin off white film for a head. Taste was nice and smoky. The sweetness of the doppelbock seems a little off when paired with the heavy smoke flavor. Seems kind of muddled and leaves a slightly astringent flavor in the mouth after the swallow. Medium light carbonation. Love this brewery as they make the best smoked beers out there!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Draft @ Ølbaren, Copenhagen. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty smokey caramel aroma. Fruity malty smokey flavor with oaky hints and hints of caramel. Has a fruity malty smokey caramel finish.

Sampled on 4/16/2011. This smoked beer pours a slightly cloudy amber brown color form a 50cl bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is smoky, meaty, bready and sweet. A medium bodied Smoked beer. The malts are caramel, bready and sweet. The hops are herbal and earthy. Decent carbonation. Lots of meaty smokiness throughout, not overpowering by very prevalent. You can still taste the sweet malts but the smokiness help balance them. These guys really do know how to make smoked beers. Perhaps a touch of wood in the finish as well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Bottled sample. Pale copper in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of peppery woodsmoke and slightly sweet pale malts. In terms of taste, the smoke is definitely different than other Schlenkerla products; a bit more spicy and smooth, with a more wooden (as opposed to smoked meat) character. The general maltiness plays a stronger role here too. Medium bodied with no alcohol heat.
Bottle. Deep amber colour with an off-white head. aroma is smoked, caramel, malt, alcohol. Flavour is sweet, smoked, malt, caramel, hop, alcohol. Nice beer.
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is smoked meat. Flavor is smoke with some sweet malts trying to get through. Love these smoked beers.

Bottle picked up in Chicago and served in a Mikasa pilsner glass.

THe pour brings a copper-hued brew with a very strange white head. It started out quite frothy with large bubbles, and then comes a reverse head. The two eventually meet and form a nice, dense white head with good retention. A bit of lacing on the glass and a thin collar throughout. This was the highlight of the beer for me. The nose is overwhelmingly smokey with a bit of a meat character and not much playing behind it.

The taste is similar in terms of what the smoke does. Here I can get a bit of the smoked oak, though I cant say it really adds a positive dimension. The underlying doppelbock is completely gone and I dont get anything that would indicate this was the base. The taste brings a bit too much tannin and is overwhelmingly smokey. I suppose its not that the level of smoke is bad, its just that theres really nothing else there. A bit of an astringent, bitter finish. Really not a fan of this though I could see how one could enjoy it. My least favorite Schlenkerla beer to date.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-19-2011

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 Delicious, it tastes the way a campfire smells. The flavor is different from other Schlenkerla rauchbiers, the smoke, while still strong and the dominant flavor, is more mellow. This is a great beer.

16.9 oz. Clear amber/orange with a medium beige head. Aroma of fresh campfire, smoked ham with a light bread scent in the background. The flavor is very smoky with some sweet bready malt and caramel way in the background, the alcohol is well hidden. Medium body with average carbonation and a smooth, long, smoky finish. Overall on hell of a smoked beer, these Germans know how to make a rauchbier.
500ml bottle, aroma of smoke, leather, and a slight hickory from the doppelbock. The sweetness is struggling to get past the smoke. Delicious smoky goodness, would go well with breakfast.

At first sniff, it was like I was about to drink a glass of bacon. Not faux-Bacos as many low-end rauschbiers often are... but honest to god bacon.

Once you get through the scent, there is a wonderfully salty and sweet beer underneath, that makes you want to keep drinking.

I had this along side hot pretzles. So good.
Pours deep amber with notes of smoked wood and bacon fat.  The smoked flavor and the malts give a true bacon fat style flow to the flavors.  A nice lingering finish.

Pours a nice copper honey color with a full white head.  Mmmmm...bacon!  Really, this smells of bacon and lots of it, a strong outdoorsy smokey woodsy aroma like oak on a campfire, a bit of alcohol.  The fruits really add a unique complexity to this.  It tastes of bacon, smoke, oak, caramel, and again a bit of alcohol.  The bacon, smoke, and fruit remind of me of green beans with bacon added.  While odd, its very enjoyable!
Bottle. Amber pour with some tan head. Aroma is full of smoke and woody characteristics. Flavor is varied, malts toasted, smoked, and even some sweet. Nice

Courtesy of northernbrews. Golden/orange, minimal head, oily coats glass. Absolutely love this. Its pretty one dimensional. But I dig it. Tons of smoke, wood. Flavor has a nice munich malt character, melanoidin sweetness. Oily mouthfeel.

Courtesy of northernbrews
Bottle:  The aroma is meaty smoked cheese.  It pours a mostly transparent amber with a small off-white head that quickly fades to film outlined by a soapy ring.  The flavor starts with a quick dose of caramel and a touch of fruit.  The finish has light smoked cheese...nowhere near as strong as the aroma.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation .

Bottle courtesy of northernbrews. Pours hazy amber with a nice white head that fades to a thin ring. Aroma is a nice bacony smoke that overpowers. Nice medium body. Flavor is pleasantly smoky bacon. Leaves a lingering smoky finish.

500ml botle poured a clear amber with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of smoke, carmel and light fruittiness. Palate was medium bodied and smootrh. Flavors of smoke, carmel, light earthiness and a hint of fruittiness with a smooth lingering smokey carmel finish.

Bottle from Premier.  Pours a clear amber with a medium white head.  Nose is restrained for the brewery - iodiney smoke, caramel, restrained berries (no, really, Im getting them).  Flavor is smoke, really amazing caramel malt that totally coats the tongue, alcohol.  Some iodiney smoke comes out in the finish with a bit more alcohol & wonderful sweet malt.  If the alcohol wasnt there this beer would be perfect.

Lightly hazy amber with a small white head, looks lively, very doppelbockesque... Smoky aroma with notes of lightly flowery/grassy hops and abit of sweetness...  Very malty flavor with not as big notes of smoke as with most of their other beers, oaky, that seems to muddle the smokiness a bit... Not as lively as expected, medium to medium full bodied with a caramel finish that is a little over the top.. Way too sweet..

Bottle.

A - Nice crisp bronze color with a medium sized, thickish, fluffy, foamy, white head. Decent retention leaving a thin foamy lace.

S - Really nice aroma with the obvious smoked meat aroma. The oak provides a nice level to the aroma. There is a nice caramel/sweet malt aroma that in other beers can be overpowered by the smoked aroma. A very subtle raisin like aroma as well.

T - Like the nose, there is a lot of smoked meat flavor, but not much of a bonfire smokiness. Oak flavor is definitely present, though not dominating. Caramel malt and a subtle dark fruit flavor as well as a very faint hoppy bitterness show up. Pretty complex.

M - Medium body with average carbonation. Quite smooth.

D - Like other smoked beers Ive had, this is a one and done for a while, but the complexity is quite nice.

Notes: Interesting, complex smoked beer. Smoked meat is the strongest, but this more than other similar beers provides more balance and complexity to the flavor. Has subtle/vague doppelbock hints as well as oak.

Color is a little off for a doppelbock although that could be due to the smoked malt.  Aroma is strongly smokey, can only tell that its a doppelbock based on the finish.  Overall, this is good, just wish the smokiness was a little more subdued.

Slightly hazy deep bronze colored body with a bright white head. The nose has lots of smoked meat and some caramel. There is also some hazelnut. Smoky wood and a little bit of hay. Notes of caramel. A highly carbonated body that is a little sharp on the tongue. This is a tasty one with plenty of residual sweetness.

(500ml bottle, courtesy of blutt59)  Pours a clear golden body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of smoke, sausage, raisins, sulfur, baked beans, and brown sugar.  Flavor of smoke, roasted grain, caramel, and oak.

Medium beige head. Beautiful deep red body. Deep salty charcoal smoke
aroma with grainy, resiny notes. Dry roasty smoky resiny taste with
salty charcoal and freshly sawn wood notes. Fullish body. Mild, soft
mouthfeel. Dry roasty charcoal smoke and licorice aftertaste with
salty wooden notes. Very harmonic and balanced, with a beautifully
pronounced and rounded smoke character. Excellent! Really love the
smoke character and drinkability. (0.5l bottle, Amundsen Bryggeri,
Oslo.)

Bottle. Pours a brilliant clear medium amber, thin white head. Big smoky nose, but not as complex as expected, lots of malt, spices and smoked sausages going on. Almost dry, medium bodied, fairly low bitterness, a bit low on CO2. Very smoky, malty taste, the slightly buttery Doppelbock notes come through quite nicely, and it finishes rather dry, with the smoke lingering on. Not bad, although I expected a bit more complexity. (2010-12-08)

Aroma smoke, camp fire, bacon, salt, blt. Pour deep golden orange white head good lace. Taste malty balanced by big smokey salty hit of farmers thick cut bacon, touch of earthiness and taste of dobblebock sweetness. MF medium body fine fizzy carb. Overall good balanced beer that tastes like bacon a lot which I enjoy however not something I could drink everyday.

Bottled500ml. -Trade with shrubber85 (thanks Roger!)
Beautiful red amber coloured, medium sized pale beige head, mild and pleasant smoked panceta nose. Sweet malty, smoked panceta and light hoppy with no trace of alcohol. Sweet and woody smokey finish. Of course, Schlenkerla didnt disappoint me this time either.

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Smoke and bacon aroma with light malt. Smoke and malt flavor with light caramel. Medium bodied. Light caramel and smoke lingers with malt and light mineral notes.

Pours clear amber color with small white head. Aroma is more campfire than smoked meat, but it still has that meaty smell. Smokey flavor with some sweet caramel. Alot different than their other beers. Medium body with minimal carbonation.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2012 Bottle @ Hessen Haus (and now multiple bottles at home including a bottle courtesy of doodler for my 28th birthday, grazie Scott!). Dark orangish brown appearance. Smoky, fatty fucking meaty aroma with tons of smoked ham. Rich, dark caramel malty, big smoked, glazed ham/meaty flavor thats somewhat spiced but super smooth. Some toffee, light maple syrup, a bit of chocolate, and lots of caramel. Meaty aftertaste. Super easy to drink and really no noticeable sign of the 8% abv. Pure goodness. I love you, sexy. Previous scores: 3/26/11: 4.3, 3/28/12: 4.5, 5/23/12: 4.6

The beer is a pretty clear gold with a white head, decent head and retention.

The aroma is awesome, just what youd expect. Tons of smoke and pork, just like it should be.

The taste is like the aroma, tons of smoke and pork, mixed with some light grass. It is wonderful and way to easy to drink.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011 Re-rating - less fruity on the taste this time, but major smoked beef thing going on. Overall, better than the last time.  

Previous rating 26/03/11 6+5+7+3+10= 3.1
500ml bottle. Beautiful cherry cola colour with gentle carbonation and a nice head. The nose is malty with smokey bacon and salami notes. The taste is full flavoured with gammon and fruits. The palate has a big structure, it is rich and complex throughout and has a long finish, though it doesnt clean. Overall, this is a great beer, especially with food. However, it is so rich that I would definitely not want a second.

They snuck this one in on me, saw it on the shelf and had no idea it existed before then! Pours a bright golden-amber color, clear, but no head, large bubbled carbonation is light. Aroma is just beautifully smoky, reminds of campfire and my grandmothers burned down house. Only hints at salami type meatiness. There is a light toffee behind it. Flavor is more on the toffee type melanoidin malts, maybe a little flabby, with the smoke coming up behind. Finish is light and undercarbonated with alot of lingering sweetness and smoke.

Bottle from ogivlados trade with shrubber85 (huge thanks!) Ooh, I was so looking forward to this one. Heller just owns. Anyway, this started off well with a superb red-amber colour topped with a white head. A sublime smoked ham, no, panceta nose, slightly buttery, ending in bubblegum... whoa. The taste was a bit of a letdown after that, an attack of sweet maltiness carrying with it that same lovely panceta smokeyness, but going nowhere. So yeah, the smokey notes are lovely as usual and it turned relatively balanced in the end, but I was expecting more... Obviously, its still an above average smoked, and Id definitely have it again. But after some other beers they make.

500ml bottle. Rating #238. Clear copper pour with a big bubbly white head that dissipated pretty quickly. Nice smoky aroma, almost like a nice smoked fish. Big smoke in the flavor as well, its about the only flavor I can pick out actually, but not bad. (1511)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
Bottled 500ml (from Utobeer, 3.50£, BB 08/2011)
Clear deep copper color, small white head. Smokey typical Schlenkerla-nose. Medium to full-bodied. Moderate carbonation. Smokey, sweetish malty flavor. Combination gives hints of licorice in the finish. Quite strong alcohol presence, but otherwise much "easier" beer than normal Maibock or Urbock.
Pours copper with white head.  Smells of smoke, some sweet malt.  Tastes of caramel, smoke, pepper, dark fruit, some underlying bitterness on the finish.  Full bodied.

Aroma of chipotle and caramel.  Appearance is red and clear with medium carbonation.  Tastes of bacon, pine, and smoke.  I do not like this at all.  If you like the taste of burning peat, this may be the beer for you.

Date: 3/6/2011   Source:Other   Smoky caramel aroma. Clear copper golden with small white head. Smoky bacon with bready biscuit malts. Sweet with touch of spicy hop notes. Medium to full body and mouth feel. Finish is sweet bready and smoky. I like it a lot.

Deep chestnut pour. Aroma is obviously smoky. Not a punch in the face smokiness, but rather subtle, still dominating. A bit of grassy hoppiness along with a clean caramel malt body. Taste is also dominated by the smoke, but it is not overly smokey. Its a good balance between the smoke, a good caramel and biscuity malt body and a clear yeast component that gives the characteristic bock sweetness. Very good.

Pours clear orange/gold with a huge off white head. The aroma is beautiful smoky campfire with hints of bacon, brown sugar and a tiny bit of toasted and caramel malt. The flavor is extremely complex and wonderfully balanced with intense smoked beechwood and oak, brown sugar and caramel flavors come out as it warms. Rich mouthfeel with below average carbonation adding to the depth of flavors. German noble hops are balanced flawlessly with the smoke to add even more complexity and softness to the finish. Just spectacular.

A Christmas Smoke.  0.5L bottle.  Pours light copper, light tan head. Aroma of smoked fish, campfire, and burned / charred oak.     Sticky malt sweetness.  Of course a smoked flavor all through the finish.  Sweet toasty caramel sugars and smoke.  Oaky tannins, wood bitterness.  Very soft body, leaves a lingering smoke character, like a tea-wurst, without the meat.

I dont know, I guess Im the wrong person to rate smoked beers. Its a vegetarian eating bacon in a way. I want to like them because I like smoke flavor, but generally theyre too much. This one softens as it warms and I grew to like it, but not too much.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2012 500ml bottle.

It pours a different color than most doppelbocks, it is a heller doppelbock It it a beaut though. t is a clear reddish orange with a foamy, but creamy white head that sticks for a nice while and recedes to some nice lacing.

It smells very smokey with campfire, smoked bacon, and smoked oak. There is a subtle kiss of noble hops hiding in the background.

The taste isnt as smoky as the smell but it is loaded with smoke overtones. This one legitimately has a slight taste of bacon with some syrup. The smokiness is in check, although it lingers with a bit of campfire in the finish. The malts are big and sweet, more so then some of the other Shlenkerla beers and it provides a nice balance to the smokiness.

The mouthfeel is thick and viscous, it makes this one a mouthful, but a pleasant one.

The helles is the only thing better from this great brewery.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-27-2010 04:58:41

500 ml bottle. Amber body with a fine, dense medium sized off-white head. Aroma is smoke, malt, ham, grilled mackerel and bonefire. Flavor has smooth and mild malt with much smoke, well integreted bitterness, some caramel and just a hint of alcohol. Very balanced. This is the best I have tasted from Schelenkerla so far.

Smoky as expected.  Truly a classic brewery.  As per the intended style of a doppelbock, this was a touch light.  Smoke did dominate overall, which was not a surprise, but it didnt leave room for much else.  There was the thick slippery mouthfeel of a DB and a nice sweet finsh blended amidst the smokiness.  Other than that, it was a smoked beer.  Period.  Dont get me wrong, I enjoyed it.  Truly a one-of-a-kind brewery.

Bottle from Birroteca La Tana del Luppolo, Bologna, Feb 2011 consumed March 8th 2011  There was a very impressive German section of beers within this great little shop. Pours a wonderful reddy brown colour, in fact more red than brown in a certain light. Quite lovely smokiness, not sure that I can get any hoppiness, I think the smoked bratwurst and oakiness are more noted. Soft in the mouth, sweetness, and lovely smoked sausage in mouth, wonderful smokiness, woody flavours, this is quite, quite marvelous.   A9 A5 T8 P4 Ov17  4.3

On tap at Svet Piva, Prague. Pours cloudy copper with a 2 " creamy tanned head.Aroma of heavy smoked bacon, summer barbeque gone wrong. Taste is smooth and smokey, well balanced and full bodied. A treat.
bottle, clear amber orange with strong smoke and orange peel aroma, flavor is great smokey fruit cocktail, bready malts, caramel, lasting finish

Bottle from Sams in Durham.  The other Aecht rauschbiers hit you like a punch in the face (that you didnt ask for, but you know you deserved), so its a nice surprise that this one is more of tasteful interaction where you have a safe word and have asked to be slapped a bit.  Pours bright amber, maybe with just a slight hint of haziness, or is that my imagination?  Smallish head.
