Nose presents smoke, sweet malts (dark and sweeter caramels, bread, wood, slight hint of bacon covered in maple syrup).  Great balance of sweet and smoky that is also found in the taste.  A hint of hops coming through the malt and smoke as well as a salty note.  Dry finish.  Wonderful.

500ml bottle from Winooski.
Appearance : Clear shiny copper colored with a small white creamy head.

Aroma : Nice meaty smoke with notes of white sugar and caramel. Woody notes.

Taste : Woody and meaty smoke. Some white sugars. Some hops and sugars on the finish with lots of smoke. Smoke less present on taste than aroma. Finish is a little bit bitter and quite dry.

Overall : Very nice beer. Nice nose and taste. More sweetness than the Marzen but still well balanced. Soft carbonation but with a nice fizz. on the palate. Very clean and elegant stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2011 Bottle 50cl from Quack-duck many thanks. A clear amber -brown beer with medium head. Nose is on malt, toasted malt and off course smoke. A creamy like beer, sweet, with a porter like body and an amazing smoke presence pure and wood like, good bitter chocolate like notes. Long aftertaste, caramel and malty sugar notes with smoke flavor going to aches at the finish. Yeast is not fruity which leads the body from the caramel-sweet side to a spicy-smoke finish, really a great brew, vanilla, tobacco and resin notes at the finish.  The beer has 8° but alcohol is well hidden, for the one who like smoked beer this is wonderful, and very drinkable, a dream, the masterpiece merge between oak aged porters and German smoked beers. So Quack-duck many thanks for this one, if you can get some more...

Bottle, thanks Yngwie! :-) Pours a deep nougat brown body with a small white head. Aroma is a beautiful, mild smokey caramel blend; not as insistent as the other version but oh so subtle and nice. Taste is a magnificent multi-layered blend of smoke, caramel, wood and meaty undertones, the smoked meat surfacing occasionally. Full-bodied and extremely smooth. Best rauch Ive had so far! :-)

Vom holz at the ausschank.  Served in a goblet.  Dark golden brown colour with a thick head.  The aroma has smoke, caramel....different smoke than the normales, lighter and drier, but just as strong.  Starts strong on the palate - muscular pale malts, caramelized notes and alcohol all to the fore, signifying a well-made and assertive doppelbock.  Then, it all gives way to an elegant, refined oak smoke finish, almost with white pepper notes from the alcohol, something Im more accustomed to finding in a tripel.  The full package is appealing - its a definitive statement not only of Schlenkerlas awesomeness but also of the beauty of doppelbock for the Frankisches weinachtsaison, fitting as naturally as gluhwein and lebkuchen. A real treat.

Thoroughly enjoyed from a 16.9oz bottle in a wine glass.  The beer pours a deep brown color, with a moderate light brown head.  Wondrous notes of smoked meats and German character malt come through in the nose; an intoxicated array of bacon, raisons, caramelized brown sugar, and just a touch of wood.  The palate replicates many of the aromas, showing a deep and rich smoke note, followed by a nice but not over-the-top amount of malt depth and complexity.  Again, oak shows through, but only slightly, adding to the painting, rather than completely covering the canvas.  The finish leaves a lingering note of smoke.  Overall, an outstanding beer, by any measurement.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2011 Bottle at Wine and Beer Westpark on 01/08/2011. Clear golden amber body with a small off-white head. Sweet smoke, caramel and light bread aroma. Sweet smoke, caramel and toasty flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 8/3/8/4/16 - 3.9

Bottle at the 5th Annual Richmond Industry Gathering on 11/28/2010. Clear copper body with a small brown head. Big smoke and salt aroma with a bready background. Big salt and smoke flavor with light bready notes. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 8/4/8/4/16

Bottle courtesy of yngwie.Pours deep amber with an off-white head.Aroma is smoked ham, malt, alcohol an burnt wood.FLavor is sweet and smoked with some oak and ham.Medium body, average carbonation.Very nice smoked beer.
Very distinct smoky flavor, the doppelbock amlts really stand up to the strong smoke flavors

bacon, smoke, salt, pig sex, bbqd meat, and light burnt wood aromas.. . smell is not a 10, more like a 110 .. . A-Maze-Zing! artistic and delicious! .. one of the finest rauchbiers ive ever had... Well, I couldnt see his face, could I? Im not made of eyes!

medium brown with large tan head.  monstrous smoked nose with touches of malt present.  little bitterness before a lot of munich malt that provides a nice balance to the overwhelming smoke from the rauch malt.  little residual sweetness and well fermented resulting in a very drinkable brew and the most balanced of all the aecht brews ive had
Bottle. Dark amber. Big fishy smoke scent.  Sweet smoke flavour. Some fishiness. Hard to pick out a style underneath the smoke. There is some caramel malt and malt sweetness.

Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours hazy orange amber with a little whiteish head. Aroma is rough/harsh smoke. Med body. Flavor of smokey malt. Tobacco hints. Oak? Apparently lost in the smoke. A flavorful beer that went really well with the homemade chili.

500ml from Sams, Durham. What a bad-ass beer. Clean, clear amber pour with a firm but fairly slim head. Lovely nose, filled with sweet malts, dry hops, and tons of smoke. Mouthfeel is creamy and substantial, and the flavors are really intensely good. A bit of salt and woodiness in there, with a fine and well balanced doppel base that gives heft to things. Clean and dry nonetheless, and anything but too sweet and heavy. Terrifice beer.
Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Pours reddish amber with almost no head and an extreme smoky aroma. There is an ashy smoked malt flavor with a bitter tobacco finish.

On tap at Pigs Ear Beer Festival, day 2 (beer #12) on 1 December 2010. Big props to the foreign beer bar guys for getting hold of this cracker. Has the sweet silky richness of a doppelbock but the smoke, relatively subtle here, provides a wonderful counterpoint. And, for an 8% doopelbock it is remarkably, and wonderfully, drinkable. Im not usually a big fan of doppelbocks but this was stunning. No soy sauce, thankfully.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2011 Light bready aroma.  Fine amber pour.  Fairly dry, medium weight bock.  And where is that Aecht Schlenkerla signature smoke?  I didnt notice it right away, but as the beer warmed it became sweeter and smokier.  There is some molasses flavor in the mix, and I was surprised that the ABV was so high.  This is flavorful and flawless, an unspectacular German bock enlivened with some "Schlenkerla oak smoke."  I would get it again.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Copper colour, offwhite head. Aroma is smoke, bacon, some fruitiness. Flavour is smoked malts, bacon, smoked pepper bells. Quite dry and slightly sweet finish.

On tap at Zly Casy. Dark red brown with a lasting off-white head. Wooden and clean smoky aroma. Sweetish malty flavour with intense smoke and again a certain wooden note. Impressive balance in the beer and no sign of the alcohol content.

Light brown with a thin feel as you pour it: the visual experience makes it seem like its juice, not beer. Head has to work a bit to get going, then dies pretty quickly. Smell is classic Schlenkerla--over the top smoke and meat. Mouthfeel is very watery. Taste is all raw bacon and smoke. A bit of alcohol warmth in the finish. Pretty great flavor, but I wish it had a bit more balls. Definitely easy to drink and I like the woody, peaty, Highland single malt flavors that come through. If youre a rauchbier person, youll like this, though you may think others (including Schlenkerlas flagship) are better; if not, you wont.

Bottle.  Pours clear copper with an average, fizzy white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, toasted, nutty), light hops (earthy, woody), and light esters (fruity) with notes of wood, smoke, and bacon.  Flavor is heavy malt (bread, caramel, toasted, nutty), light hops (earthy, woody), and light esters (fruity) with notes of wood, smoke, and bacon.  Medium body, carbonation, and creaminess with low warmth and a medium sweet finish.
Orange and yellow clear pour.  Meaty smoky aroma.  Dry flavor with smoke.   A bit sweet on the finish.  Decent.
Smoky nose with some rather medicinal notes and a touch of butter. Tate is lightly sweet with some caramel and some fruity yeast, lots of smoke, some oak notes, and some butter.
Poured dark hazy amber, salty smoked meats, caramel malts, little wood, slight tobacco.

Draft @ 4th ave pub in brooklyn. This is what a smoked beer should taste like$ much boozier then the others from them, but very good. Smells of smoke, sausage and wood. Tastes like bacon with a hop andmalt finish thats balanced. I dont see how this is a dopplebock, but its a good smoked beer. Im a fan

Tap @ Zly Casy, Prague. Pours dark unclear brown with a creamy white head and lacings. Chewy malty. Smoke, caramel, campfire and bacon. Smooth and subdued smoke profile/balanced. Full bodied. Dammn lovely!

Its hard for me to be fair with this one, but Im simply not that big of a fan of smoked beers but it came in a mixed sampler, so... Aroma was good slightly smoky, notes of bacon smoked meats. Flavor was just too smoky, liquid smoke, smoked meats. Ill know better and pass from now on.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2011 500ml bottle (CWAF2011) - Shared by Toby for the crew - thanks!
8 Stunning sweet mellow bacony aroma. Textbook Schlenkerla, this is what we love.
4 Deep brown, small head.
8 Lovely soft roasty malts. A decent roast, but tones of gently oaky smokiness.
5 Beautifully mellow woody dryness.
16 Superb, but not as good as the unbelievable urbock. Look forward to having this again in quantity.
Rerate: 500ml bottle (Trade from Quack-Duck - thanks!)
(8:4:8:5:16=4.1) Nice to have this in quantity finally. My goodness its a tasty one. The tarriness and smokiness is more pronounced in this one, with more of a burnt bite for the full length of  the taste. Certainly oakier, a little bit barkier too. Stunning.

Bottle. Poured clear dark copper color with an average light brown frothy head that was mostly lasting with very good lacing. Moderate woody smoke malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet smoke flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Complex standout beer.

light ruby colour, clear with steady bubbles
Aroma is softer than some of the other Schlenkerla beers but it is still definitely smoked meat. 
med/ body and pretty fizzy
the background is definitely a doppelbock; alcohol presence, fizzy, rich malt flavours
but the dominant taste profile is the smoked meat. It tastes like a german smoked sausage.
This is perhaps my second favourite schlenkerla, second to their Märzen. I like the higher abv but the smoked sausage nose and taste is slightly softer, probably tempered by the higher alcohol.

Tap J-Betskis in RAleigh, NC.  Clear dark amber pour with a thick off white head.  Long lasting and loads of drippy lace.  Aroma of campfire, smoked meat and oaky tannins.  Flavor follows suite.  Another solid smoker from Aecht
UPDATED: APR 13, 2011 Bottle.Copper red with a large head,aroma of smoky malt wood and sweetness,taste is deep and sweet,smoky and malty,molasses,ashes,dry oak and leather,full and warming,corrr.

The aroma is smoky of course, meaty, salty.  Very little of the base beer comes through on this.  The appearance is a clear amber, white head.  The flavor again is smoky, sausage-like, some caramel struggling to poke through, some wood.  The finish is salty, smoky, slightly sweet.  Medium/thick in body.  Interesting.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2017 500ml bottle from Utobeer.  Mid brown beer with lasting beige head.  Oh wow.  Just love that aroma.  I mean who doesn?t love that?  That smoked sausage aroma is just so attractive it makes me tingle in my perineum.  But it isn?t stupidly strong, it has perfect balance on the aroma.  A little sweet in the mouth from the ABV.  But the balance in the mouth is just right.  Yes it?s a big tasting beer, but it never runs away with itself.  It has some sting on the end from hops and carbonation that balances the smoke and the ABV and the toffee.  There is a bit of reminder on the flavour of something you get in a dentist, but you soon ignore that.  Incredible really. Re rate on tap at Schlenkerla Bamberg. The mouthfeel is so much better on tap than in bottle. Really good smoke mouthfeel  Some chocolate liquer. Really smooth  a real sipper as the finish lasts and lasts.

16.9 oz. bottle, consumed on 1-24-11. The aroma is smoky, of course. Bacon and campfire scents. Reminds me of a Caol Ila Scotch. The aroma isnt as strong as that on the other beers from this brewery that I have tried. Dry, chalky smell. Roasted green grape and sausage scents. The smell isnt as overwhelmingly awesome as I had hoped, but it certainly is quite good. Pours a gold to light amber color. Surprisingly light in color. Small amount of slow-rising bubbles. Small amount of short-lasting beige head. Smoke hits the palate right away. Fruity, juicy base that reminds of that of an English ale, surprisingly. Chalky, dry smokiness. The taste is closer to what I was hoping for than was the aroma. Meaty and lemon juice flavors. Charred oak-type taste reminiscent of that present in bourbon and rye whiskey. Long, dry, smoky aftertaste. Also a tongue-numbing chalkiness late in the aftertaste. Full body. Could stand to be a bit livelier. Easy to drink. There is a good base beer here topped with good smokiness. My only complaint is that I would prefer it to be smokier still.

rigtig dejlig frisk røg!
Malt, rugbrød, tøv og røg, rødgylden, klar med hvidligt tæt skum.
meget sød og blød.

50 cl bottle from De Bierkoning. Copper color. Beige, lasting head. Aromas of smoke, caramel-sweetness & aromatic hops. Flavor is caramel malty sweet, smoky and somewhat bitter. Firm body. Bit dry finish with good bitterness. Great brew.

D: Mycket rökig och salt
S: Förvånansvärt len och inte alls lika rökig som smaken (nästan lite synd)
E: Lite tunn vätska och vattnig eftersmak.

Aroma does seem to have a bit more complexity and nuance than the other Schlenkerla beech smoked beers and the smoke is a wee bit less intense.  The smoke is still front and center in the flavor, but the rich, sweet malts of the dopplebock style carry the smokey intensity well.  A bit of hop bitterness on the finish.  Nice.
Bottle from Beer Ritz. Dark brown pour with a beige head. Dark fruit, smoke, wood and raisin aromas. Flavours of smoky bacon, dark fruits, dates and caramel. Fruity finish. Good stuff.

A: The beer pours amber in color with a soapy white head to go with it.

S: Definitely quite a bit of smoke, though not quite as campfire heavy as their other beers. Theres a definite oak smell to this (apparently the use of oak is one of the main things that sets this beer apart from their others) it, and just very woody overall. A slight meaty character, which I tend to pick up in smoked beers.

T: I can actually taste a decent amount of sweetness from the beer, which has a doppelbock recipe. There is still a lot of smoke and a hint of saltiness to it. There is a touch of fruit underneath, maybe apples. Perhaps its the saltiness, but I actually do get some bacon here.

M: The body is medium and so is the carbonation. The smoke sort of lingers on the tongue.

D: While their beers arent always my thing, this was surprisingly good. Certainly quite smokey, but enjoyable and different.
Pours a light reddish with a small head. Aroma is wood, musk smokeyness. Taste is smokey bacon bits. Palate is thick but a bit sticky. A weird but interesting beer

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2011 20110609:
Bottle 500ml at home, thanks to Yngwie for the maternity gift. I really needed a rerate of this as I was frankly not anywhere near expecting what I got when I tasted this the first time, and was put off by the intensity. 

Pours a clear amber with an inch of dense, offwhite head. Aroma is loads of smoked beech, tends towars oak, some caramel sweetness. Taste is very sweet and medium bitter with intense smokey dryness lingering for quite a while. Medium to full body, oily texture and soft to average carbonation rounds off a very complex and interesting beer.


20110122: 6 4 5 3 11
Bottle 500ml shared courtesy of Yngwie. Pours clear ruby red with small, off-white head. Aroma of smoke, sausages, bacon, smoked ham. Taste is light sweet, acidic and bitter, feels like eating fried bacon with tons of HP Sauce on the aftertaste. Light to medium body, thin to slick, average carbonation. This was a bit too much smoked ham and bacon for me.

Lovely bacon bits and ham aroma, it only reminds me of beer every now and again.  The smoke is very clean - not clingy like hickory.  Good bottle, good cap, clear honey gold with a huge head.  This was a chore to drink - creosotic, briny, more a cooking ingredient than a beer, the smoke came off as stale -- and this isnt my first rodeo with rauch or smoked beers. Bittering was unpleasant.  Im sure that the brewmaster will think that he threw his pearls before swine, but this was not very enjoyable.  New Leaf Market.
Bottled 50cl. A huge amount of bacon throughout. Smoky and very enjoyable. Interesting. I find other beers from this brewery a lot more impressive than the Eiche.

0.5 l bottle, thanks Timo A! Red amber color. Thick smoky bacon aroma with sweet malt. Sweet, malty and smoky flavor with thick tarry and bacony smoke. Thick palate. Nice sipper but I prefer the more drinkable Ur-Bock and Märzen from this brewery.

Bottle.  Smokey and honey ham aroma.  Clear chestnut color with nice off-white head.  Sweet honey smoked ham and malt flavor with a lightly bitter grass finish.  Much sweeter than any other Aecht Schlenkerla beers but nicely balanced.  Given the sweetness of this beer, I was thinking it might go well with a spiced Christmas cake so luckily we still had some Nuernburger Lebkucken - goes together well.
ambrata schiuma media discreta persitenza naso affumicato ma non ivadente note caramellate leggero etilico in affumicata riscaldante maltata leggero caramello

500 ml bottle from Enniskillen, bought at Country Club Liquors. Nose is lightly sweet, smoky, and caramel with a backgoud hint of bubblegum. All nicely light and balanced notes like most overly smoky "smoked" beers. Clear orange with a small yellowish head. Flavor is lightly smoky, caramelized sugar, and a very light bitterness. Finishes with hints of smoke and bitter.

I was pretty excited to see a Schlenkerla Id yet to try at my local store and intrigued by the use of oak instead of beechwood in smoking the grain. It is a fairly standard coppery bock color w/ a small white head. The nose is the furthest thing from standard, however. Its thick w/ musty smoked notes. You can really tell the difference between this and their standard offerings. This feels a bit more nuanced, perhaps a bit floral. This brings to mind aromas of the forest in autumn around a camp fire. The texture is creamy and the touch of alcohol is warm and comforting. I am not sure if my numbers will match up in the end but I think this might be my favorite of the Schlenkerlas.

Bottle 500ml @ home
[Courtesy of yngwie] Pours clear dark brown/amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of smoked malt, smoked ham/bacon. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with a short to average smokey finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Handsome, deep chestnut beer with a level cream head. Aroma of meat, leather, smoked gammon, onion sauce- Nana Gs kitchen circa 1985..and other kitchens of my childhood. Chargrilled meat taste lingering with ash; hints of TCP, custard and a lethal creaminess off the oak- some coppery hints in the finish and way more bitterness than the beechwood-smoked Schlenkerlas. Maybe doesnt quite hit the heights Id hoped for but still huge, savoury and very, very drinkable chilled..which is what Im becoming very, very quickly. Pure lederhosen-slapping, goat-beating loveliness....And I applaud the innovation-within-traditional boundaries that updates a world classic without surrendering its essential and unmistakeable Schlenkerla-ness. Hats off.

Bottle. Finger of foamy white head that disappears quickly on a bright clear amber orange.  Deep woodiness, slight oakiness, campfire smoke in the aroma.  A strong malty sweetness cuts through the meaty smokiness, and the big smoke, fire, and sausage of others from the brewery are tamed down a bit for this one, but its damn good still.  Bacony aftertaste with some sweetness following on an oily body with very soft carbonation.

Dark coppery colored with little yellow head. Strongly rich tar aroma dominates with smoke and sweet fruitiness, nice wooden oaked touch and caramel. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is more dry with tar still dominating, smoke and bacon here strongly as well. Aftertaste dries with some hops, still bacon and smoke here. Just excellent brew.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2013 Bottle, 8.0%. Distinct smoke aroma, but not too much, also some malt. Clear brown colour, seems to have a little red. Tan head, semi-frothy and semi-stable. The flavour has a distinct smokiness and a rather sweet maltiness. The finish is drier and perhaps a bit more aggressively hopped than their Rachbier Märzen. Does not really taste 8%, but it is very good.

Pours a clear orange/amber with a substantial, but not big, antique lace head.  Aroma is smokey malt.  Theres smoke in the taste as well, along with sweet toasted malt, honey, a pleasant grassiness and mild hop bitterness.  Alcohol warmth follows the swallow.  An exceptional brew!

500ml Btl - Really excited to try this, really like the other Aecht Schlenferla Rauchbiers and smoked brews in general.  Pours a golden orangeish with a small creamy white head.  Nose is huge sharp smokiness, wood, oak, malt, sweetness and maybe a tiny hint of alcohol.  Taste is slight malt sweetness upfront which immediately gives way to a sharp long-lasting smokiness with oaky, woody undertones and very subtle earthy hop bitterness at the very end.   Aftertaste lasts forever, mouthfeel borders on thick and syrupy, medium carbonation.  Incredibly flavorful, the fullness of the mouthfeel is the only clue of the 8% ABV.  Surprisingly enough, the smoke and oak blend together perfectly and there is no heat, no astringency, no off flavors at all, cant believe these flavors meld together this well in such a fresh beer.   A truly splendid brew!

500 ml with best before date June 2011 into Aecht Schlenkerla Eiche glass. Pours amber to deep coppery body with reddish hue and good clarity, topped by medium beige dense head with good retention, that clings to the walls.
Aroma is a pleasant balance between malty sweetness and non-harsh, smooth wood &, bacon-like smokiness obtained by oak-wood kilned malt.The smoky curtain is delicate enough to transmit the Doppelbock characteristics of the base beer underneath: rich malty malty sweetness with significant melanoidins and touch of plum and grape-like fruitiness.
The flavor is campfire and bacon-like smokiness which interplays with malty sweetness. The malts show melanoidin qualities accompanied by notes of dark chocolate. Towards the finish emerges peppery spiciness (probably originating from the Hallertau hops used) with moderate hoppy bitterness. No inappropriate harsh, burnt or charred flavors. The finish is semisweet although the smoke reduces the Doppelbock sweetness to some degree by adding some dryness. Medium to full boded with soft carbonation and unbelievable drinkability for a beer of this type, partially thanks to smooth and complex yet not overpowering smoky character.

In short: A fantastic smoked Doppelbock with perfect balance between the smoke and base beer, reflecting the character of both.

Bottle from Systembolaget. It poured a clear dark golden liquid with a medium sized dirty white head. Flavour of smoke, ham, wood, fur, wet animal, tar, smoked ham and old boat. Fat and smooth mouthfeel with a medium thick body and low amount of carbonation. This one was packed with smoke and allot of flavour I relate with a life in the forest or on a boat. However I felt that the smoke was a bit too overpowering.

Finally, a bottle.  Nose is strong woody smoke, campfire and pig-roast analogies aside, just bursting out of the bottle, as always.  Sweet malt swirling in there as well, alcohol is subdued.  Amber-copper pour with an ephemeral head.  Taste has low bitterness, light to medium sweetness, and theyre nicely balanced.  All sorts of bready and crackery notes toward the end, along with that ever-present smoke (but different smoke from what Im used to from Schlenkerla, getting a little toward fish).  Smooth, rich obese body with a touch of alcohol wallop for good measure.  Just layers of malt for the tongue to sift through.  Touch of hoppy spice from the bright and lively additions, and another spicy note that suggests a dash of rye.  Even smaller touch of lagery citrus and crispness.  Super mellow and rewards the search for complexity - an immediate favorite!
Magnificent, smoky with honey oak sweet taste, I would ascribe this to be maple-cured bacon on the list of Schlerkerla beers.

1 pint 0.9 fl oz of beer. Smoke! A thick bonfire-like smokiness fills the room right away once this one is poured. All in a very positive way mind you, as to me theres really not too much roasted pork in the aroma. The smoking woody oak tree notes really take over, but also some caramel and grain malts with decent dose of earth as well. On the pour, a thin layer of white bubbling cream head, little retention, and a light auburn, bright, clear, and lightly carbonated appearance. The body is nicely creamy and medium bodied. I was expecting it to be a bit more chewy, but actually turned out to be nicely drinkable. Light sweet fruits start in the beginning, with strong smoked wood and earth taking it through the end. Well balanced as  a result and pleasantly bitter. Other notes of toffee, cookies, medium grain malts and light burned grass. I think the smoked notes work quite well with the doppelbock style. Easily one of the best smoked beers I have had.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of Bamburg wood, smoke, band-aid, and oak.  Poured amber in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium spicy.  Tastes of wood, smoke, oak, bacon, smoked cheese, smoked meat, and slight caramel.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Smoke, oak, wood, smoked meat, slight bacon, and hit of caramel finish.  8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.  Like drinking liquid smoke.

Bottle: Pours a transparent deep copper amber with a clingy-lacing froth of off-white head.  Has a sweet smoky caramel nose with a touch of sea salt.  Starts with a good toasted malty fullness and sweet caramel notes with a complex smoked oak flavor and light noble hop bitterness before a smooth balanced finish.  A very flavorful and quite drinkable brew.  Perhaps not as smoky as the Urbock, but more balanced.
BottledPours a clear, deep amber colour with a fine head. Campfire aroma. Dry flavour of bacon and burning wood leading to a somewhat sweet and warming finish.

16.9 oz bottle.  Clear golden brown with pink highlights and a sudsy white head.  Nose is kippers with apple and hay.  Medium body with light carb.  Taste is malt, nougat, clove and ham.  Smoke is complimentary throughout; overall a bit too sweet.

Bottled @ in de Wildeman. Dark color, short head. Great smoked aroma, bacon, soft roasted malt, only a slight hint of oak. It seems a bit softer than the regular rauchbock, but the smokey notes from the Schlenkerla beers are just so perfectly clean and balanced. Stunning beer again!

(Bottle) Pours clear dark amber with a sand coloured head. The aroma is smoky, but softer than the other Schlenkerla beers. Clear tones of campfire smoke alongside more subtle meaty/sausage/fish-like notes. A light sweetness from the malt is notable. Herbal, light grassy hops way in the background. Elegant and Lager clean nose. Whisper of honey, wet asphalt, wet forest, doughy white bread, wood shop and dried fruits. Complex nose (for a smoked beer). The flavour is light to medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Tones of smoke, herbal/grassy hops, dried fruits and bread. The flavour is bit more one-dimensional if you compare it to the aroma. The mouthfeel is clean, soft and smooth with a light sticky touch. Light to medium carbonated. Smoke lingers. Medium to full bodied. Clean end elegant, somewhat like a smoked champagne.

Bottle from Quack-Duck, thanks! Dark brown color. Oak, malt and smoked sausage in the aroma. Malty sweet, oaky flavor with loads of Hema smoked sausage. Hint of peach. Long aftertaste. Very well balanced and likeable brew.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2010 Dark amber color, translucent with a decent beige head. Nose is a bit more grainy and leafy than other Schlenkerla, still nice smoke but not as thick or immediate. The smoke flavor also lays off a bit at first, way more caramel and earth at front palate, then a wave of malt, leaf, bubblegum mid-palate, then finally some lasting hints of lingering citrus, and alcohol in the finish, leading to medicinal notes. Moderate-full body, sweeter than most Schlenkerla leading to more complexity from the less amped, more balanced smoke, one that I enjoy less but still find fantastic. The finish is long-lasting smoke. Damn good, not my favorite, but fantastically enjoyable while remaining subtle.

20101229  500ml bottle from Honeygo.  Light motor oil amber with thin beige head.  Pretty average looking beer, but thats where it ends.  Aroma is smoky, heh.  Well, in fact its one of the more intense and complex smoky aromas Ive come across in a while.  More of a brine and woodsy smoke with this beer, and with a great hoppy interplay that adds some herbs and late hay.  There is less of the (typical) Schlenkerla smoked meat (hate that analogy) and yet its just as smoked.  Gorgeous.  Medium bodied with soft eff and a lingering bitterness that begins mid-palate and sticks around with a grassy, herbal, mildly woody note.  Late leather and some alcohol, quite warming, savory, damn.  This is one warmer that I just want to guzzle.  Fantastic stuff.  Sheesh, I bought three but Ill definitely need to load up on this one.

Bottle; Pour is clear copper with amber highlights. The Off white head died immediately, unfortunately. Everything I was expecting on the nose; Ham Roasts and Campfire, Caramel Malts and oak. This is certainly the best Aecht brew Ive had - it just works or fuses the best; oak, smokiness, roasted ham, campfire, caramel malt sweetness, with a tingling on the tongue. Rounded off with the hallertau - but it takes a backseat to the rest. Excellent really!

Bottle at In De Wildeman, Amsterdam. Red, brown colored brew. Very intense, smoked aroma, burning wood. Aroma fades rather quick. Flavor has a good amount of smoke too, malty sweetness, caramel and bacon. Nice.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2011 Bottle. Amber with a white head. Aroma: sweet, smoke, campfire. Taste. sweet malt, fresh fruitiness, great subdued smokiness that isnt meaty at all, salt, some candy, caramel, low bitterness, but there is some acidity in the finish. There is also kind of a juniper smokiness that reminds me of my childhood fishing trips (korv grillad över enris). Medium-bodied with noticable carbonation. Really good!
Bottle with best before date a month ago, still as good. Some more tar in the aroma, more salt and smoked meat in the taste. Not sure if this has changed over time, I wont change my original notes.

Aroma of smoke, malt, and raw grain. Pours copper with light tan head that dissipates quickly. Palate is thin yet a bit oily, like bacon grease. I was expecting a harsher smoke flavor, but this beer is very well balanced and almost subdued considering other Aecht Smoked beers. Starts sweet and smokey and finishes with a nice bittering but NOT overly so. This is a special beer in the smoked catagory. Very enjoyable, with a little bit of "holiday" coming through. I think this is my favorite from Aecht Schlenkerla! Tasted @ 50F.

Bottled from Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Cola colored, brown head. Very smoky nose (duh), wood-notes, malts, perhaps some wheat shining through. Smooth malty and smoky flavor, some liquorice, caramel, sweet initially which later on becomes more bitter. Excellent developing, complex and long-lasting finish, very nice. Similar to all of the Schlenkerla beers this is an outstanding brew. A bit too sweet for me in flavor, but its extended complexity makes this a good addition to the other rauchbiers from this brewery.

Bottle.  Copper with a beige bubbly foam.  Aromas are toffee and rye malts with smoky bacon crisps and hints of barbecue sauce.  Very rich on the nose but not overbearing.  Lightly fruity and floral.  Flavours are sweet, rich rye with lots of smoke.  Apple with peppery, warming alcohol.  Some chocolate with yet more smokiness.  Easy to drink considering its strength and character.  Very good.

Clear brown pour with a clear body and lively carbonation. The aroma is smoked salmon, bacon, charred meats, and all sorts of pleasantly placed smoke characteristics. The flavor holds smoky bready malts with toffee and caramel being most predominant. More smoky wood, campfire, smoked salmon, and bacon comes through. Mild graininess with a slight floral hop bitterness. Palate is medium bodied with lively fine bubbled effervescence and and chewy body. Clean, smoky finish. Another delicious beer from this brewery.

Bottled from Systembolaget
Deep golden with a small, white head.
Loads of tar. Sweet with oak and som e violet.
Low bitterness.

500 ml bottle from Wine and Cheese Place.  Pours a clear copper color with a finger-thick white head that settles into a thin film on the beer.  Aroma of smoked pork, wood, campfire, well-done bacon, and burnt sweet toast.  Flavor of smoked pork, burnt toast, caramel malts, toasted sugar, peat, nectarine, honey, and corn syrup.  The flavor drops out a little from the nose.  Medium-full bodied, with a smoky, syrupy mouthfeel and a quick metallic, then lingering smoky finish.  Sweet and smoky, and I liked this way more than I expected.  All of the Aecht Schlenkerla beers are great, and this and the dunkel are the best.

Aroma: Intensely smoky, camp fire, bacony nose, very inviting, would be great next to some barbequed pork.

Appearance: Amber pour with a fast-fading off-white head. 

Taste: Rich caramel malt, smoky, bacony backbone, nicely bitter finish.

Palate: I thought the mouthfeel was pretty thin.

Overall: Very tasty. I really enjoy the beechwood smoked version as well and will probably do a side-by-side comparison to see how the msoke character differs.

Pours orange with a medium well retained head and some bit of lace. The aroma is very woody and smoky but this is not without a nice dose of fruitiness and some mineral character. The smoke in the aroma  is a very sweet smoke I kept thinking of Christmas hams and bacon. The flavor has a nice spicy on smoky character right up front and the fruity almost sweet malt again gives this a cured bacon character. 
the beer has a nice dose of bitterness not from any distinct hop likely because of the dominant character of the smoke and malt, er um.. the smoked malt... whatever. Despite the smoke the beer retains the character of a dopplebock almost perfectly with a nice semisweet malt, some spiciness, and a nice creamy texture with just a tinge of warmth from the alcohol. This retains the style on the label far better than say the Marzen or Weizen do, not that that makes those bad beers... I guess it just makes this one all the more remarkable. The beer is nicely full on the palate and the carbonation is low but just right to perfectly present this beer.

Pours a clear orange amber with minimal bubbly head. Aroma holds phenomenal smoke and oak; not multi-faceted, but beautifully balanced. Flavor is much more subdued, with lighter smoke and wood presence and a touch of sweeter malt. Palate is very light, particularly for an 8% "doppelbock." Very interesting, and tasty, but the combination of styles and how to categorize this is truly befuddling.

the smoke flavor is in your face with long stench of smokey goodness. despite that there is plenty of sweet malts with strong wood flavor, little hops but the taste is ideal with cheeses ad BBQ all the way. not to be drunk by  itself.

Aroma of burnt oak, campfire, peat and slight caramel. Appearance is reddish light brown with white head. Flavor matches the nose with a very slight milk chocolate taste. Palate is bubbly and creamy. Good and different on the Doppelbock side of things.

The commercial description is spot on.  A smoother, creamier version of the rauchbier.  I do appreciate anything with smoke, but I still prefer the punch you in the face aroma and flavor of the marzen and urbock, as oppossed to this mellow, vanilla campfire presented here.  The flavor is definitely like licking a burnt piece of wood.  Very nicely done.

Bottle. Copper with a short, foamy white head. Aroma is very appetizing! Barbecue cooking on the pit with pork and sausage smothered in a tomato and brown sugar based sauce. Thats it in a nutshell. Taste is smoky but sweet. Sweet malt, caramel, light bits of brown sugar atop burning wood, barbecued meats and smoke. Body is medium with a very soft carbonation. Ends with more smoke, burnt wood, barbecue, and caramel. This is delicious! Its unfortunate that this was not out during the summer. Would go perfect with any cook-out.

The aroma is very smokey and if smoke beers are your thing you will love it. I will give it credit for being what its supposed to be. The appearance is orange gold with a thin head and has very little carbonation. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is thin and watery. Overall a smoke beer for smoke beer lovers, which i am not.

On tap. Pours a clear reddish brown with a dense and stable off-white head leaving some lacework. Sweetish aroma of caramel and baconish smoke. Quite a rich and full body with a solid base of caramel, smoky in a rubbery way with a fairly bitter finish. 141210

[500ml bottle, Cornelius Beer & Wine, Edinburgh] Pours a rather nice copper colour with a pearly white head. Aromas of smoke  very similar to those thin packet frankfurters. In fact, its like every smoked meat dish youve ever come across. Having had the Rauchbier Marzen this Eiche is less crazy and slightly sweeter  but still very much the smoke monster (albeit a small monster compared to their other beers). The oak does make a difference  but at the end of the day youll either love this or hate it. Doesnt really do it for me, Im afraid [17122010]

Bottle.

Clear amber with a small white head. Aroma and taste of smoke, not as much ham as expected. Sweet with a lot of carbonation. Good but not excellent. Easy to drink.
Bottle (thx Travlr). Pours light amber with an off-white head. Flavor of shoe leather, beef jerky/bacon, malt sweetness, and salt. Grows on you after a few sips.

Bottle at Paradiso Dupont.  Clear dark amber color, beige head.  Aroma similar to what I imagine the Lord of the Flies set must have been, with burning pig flesh all around.  Taste has campfire, bacon, light spice, lots of malt, ashtray - everything but the marshmallows.  Very nice.

Good Stuff here. Smokey, as is to be expected, but there was also an undercurrent of sweetness that balanced everything out. Good mix of caramel and smoke, like maybe caramel covered bacon or something.

50cl Bottle from De Bierkoning, very happy to finally see this bottled here. Clear chestnut colour, big off white head. Aroma of campfire smoke, a bit salty, light bacon, some sweet malts and caramel. Flavour is light sweet, malty, caramel, light fruity, good light salty, smokey and prickly bitter finish. Medium bodied. I found this to be more subtle in smoke and less sweet than the Urbock, thus more enjoyable. Great smoked beer.

500 ml bottle in Germany, thanks to Bottleman. Poured a coppery amber with a smallish white head. Aroma is dominated by the rich, somewhat meaty smokiness. The smoke flavor is not so strong as with their other beers. I appreciated the beer as a whole more than their others. Has a strong, somewhat sweet malty body and a spicy, bitter hop presence. The alcohol is not very noticable at all. A pretty awesome experience.

Pours an orange-amber into the glass, with a fully diminished head that reduces to no lace.  The nose is of awesomely smoked peat, smoked pork, wood, grilling campfire, some bacon and spent ash.  The flavors are of sweet malt, earthen smoked oak, spent campfire, smoked peat, and finish with a smoky bitter.  After the finish, the effervescence contains smoky fringes, really hitting on ash and sweet spent grilling (pork/peat) campfires.  The drinkability is superb, as the mouthfeel is smooth, with a decent body that slides down the palate in wonderful integration.  Awesome job with this smoked!

(bottle) Clear, deep amber colour with a copper shine and a big and tanned foamy head. Profound smoke malty aroma, moderately sweet with notes of saumon fumé, bacon and a salty touch. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, full bodied with a pleasantly smooth carbonation. Pronounced smoke flavours as expected from a Schlenkerla brew, just a tad more fishy than fleshy, accompanied by shades of caramel, earthy notes and even a tinge of hops; sweet and slightly bitter smokey finish with a light but warming alcoholic note shining through. Just another Schlenkerla gem. 18.XII.10
Bottle. Big dissapointment. Didnt like the mix of very sweet and heavy smoked malt´. It was just too much for me really...

500mL courtesy of Travlr. Pours a light amber with a thin, white head. Aroma is huge hickory smoked bacon, barbecue pork, honey maple glazed barbecue, rich leather. Taste is creamy, huge bacon, honey malt sweetness coming through, big time barbecue abounding. Malt-forward, sweet barbecue, honey, rich body. Hilarious.

Bottle, from Schlenkerla-shop.de. A two-finger thick head sits patiently on top of the steadily sparkling deep amber body. Nice layers are left as the creamy, off-white head slides down the glass as Im enjoying the beer. Quite subtle on the nose, at least compared to the Urbock or Märzen. Smoke, damp forest, caramel notes, hints of prunes, figs and dates, and some caramel. A faint alcohol touch and some grains and grassy hops too. The smoke parts reminds me of both smoked meat, smoked and then roasted sausages and a bit like smoked fish. Its full-bodied and creamy on the palate, with a slight alcohol burn down the throat. A bit too smooth actually. Theres a whole bunch of complexity in the flavor as well. Some bitterness, but not much. Far from overly sweet, but sure on the sweet side, with caramel. Else theres wood notes, smoke, alcohol hints, dried fruits, cured meat and some grassy hop hints. The end stays for a long time, very long. Wow, this was a real treat! Its dangerously easy drinking, at least when cold, a bit more demanding when it heats up a bit. Its really tasteful, and it has the looks of a super model. Due to Norwegian tax rules it was pretty expensive getting a crate of these, but it was certainly worth each damn penny. Or øre as the Norwegian equivalent is. Now Im looking forward to the rest of the winter. 101217

at ølbaren
clear dark amber, small head.
very smoked aroma, lots of smoke, one of the most smoked aromas ive sampled. smoke is more dominant, the rest is a little more subdued. flavor is sweet, smoked, caramelly, very nice.
A beautiful golden copper lager.  Smokey aroma, reminds me of good bacon.  A nice malty, smoke flavor.  Medium thin mouth feel.  The oak smoke really comes though.  One of my favorite lagers.

Picked up a 500ml bottle from Heritage Liquor in Maplewood, MN. Pour a semi-clear golden amber colored brew with a creamy and long lasting beige head that leaves behind some nice lacing. Aroma of smoked peat, a hint of cotton candy, a touch of bacon, and floral hops. Taste is quite smooth. Medium to full bodied, flavors of caramel malt, cotton candy, plenty of smoked malt, along with candied wintergreen and a touch of ham. Finish continues the smoked sweet caramel aftertaste with a short dry bitterness. Most excellent!

Pours clear amber into a stem glass. Off-white head with limited retention recedes to mottle surface. Sweet smoke aromas. Sweet and full with caramel upfront and smoke from front to back. Lasting sweet smoke finish.

Bottle: Clear, ruby-amber coloured, small to mid-sized lacy off-white head; sweet smoky ashy nose, mingled with aromas of caramel, grilled salmon and burnt furniture; solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium to full bodied, soft; aromatic hops show up in the caramelly-smoky and bitter finish. Very good, but a bit overrated.....

One of the beers from the new stash of german beers arrived in Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Allready when opening you can sense the smokeyness as from a bonfire in the mittle of summer. The pour is kobber red and clear with a neat tight and solid orange head. The nose is first of all smokey in a comined ham / bonfire way. Next to the smokeyness there is some metal and malty notes fighting each other for attention. The mouthfeel is pretty thick and a long lasting flavour of smoke stays with along with some mild sweet malts. Its surprisingly thick. The taste is sweet but also here you first of all notice the dominatic smoke flavours that kind off takes over the intire picture. NIce warming beer - that indeed is suitable for christmas and long cold nights in a wooden cabin with snow outside. Cheers

Mouth watering smoky bacon nose. Clear copper, no head. Sweet malt and smoke. Smoky oak finish. Unusually good balance for an  unbalanced style. Distinctive and the food pairing possibilities are intriguing.

Bottle @ The Beer Mongers...  Poured clear golden with an off-white head. Very smokey.  Liked smoke Gouda cheese and campfire.  Decent sweetness though. Holy wow!  This is incredible.  If you dont like smoke beers beware.

1st December 2010  Pigs Ear Fest! Clear amber beer. Light crisp palate but fairly low carbonation. Sweetish malt with a little dark toffee. A nice amount of smoke, not overdone. Balances out really well. Tiny bit of orangey hop in the finish in the semi dry finish. Very drinkable.

Light copper colored with a small light beige head. Intense smoky aroma of mainly smoked ham and smoked dried salami, but also caramelly, woody and fruity notes lingering behind the smoke. The alcohol is nowhere to be found. The finish has a slight sweetness.

Bottle. Medium high fluffy white head. Hazy yellow body. Aroma where the wood competes with the smoke of be the dominent part.  The goes for the flavor. Smoke is somewhat subdued but the balance is very good. Alcohol well hidden. Low carbonation. Long aftertaste.

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - 500 ml bottle. Pours a slightly murky dark orange with a thin, but sticky white head that leaves a slight trail of lacing. Enticing aroma of smoked meats and maple syrup - smells like a smokehouse. Flavor is full bodied and bold. Plenty of smoked ham goodness, some sweet molasses, a hint of dates, a hint of wood. Mouthfeel is thick enough to match the flavor. Excellent smoked beer - the smokiness doe snot override the original beer flavor but rather enhances it.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2016 Bottle from RexTalionis, thx!  Poured  copper color with a light beige looking head. Really intense smoke aroma, delicious. The smoked ham flavor is almost covering the rest of the flavors, but I also noticed some wood flavors and sweetness towards finish.  Great beer again from Heller, but I prefer the märzen and Urbock over this. 

 Rerate,  vintage 2010.  Most of the smoke has disappeared,  mostly salty meat,  wood and sweetness.  Flavor has sweetness,  broth,  salt and smoke.  Not worth aging if you ask me. 
546311
Pours bright golden with a fully receding off-white head. Notes of smoke, oak, cured meats, earthy, charred toffee, dusty malt. Full bodied lightly sticky with soft carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours a fairly transparent bronze color with thin, bright white suds thrown haphazardly above.  RIch, Meaty, and smokey nose with an underlying woody sour twang around the camp smoke edges.  The mouthfeel was somewhat syrupy with fairly low carbonation.  The flavors were decently smokey but more of a smokey wood flavor than smokey meaty, I would say...I think...I mean, they can interchange, but Im getting smokey wood more than meat here.  Redundancy.  Yes. No.  Ok.  All in All, Flavors are nice enough but Im neither digging the overall syrupy texture nor the low carbonation, and both of those attributes here are bringing down the experience for me.

Bottle. Poured deep copper brown colour with a tan head. Aroma is smoke, smoked beef and charred wood. Flavour is at first very intense smoke and smoked meat. Smooth and as it gets warmer the smoke is still there but not as overwhelming as it was at first. Smoked sweetness detected in the end. A great one.
Really good smoke beer! The oak notes are very present and gives a new dimension to the smokyness which becomes more reminiscent of smoky Whiskey than of meat and sausages as the original

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2013 Bottle from 5 points bottle shop. Had my first bottle a couple weeks back at a better temperature and it was everything I would expect from Schlenkerla. This particular glass Ive poured myself is a little too cold. It seems sweeter with more vegetal esters and less smokiness, not at all the amazing brew I indulged in last time. I am noticing how low the carbonation is in this. No head remains. As the brew comes up in temp, that lovely campfire, barbecue-like smoke gains strength. This was supposed to be a departure from the marzen or urbock, but its not much of one. I certainly cant complain. The smoke is similar to beechsmoke, still meaty and lingering. This strongly reminds me of their urbock, maybe just slightly fruitier. Absolutely wonderful smoked offering when served closer to cellar temperature. 
[November 28, 2013]

Bottle from Argonaut. I am sad to say that it has been far too long since my last taste of Schlenkerla. My recent disappointment in a few American smoked beers lead me to return to the roots of the style. I can safely continue to maintain that Aecht Schlenkerla makes the worlds finest smoked beers with no one else even in contention. I almost weep tears of joy upon sipping this beautiful beer.

Clear quite deep amber colour with off-white soapy head. Aroma is smoky sausage, some fruit and hops. Makes me hungry. Taste is rich sweet, caramel, dried fruit, spicy hops, malty, oily. Warming alcohol that doesnt go over the top. Oh I can definitely see this with cheese.

500ml bottle from K&L Redwood City.  Pours a surprisingly light copper color with a small white head that has average retention.  The aroma is smoked ham sandwich on rye, not an uncommon smell for me to pick up in Aecht Schlenkerla beers.  Some sweet malty notes back it up.  The flavor is rather typical for beers from these guys.  Sweet pale malt, caramel, and a hammy intense smokiness.  Pretty nice mouthfeel, smooth with medium-plus body and average carbonation.  Long smoky meaty finish that sticks with you.  Overall, nothing really wowed me, and Ill say I like the Urbock better.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2012 Draught at Rovers thx to Clyx 2012-02-15, still smokey! New rating 3,6 ie new average 3,9

Bottle picked up at the SB today, cons 2010-12-06 Göteborg
AR: fine smoked sausages, 
AP: dark coppar colored body, 3 cm high froty wee bubbly light beige head  
F: first some light smokey birch sauna, then a rich and round toffee, and then again a pritty short smokey finish. Medium + bitterness, medium carbonation, a bit oily in concistence, and yes there are are some vanilla beans.

*** GERMAN BEER RATING #2500 *** bottle. Clear brown colour, mid-sized off-white head. Smoky nose. Full-bodied, solid malty base with sweet hints, lots of woody smoke in the middle part. Bitter hops blend in towards the lingering, smoky finish. A delicious smoked beer.

Bottle. Pours out in a clear amber colour with a small white head. Big intense smoke aroma of ham, tar, bacon, oak and salt. Nearly full-bodied with strong notes of wood, bacon, salt, licorice and ham. Long Smokey finish of bacon, oak and mild alcohol. Not complex but will calm down most "smoke-heads".
Not much to say but this: this is liquid smoked chese in a bottle. Looks good too! Dark golden, unlasting head. Leavs no lacing.

5th Epic and Rare, courtesy of dkachur I believe.  Amber appearance.  Flavor and aroma match - sausage.  Pure smoked sausage.  A little bitter on the finish.  Another beer from these guys I can respect but not really care for.

Thanks turdferguson for sharing. Pours a clean light copper with a thin offwhite had. Nose is rich and meaty, nice smoke character and sweet malt profile. Rich and dextrinous flavor with a fantastic integration of smoke and malt. Medium hop bite and spicy alcohol.

A Mes rate. Cask at Pigs Ear.Deep russet brown colour with a thin off white head. Epic Schlenkerla smoky goodness. Thick and chewy doppelbockiness with a good stinging bitterness from the smoke and some glorious fruit and a hint of sour madness. Brilliant, brilliant, brilliannnnnnnnnnt.

Hazy caramel color at first, then turning mostly transparent with a coarse white head.   Aroma is phenolic and caramel with woody band-aid.  Taste is the same with a maple syrup sweetness and heavy band-aid into the finish. $5/500ml

Bottle. Yet another Schlenkerla. I havent rated all of the locally available ones as I am not a big smoked beer fan. I rate this one on blind faith...and objectively. Pours with a hazy deep golden to very light amber body and a frothy white head. Aromas of ...SMOKE..big surprise. BBQ, jerky, bacon fat, charcoal briquettes, maple, oak, flint, pencil, honey. Not my thing to be perfectly honest. Ill still try to rate as objectively as I can. Honey, hay and smoke, light bacon fat, bbq, campfire, oak, honey. Shockingly drinkable for a smokey beer. Lots of rich, caramel, wood, and fire notes. Bacon fat. Tasty. Medium bubbles. Good. Light bubblegum and caramel finish.

Bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA, shared at the 5th Annual Epic Beer Tasting in Richmond, VA, November 28, 2010. Pours a clear amber color with a thin head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of big smoke notes. This is a meaty one. Some caramel and toffee malts also. The taste is caramel, toffee, raisin and a strong smoke finish. Medium bodied. Pretty nice. Yay, Im at 100% for Schlenkerla!!!

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2010 From the wood @ Schlenkerla! where it is served in an unmarked goblet, like a wide tulip, and really comes across as a Belgian Christmas beer in character. No one in the Ausschank is drinking it, it seems "too sweet" and something for foreigners...anyway, it is red and lighter in hue than the other Schlenkerla beers. Initially giant head but doesnt leave as nice lace as the normal beer...still gorgeous holiday hue, 4. Aroma, mellow, smooth, handsome but shy 9. Oily, thick palate, moreish for sure--on a beer this strong its a 5. Not hot at all! Not head-splitting. Really smooth and mellow. Happiness! Subdued smoke, subtle enough for a wimp and assertive enough for a pro. Very woody. Well-integrated flavors overall. Any lingering mature malt sugars transmogrify into dry smokey wood.  Sophisticated yet fun and yummy 10. One of the best Christmas beers ever, 20.
Smells of bacon when poured. Medium amber appearance with a relatively small head. The flavor is wonderful. Primarily that of smoked ham, but also bacon and roasted beef. Medium-bodied and smooth.

bottle.  clear bronze/orange under a small, frothy, white head.  sweet  wood   
aroma of white smoke.  the flavor is smoke perfection, but a little different than the beechwood they normally use.  flavor of toasted marshmallow, smoked apples/pears, smoked pork, paprika, molasses.  i cant believe its 8%.  incredibly smooth.  moderately sweet.  greatness.

Bottle at Uber. It was quite diaphanous. Not much of a body on this -- the head was quite thin and wispy. The aroma was exceptional. Smoked jerky, beef, and oak. Good God, this fuckin beer is pungent, and has all of the right kind of smoky flavors to it. The oak is subtle at times, and other times its quite noticeable. The texture carries the smoke, char, and oak quite well, albeit, it is a relatively thin texture. This beer leaves a lasting smoky, char, and smoked meat flavor on your tongue. Fuck, this is the best smoked beer that I have tried. Even though my rating might not reflect the aforementioned statement, that is because I was immature in the previous ratings, and may have overrated.
Bottle. Nose of layered sweet malts, blossoming smokiness. .  Flavor is layered with mild sweetness, oak, and a big smoke finish.  Insanely smooth. Really tasty.

Cask - Maxs.   Clear amber, fluffy white head.  Deep campfire smoke aromas ride softer undercurrents of oak and sweet maple coated dark fruit.  Rich smoky wood flavors round with swirls of sweet and salty barbequed meat throughout.  Medium bodied with pillow soft carbonation.  Fantastic, but one is plenty

New Beer Distributors 500ml ($5): Pours a white head over a light amber body. Half of the beer is the aroma, which is smoky like no other. The oak smoke is I think somewhat smokier than the beech used in the other beers by Aecht. Also in the aroma you get the meat and if you wait around long enough a few hoppy notes. Taste is also extremely smoky while its cold, but as it warms up the hoppy and sweet notes start to become apparent. This is a very intense beer, and for uniquely different reasons than why most beers are intense. Tingly mouthfeel, but also coats the entire inside of the mouth.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Deep amber colour with small off-white head. Aroma is smoke, some bacon, mild notes of oak and some slight maltyness. Flavour is quite much the same in a very nice balance with some slight notes of alcohol showin as well. Quite interesting.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival.  Clear brownish amber, no head. Heavily smoky nose with plenty of bacon and oak. Sweet and full bodied with solid well rounded mouthfeel. Big time smoke flavour. Nice maklt character without any edges. The oak smoke is in fact nearly as good as the beechwood smoke. Great stuff!

UPDATED: APR 26, 2016 On tap at the Brick Store Pub. Pours a pale brown with a small head. It smells like smoke, cured meats, saltwater, and hickory. It reminds me of bacon or hickory smoked barbeque. The flavor is sweet and salty, with a smooth bitter finish. It has a medium body and an unremarkable palate. I enjoyed this beer, but mostly for the novelty. It is a strange flavor in a beer, and I couldnt stop thinking about it as bacon-flavored beer.

7/14/10.  On tap.  Huge malty and salty beef jerky aroma with an underlying fruitiness in there.  Initial sweet fruitiness followed by obvious smoked meats and bacon, with nice hoppy bitterness to boot.

Sampled on draft at Zenos in State College PA this beer poured a dark amber color with a small beige head. The aroma was dry and woody without a whole lot more going on. The flavor was sharply woody with notes of oak and hickory. There were undertones of nut, honey and fruity hops. The finish was long, dry and woody. Medium body. The alcohol was well hidden. Disappointing.

On tap at Ginger Man NY
Aroma straight smoky character of Bamberg smoked lagers, Birch wood , smoked goat cheese. Creamy. Very promising aroma.
 Appearance  Clear deep amber with mid white top.3+
Flavor and Palate : frontal smoked cheese , chewy smooth character. So smooth it feels as it floats away on palate. For traditional smoked beer lover this one is must try beer. New and automatically class on its own.
Pours a nice rich copper color with an off white head. Aroma is smoke, charred wood, and some toast. Flavor is caramel, some fruit, smoke, toast, and some charred wood.

On tap @ Ølbaren. Pours a clear red amber with an off-white head and lacings. Sweet with aromas of smoked malts and hints of alcohol. Smooth full body. Soft carbonation. Dry smokey finish with warming alcohol notes. Less Schinken than other Schlenkerla beers.

Draft @ Brouwers; served clear copper with thin white head; lovely light cream and dry smoked malt with oaky dryness and vanilla cookies; not harsh at all; light texture with smooth, rich smoke, campfire and oak; unexpectedly lovely; just so damn rich and drinkable without being a mess of bacon and dirty smoke; am I starting to grow up with the recent enjoyment of smoked beers?

En fût. Verre de 12 oz dégusté chez Gingerman (New York, NY). Arôme: Odeur de céréales et de fumée avec une pointe fruitée. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de fumée et de caramel avec une pointe fruitée. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fumé. (Rating #2971)
Tap.  Pours to an amber body with a dense white head thats deeply creamy.  Aroma of deep oak smoked salmon and malt.  Flavor is smoke, yeast, and banana.  Subtle oak.  Medium body.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2017 Most recent glass, at the Schlenkerla Ausschank, in January 2017:

Well, this recipe has changed, it seems! Much darker visually, with residual sugars more on the caramel and berry ham side of things than the previous honey. But, of course, the intense smokiness is what dominates, and thats why you want to drink this wintry brew.

First glass, back in 2012:

My Bottom Line:
Elegant smoke effortlessly rises from maple-laced honeyed malts , creating a seamless, polished Heller Rauchbock (dont know what else to call it, to be frank) that is graced by touch of herbal hop aftertaste.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A creamy sheet of foam covers the translucent golden amber.
-The mouthfeel on this one (on tap) is absolutely perfect. Round enough to let you know its a potent brew, yet luxuriously smooth. The bottle is a tad softer as carbonation is not as prickly.
-Candied, phenolic allusions appear from time to time.
-Alcohol is well concealed by the smoked malts, making an appearance in the finish only.
-That aroma is something else. The oak smoke personality, with some herbal hops, almost emulates peat smoke at times.

Bottles and on tap at The Gingerman, NY.
UPDATED: MAY 11, 2011 Draught.  This might be the smokiest rauchbier ever. Pours a dark red and smells like - smoke.  Rerate.  Liked it much better in 2011

From the barrel at the London Drinker festival 11/03/10. Copper coloured with a slight, white head. Aroma of sweet malts, wood smoke and a touch of marmalade. Flavour had sticky malts, oak and a hint of bacon. Alcohol balanced the sweetness and smoke well. Interesting, but a half pint was about the right quantity.

On tap at In de Wildeman as Schlenkerla Eicken Rauch Doppelbock (8.2% ABV). Copper, off-white head. Heavy smoked malts aroma. Salty meats, good smokiness to balance the sweet malts. There is an added complex and dry side that may be due to the oak barrels, but the smoky malts overpower much else. Still interesting.

On tap... first true smoked, I believe.  Unbelievable how smokey, bbq, bacon like this smelled.  tasted similar.  while i would say its a "cool" beer to try, wouldnt say I love the taste or could drink more than one.

On tap as Oak Smoked Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier.  Clear dark amber pour, white head.  Lots of smoke, malt, caramel, campfire, oak, and some meatiness (bacon).  There was some fusel type flavors, which I didnt really like.  Interesting beer, but I can not drink very much of it.

Draught wood barrel (gravity) @ Schlenkerla, Dominikaner Strasse 6, 96049 Bamberg, Germany.Clear medium red orange amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, wood - oak, smoke - Schlenkerla smoke *<;O), light alcohol, fresh wood notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, light wood bitter, more sharper than a regular Schlenkerla. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091218]
Light sweet wood smoke light medium body .smoke in fill aroma bit not dominant in taste. Making it ideal for smokemhinged pqirings.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2012 
Name: Eiche
Date: January 05, 2010
Mode: Draft
Source: Brick Store Pub
Appearance: clear copper, dense off white head, streaks of globs of lace
Aroma: big smokey aroma backed by caramel sweetness
Flavor: rich malt flavor, big smokey character that has a nice oaky edge, caramel sweetness, nice earthyness from the smoke offers a light balancing bitter effect
Overall: the oak offers as big of a smoke character as the beechwood but appears to be a bit softer and more approachable

Name: Eiche
Date: February 06, 2012
Mode: bottle
Words: ale yeah
Appearance: clear deep copper, fine beige head
Aroma: sweet smokey aroma, caramel sweetness, smokey oak, breadyness hiding  under the smoke
Flavor: sweet and smokey flavor, sweet bready caramel, lot of smokey oak
Overall: more of the sweet caramel of the doppelbock comes through in the bottle without losing any of the smoke

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.9/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Draft thanks to 17thfloor. Pours a deep golden amber with a creamy thick white froth. Aroma is woody, smoked bacon, a very light citric sharpness, nice soft oak and maltiness. Flavor starts with a very sweet caramel malt, picks up a fired, smoky lightly fired malts. Picks up a stronger smoke character and a very light oaky wood, very light though, which is nice because it stays in balance. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Very good, I really enjoyed the balance and the freshness, very easy drinking and enjoyable.
Draught at Ølbaren. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Ugly dark-yellow colour. Moderate malty ugly bacon rauch aroma and flavor. Average finish. Watery palate. Hate it.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2013 Tap at Ølbaren. Nice head with excellent duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich bacon, salami and smoke. Very smooth. Rerated @ fonefan tasting. Original rating 6/4/6/4/12.

On tap at Track 84 - Warwick, RI. YES! Real and intense smoke, this time on a different bent. Strong wafting deep woods campfires rise from the glass. The smoke is even, quick, and dry. Much of less of the pork-fat, bacon, grease character and more of a soft, warm September afternoon in central Wisconsin, centered around an oak twig burn pile edged with leaves. Crisp, chalky, and delightful. The smoke is more direct and overwhelms the malt profile completely, but holds its own against the alcohols. A wonderfully balanced beer. A sharper, drier smoke, but a beautifully intense one.

Draft. Pours amber orange with a beige head. Nice smoky aroma with lighter notes of burlap. The flavor has smoke, some oaky woddy notes, rope, and burlap. Very good and very drinkable, however, my top Aecht Schlenkerla brew is still the Fastenbier.

Draft Clear, deep amber lager with a small, white head. The aroma is an assortment of caramel, praline and campfire smoke. Medium-bodied and creamy with stinging carbonation. Bittersweet flavor  leans more toward the bitter side of balance. Lengthy, bittersweet finish.

Draught @ Ølbaren. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Bacon, fruits, smoke and spice in the aroma. Flavour as well full of bacon and smoke. Has some caramelly and spicy notes as well. Medium to full bodied. Heavy smoky bitterness in the end. Complex and balanced. Nice.

Draught at Ølbaren. Clear amber body with a creamy off white head. The aroma is bamberg smoke, sweet malt, caramel and some dark fruit. The flavour is sweet tobacco, smoke, sweet caramel, dark fruit and light bacon. So great balanced. Fantastic smoked beer!

Draught. Clear dark brown amber colour, medium nice off-white head, good lacing. Lovely smokey  woody  aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour has a very pleasant not too bombastic smokiness with caramel, wood and a mild bitterness. Very tasty pleasant  smoked!

Tap at 4th Avenue Pub. Green olive, hammy, smokey bacon, scallion, marshmallow and chili pepper aroma. A long list for a very complex aroma. Still, I vastly prefer the smoke profile from the traditional beech wood; this was just a bit too hammy and vegetal, and didnt have that lovely campfire and hickory bacon aroma that their real stuff does. Full bodied in the mouth, hammy, prickly carbonation, a bunch of peat flavor. Reminds me more of American smoked efforts, which are never as good.

Fad: Flot orange let uklar øl med et fint skumhoved. Duft af bacon og røg. Klassisk Schlenkerla. Røgen er ikke så dominerende i smagen som røgen lægger op til, men er stadig super integreret i øllen. Flot og lækker røgøl.

From tap at Ølbaren. Pours clear and golden orange with a creamy, off-white and dense head. Aroma is smooth beachwood smoked. Not oaks. Smooth sweet, caramelish and mellow smoked. Lovely smooth and light caramelish finish. Greatly wellbalanced. Smooth lasting smoked finish.
Draught.Amber colour with small off-white head.Aroma is strong smoked and malty taste like good smoked bacon and carmel.Medium body with slight flavor of herbs and nuts.Nice smooth finish.

Draught at Ølbaren.
Clear amber coloured with a medium sized white head.
Smoked aroma of burnt wood and caramel with notes of hops.
Smoked flavour of burnt wood, caramel and hops.
Smoked and hoppy finish.
Usually I dint like smoked beers, but this is good and well balanced.

Draft. A deep red beer with a lazing beige. The aroma has strong notes of smoked malt and medium notes of caramel, and a bit of alcohol. The flavor is very sweet with strong notes of smoked malt, and medium notes of caramel, and wood, leading to a smokey finish.

Happy as a clam that they tapped this while I was at Spuyten Duyvil in Brooklyn.  Pours a waxy copper color with a trim off-white head.  Smells of smoked malt and caramel.  The most approachable Schlenkerla beer Ive yet to encounter.  Very balanced and relaxed flavors of smoke, meat, caramel, and hops.  Would drink this on the regular, if possible.

Draught at ØLbaren. Clear brown - offwhite head. Lovely smokey aroma. High malty, medium sweetness, malty sweetness, caramel, ryebread, nice smokey taste and aftertaste, Smooth body. Soft smokey mouthfull.....

32oz growler courtesy of scrizzz. Thanks, Clint! Pours a deep, brilliant and clear golden-to-orange-to-ruby color; creamy head formation with decent retention and fine-bubbled lacing; really attractive color here. Gorgeous density of smoke character in the aroma: charred oak, smoked meats, and a fair amount of spiciness; not quite the same slim-jim / peppery character of some of their others beer, this is smooth and creamy and shows layers of smoked meat and vanilla and toasted wood; absolutely beautiful aroma here. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of creamy, well-attenuated maltiness here in addition to all the smokiness in the nose; relaxed carbonation; light caramel and fluffy, honeyed malts in addition to the smoke: roasted meats, fair amounts of spiciness, and a hint of something approaching pepperoni or spiced pork; beautifully creamy, full-bodied, well-attenuated, and highly sessionable; this hits a similar spot to the Fastenbier, which was similarly fantastic and fleeting in its availability. I need to find a place out here with cheap Schlenkerla bottles. Lasting finish: nicely toasty on the departure, including honeyed maltiness, toasted oak, and smokiness that lingers long afterwards.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2010 Clear amber with a tiny white head. Swwet aroma with roasted malt, ham and plenty of smoke. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel, plenty of smoke and ham. Very smooth and the alcohol was well hidden. Lovely.

Draft at redlight. Pours a mostly clear coppery amber color with a small, foamy white head that settles to a thin film and leaves tiny spots of lace around the glass. The aroma shows notes of a sweet caramel malt base, fresh floral hops, salty bacon, smoke, and oak wood. The flavor shows more caramel and doughy, bread malts which add sweetness to the smoke oak wood flavors. The smoke is present throughout, but doesnt overpower and lends a salty, earthy overtone. Medium bodied with balanced carbonation leading to a dry, salty finish. I like the oak smoke in this one, but I think I prefer their other stuff a little more.

Tap at the Maproom.... Pours a mostly transparent orange cider brown with a medium fluffy white head... Medium degree of salty smoked malt on the nose upfront with more grain and a subtle sweetness on the backend...  Less smoke on the flavor with more of a malty grain presence that adds a modicum of sweetness. A real treat with a good balance between smoke and malt. Carbonation is semi-lively and not as smooth as some of the other schlenkerla beers on tap here. Still tasty.

Draft at Map Room. Pours a somewhat clear bronze. The nose is very different, cleaner & less phenolic. Lots of ham and bacon in the nose with distant noble hop herbalness. On taste, it has a clean flavor, not overrun by smoke, though it does come through. Pleasant bitterness couples well with the fantastic base beer. Very elegant and fantastic.

Draught at Beachwood BBQ.   Red-amber with a creamy head.   Smokey meat and caramel aroma.   Meaty flavor, but less smokey than the aroma, probably because of the malty sweetness balancing things.   Some caramel as well.   Full bodied but not thick at all.   Nicely balanced considering that there is still a lot of smoke in here, though I still prefer the regular beech-smoked malt beers for their dryer, smokier profiles.

Tap at maproom, pours basically clear amber with creamy white head. Nose has ham, toasted oak, grains. flavors have toasted oak and malts, sweet biscuit, vanilla, as the smokey ham notes round things out instead of completely dominating like their others do so marvelously. Med body, sturdy carbonation, good but sweeter and less pronounced smoke than their others.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2010 Draft. 1.8.10 Pours a clear glowing dark orange amber with a big frothy foamy eggshell head.  Sweet and spicy aroma, light fruit, Munich malt, formaldehyde.  Flavor is greatly well balanced, smooth glassy lightly fruity Munich Malt character, typical schlenkerla smoke, salty cured meat, hard to find the oak under the smoke but exceptionally mellowed.  Medium bodied, fills the mouth nicely without being heavy, sharp smooth carbonation.  8.4.8.4.17 [O... I thought it was aged on oak... didnt realize beechwood was replaced by oak... got it now] . . . . . . . . . [rerate bottle 11.24.10] Pours a beautiful vibrant glowing rich amber orange.  Flavor as I remember, but its a bit more sticky, rich, didnt realize it was a doppelbock before but can definitely tell now.  Really is a fine beer, aroma is amazing, great smoked pork aftertaste, rich vienna, lightly grassy, very smooth, cinnamon, sweet but well attenuated.   8.4.8.4.16

Tap at 4th Ave pub.  Pale amber pour with a sticky white head.  Rich smoky nose loaded with lovely intense smokiness.  Orange fruitiness along with a slightly oily smoke component.  A bit of very light sulfur coming from the yeast.  Its quite clean.  The smoke has a much more aggressive quality than I think the beech wood has.  The body is fairly light despite the higher ABV and there is a touch of peppery quality.  It certainly doesnt taste boozy but it does seem lighter than other schlenkerla products.  Its quite nice but I think I prefer the beechwood stuff better.

Sampled on draft at the Bookstore Speakeasy in Bethlehem, PA.

Pours a clear dark coppery amber color with golden orange/amber edges when held to a light source and a two finger frothy white head with excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap and ring that leaves sporadic spots of soapy lacing behind.

Excellent roasted smokey aroma with hints of campfire, butane, barbecue, bacon ash, earthy burnt wood subtle hops, smoked malt and a subtle nut presence. I took in the aroma of this beer for a while before sampling. While it is still pretty intensely smokey, I found the aroma of Eiche to be less extreme than the other Aecht Schlenkerla beers.

Surprisingly creamy medium body with a softer smoke presence than I expected. There is still a good amount of burnt smokey malt flavor but the use of oak instead of beechwood results in a much smoother, less extreme smoke flavor. Still, there is plenty of smoked malt, barbecued bacon, butane and burnt wood in this incredibly complex beer. In addition, there is a lactic creaminess and a noticeable earthy wood presence, likely from the oak. Also, there is a slick, buttery white wine taste that was a complete shock to me. It added another level of complexity to this incredible beer. The only other beer Ive tasted this flavor in is Allagash Vagabond and this element of Eiche reminds me of that beer. Im also picking up a bit of earthy roasted nuttiness toward the end of the finish. Lingering dry and earthy smoked flavor in the finish. Highly recommended

Draft at the Bavarian Lodge (Lisle, IL). Pours a nice orange amber, darker and dulled, a decent haze with a large tannish beige head, laces pretty well and cakes pretty big. Aromas are a nice bounty of campfire meats, bacon and sausage, mixed with a touch of smokey wood, caramel malts beneath with a faint spice, vanilla, as the brew takes on a smoke dominant position. Initial is a medium body, crisp smokey ash and copious smokehouse meats, bacon and ham, a salty bit, mixing with a faint vanilla, caramel and cereal beneath, smooth, with some light bitterness in the finish. The alcohol becomes discernible as it warms a bit, oak is lively but covered a bit by the smoked element, still lovely on the palate, the smoke doesnt get too out of control and this ends up to be quite drinkable (but then again, I really am digging smoked beers). Finish is lasting, smokey and a light malty sweetness beneath with light bitterness on the backend to temper. Big but delicate, smoke forward but more than that.Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2010 Tap.  Didnt notice this was my 200th rate until after I entered it, but its a pretty good choice for it.  Poured a coppery amber with a smallish white head.  Aroma is dominated by the rich, somewhat meaty smokiness.  The smoke flavor hit me hard at first, but after a couple sips it stopped dominating, and I appreciated the beer as a whole more.
