Has a strong, somewhat sweet malty body and a spicy, bitter hop presence.  The alcohol is not very noticable at all.  I didnt know the ABV when I drank this, and was estimating it to be something like 5%.  I could feel the smoke on my breath for a good long while after having this.  This was the first beer Ive tried with this level of smoke, and it was a pretty awesome experience.
On tap. Pored a reddish color with a big foamy head. Aroma of wood, smoke and BBQ. Flavor was very nice; not over the top smoky. Wood, caramel, wood, some yeast. Soft on palate. Good beer.

Tap at Beachwood.  Was really excited to see this.  Nose is that classic porkloin zest we all know and love.  Color is a reasonable garnet.  Flavor was smaller than I expected.  Thought this would be more robust than the Urbock for some reason.  The oak happens at the start of the flavor, rather than the finish which was unusual to me.  Ultimately this helps avoid the crazy plunge from tangy roast malt to char that you find in the regular lineup of Schlenkerla.  Finish is more round and sweet than I remember the Urbock being - or than I prefer.

What can I say about Schlenkerla brews, they all rock and I love the smoke.  The brew is all smoke, hence I love it.  The beer is very well attenuated, thus nicely drying.  Particularly, the smoke is dry here, very different from the sweatier beechwood smoke in their other brews.  Love the beer, could keep putting down glass after glass. The color is a dark golden to light amber. I have no idea where that alcohol is coming from.

Draft @ 4th Ave Pub, served in a stemmed, short flute glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Tap. Aroma of smoked bacon, very salty, and freshly smoking firewood, very much straight oaky. Flavor quickly became a bit weird with a sweet maltiness that just didnt do well with the pure wood character. Felt very green somehow, lots of fresh flavors that were too much for one another.

Draught at the Bavarian Lodge in Lisle, IL.  Pours a clear amber with a creamy off-white head.  Has that trademark campfire bacon aroma.  The oak seems more prevalent in the flavor than the aroma where a distinct oak wood character comes through along with distinct bitter hops and a full smoky body.  Body is full with a nice lingering bitterness with some floral notes.  Finishes with a dry bitterness.  Delicious.

Draft at Redlight Redlight.  The pour yields a clear, coppery, golden-amber hued body.  A smooth, foamy, off-white head settles in to a steady, thin blanket, leaving patchwork lacing on the glass.  The nose is based is doughy, sweet, bready malt, with notes of caramel, light floral hops, and a solid dose of woody, slightly salty smoke.  To be honest, I cant really decipher the oak from the standard beechwood.  Flavors mirror the nose, again sweet and doughy, with notes of caramel and dried fruit on the back end.  Smoke is persistent, but not overpowering, again lending a hint of saltiness and earthen char.  Big bodied, with balanced carbonation, the palate sports a round, slightly drying finish.  Very good stuff, but the additional malt and alcohol dont necessarily lend themselves to this style.  I prefer the more sessionable offerings from the folks at Schlenkerla.

On tap at the Fourth Ave. Pub.  Pours a clear ruby tinged garnet amber with a medium sized beige head.  Campfire, bacon, smoked ham.  Smoke. Everywhere. Gorgeous.  Medium bodied, lighter carbonation than I was expecting, silky and smooth.  Smooth smoked meats and caramel and toffee.  Finishes up with more elegant smoke infusing everything.  Classic Schlenkerla smoke that makes every nasal exhalation for the next half hour smoke infused.  Really tasty, and any indication of the abv on this is well hidden.  How do they hide it?  Smoke and mirrors possibly.

Growler from redlight redlight. Pours a light amber with a tight off-white head. For their biggest ABV beer, this drinks very light. Nose is nice smoke over a toffee and caramel creamy malt body. Smoke is more subdued in the flavor, hitting light up front followed by the strong malt body, a sweet vanilla tinged toffee middle. Complex aftertaste with creamy malt and smoke returning, mild earthiness, a touch of alcohol and slight drying astringency. Very light in the mouth, creamy with a nice dryness despite the sweet malty body. Quite nice!

On tap at Stone.  Clear golden amber with a one and a half finger off-white head, creamy with fair retention. Loads of woody smoke and some smoky dry meats.  Flavor adds some light caramel sweetness and some oak, though I may be making it up.  Small amount of alcohol present, helping keep the sweetness at bay.  Dry finish, low bitterness.  Definitely heavier than their other offerings.  Medium to full body with low carbonation.  Another rockin smoked beer.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2012 (tap at Redlight Redlight in Orlando FL)

lct-cpr, thin-lasting-wh-head, sticky-med-body, med-high-co2.

aroma:  sweet §meaty ^smoky.

flavor:  sweet meaty leafy-hops T1, co2 smoky crml-malt leafy-hops T2, sweet-smoky-amber-malt T3, smoky sweet-bready-malt Ts, §adjuncty-lager leafy-hops Tf.

the wonderful smokiness in the aroma and flavor is sweeter than the beechwood smoked schlenkerla beers (not sure if that is from the oak, or more malt, or less hops, or a combination).  IMO, its not as hop-bitter as the marzen, or as malty as the urbock, and is a bit lighter on the palate than any of the others.

On tap at Oldsmar Tap House (Tampa, FL). Pours a hazy yellow to amber color with thin white head. Aroma is malty, smoky, funky. Flavor is about the same with some notes of oak and chocolate. Tough to pick through the flavors with so much smokiness. Medium body with a smoky malt finish. Seems to be a great example of the style.

On tap at DBGB.  Pours a clear orange with a small white head.  Aroma of smoky meats, peat, bacon.  Flavor is quite minty on the initial sip followed by berries, smoked wood, smoked meats.  Hmm, didnt really enjoy this one -- it was too minty.
7/4/6/3/13 [3.3/5]
minimal light lacing, white head with a gold body. im not a big smoked beer fan, but this wasnt taxing by the least. gentle balance. awesome for a smoked beer.

Tap at Redlight. Pours a deep copper pour with a thick off white head. Smoked ham, caramel aroma. Caramel sweet malt, smoked meat, vanilla oak taste. Seems the oak came through more in the taste. Not a fan of the style, but this is done so well you cant help but to not like it.

Tap at Schlenkerla.
More subtle smoke like old floorboards. A bit fruit, honey
Pretty brown amber, brown lacing head.
Light herbal, oaken barrels, much more subtle than the marzen I have in parallel. Less burned. Honeyish light berries.
Mellow, light mouthfeel
Honey retronasal, leaves honey on the palate.
A truly elegant rauchbier.
I am bummed it wasnt possible to buy ny to take home :-(

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 (draught) clear dark amber colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of mellow smoke, wholemeal bread, light herbal hops, a touch of wood and alcohol. flavour is like a freshly smoked fatty salmon, with notes of bread and again quite some alcohol, quite smooth overall. heavy body with smooth carbonation and a long smoky finish.

draft at brouwers. crystal clear burnished bright orange. creamy tan head, plenty of sheets and rings of lace. big rich sweetish bacon nose. creamy medium body. tons of rich smoky bacon on the mid, with a long tangy smoke finish.

Sampled on tap at Churchkey in Washington DC.  I have to preface my rating by saying I HATE rauchbiers.  They really arent my cup of tea.  This one comes a transparent, caramel orange with a white head.  When cold, the aroma was a little like smoked lox, but once it warmed up a sensational smoky oak aroma popped out.  Unfortunately, like many smoked beers, cold smoke was all I smelled.  The flavor also had a distinct peaty, smokiness but the oak really comes through well.  Its all about the oak.  Close your eyes and it tastes like youre eating a smoked gouda.  While one dimensional, the flavors are definitely unique, even for the style.  Finish was medium bodied with a hint of lingering sweetness.  Easily the best smoked beer Ive ever had, one Id actually order again.
Solid smoked ham aroma.  Finish Is the best part and lingers for days.  Great, and smooth.

Dark and bright orange hue, thin white head and spotty lacing. Nose is big smoke and oak, strong underlying malts, meat and bacon and other smoked meats linger. Flavor is definitely a toned down rauchbier with the oak taking quite a bit of edge off the traditional beechwood, smokey ham and bacon up front followed by bready malts and noble hop flavor and bitterness, finishes malty and smokey. Full body, modest carbonation, thick texture. A unique smoked beer, perhaps a bit less powerful and easier to use as a gateway rauch, good balance and malt profile.

On tap at Stone, labeled Heller Aecht Schlekerla Oak Smoke.  8%ABV.  Holy smoke(Pun intended!).  Smells like the leftover smell in my sweater after Ive been camping for a week.  Pure campfire.  Clear orange amber.  Initial flavor, just for a moment, is like a lager, then the smoke.  Campfire.  Smoked salmon.  Lotsa oak and smoke.  Once my tastebuds became accustomed to the smoke the taste settled down a bit.  Seriously overwhelming for the first few drinks.  6oz was plenty on this one.  Cant rate this fairly based on style, as Ive had nothing like this before.  It might be the best of this style, and I havent a clue.

Draft at Brouwers.  Hell yes, Ive been waiting for this!  Pours a crystal clear orangish/caramel/golden with a slightly off white creamy head with some fairly stickly lacing.  Slightly sweet, charred malty caramel, smoked meaty goodness, with the oak showing through for sure.  The body is much stickier with tight lively carbonation.  Sweet caramel with hints of orange and oak up front, with some grassy hints, the the classic Schlenkerla smoked malt.  Not as campfire like as the marzen.  The oak really shows in this though.  So glad to get to try this, love it.

Big smokey nose. Sweet firewood, mesquite, barbeque, vanilla and soft woody notes. Oak softens the super smoke a bit. Golden amber pour, nice frothy head and sticky lace. Dry smokey flavor with a good sweet base underneath. Bbq sweetness, caramel. Dry finish with salty smoke and wood.

Tap at Fourth Ave Pub: Deep copper pour with a thin off white film of head. Hammy smoke aroma with some piny tannins and mildly sweet, almost toffeeeish malt undertones. Creamy firm body. The smoke is there, but theres an oily, heavy tannin presence that coats the tongue. The oak doesnt give as clean of a smokiness as the beechwood. Its more hammy and less firewood like. Theres lots of peppery hallertau hops on the back. Not as smoke, or robustly malt forward as the originals. The oak gives it a bit more piny rather than cleanly and fiery smoky.
Draft. Pours a orange copper body with a white head. Vicious smoked char and roasted malt. Smoke malt, peat, campfire tones, some char and a smoky but lightly malty finish. Awesome smoked ale.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a clear but dark gold.  Very excellent nose.  Extremely smoky with hints of oak behind it.  Slightly reminiscent of a good scotch.  Lots of malt also come through in the flavor.  Another great edition to Schlenkerlas nearly flawless line.

On tap at BT and 4th ave.  Pours a nice deep copper/ bronzy orange with a nice mostly white lasting sticky head.  Aroma is nicely smokey- not over the top, but fairly intense, a somewhat cleaner smoke- perhaps more mineraly, woody, less meaty- not quite camp-fire like, good big toasty malt backbone, big caramelized vienna, some light munich.  Toffee flavor, toast, some earth and herbalness, light cleanser attributed t the tannins in the oak smokiness, more clean smoke- mineral in the end, overall very clean and easy drinking, especially for all the smoke and the 8%.  You get way more smoke (although a different type) from the urbock and unfiltered urbock especially- but this is fairly unique for a schlenkerla- although you get the same top notch big fresh malt backbone and a clean refreshing drinkable intense smokey beer.  I loved it.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Smoke on the nose, not as sharp as some of the others.  Pours amber with a thick white head.  Earthy, smooth smoke flavors, not as intense, the malts really shine through, less pungent smoke.  Very very nice to drink and does not seem 8% at all!

Handbottled at home - very big thanks to Frankenland for making this possible! Looks really good in the glass, copper coloured, strong malty-smoky aroma. Starts strong, not alcoholic, smoky notes not too much like bacon as other beers from the brewery, very well balanced, smoky-woody finish. Very drinkable for its strength. A great beer!

Rating #1800.  Orange red, smooth off white head.  Ashy, smoked meats aroma.  Taste is again lightly ashy, dry, smoked sausage, bacon, dry campfire finish.  Not the best Schlenkerla but an absolutely awesome beer nonetheless.

Growler from Bierkraft gifted to me by a non-beer-geek friend who seemed to remember that I like smoky beer.  Poured in tulip.  Bright clear reddish copper color with lasting off-white head and lace.  Beautiful smoky woody honey candy grass bready aroma with the slightest hint of alcohol.   Sweet toasty caramel candy with very mild sweet fruit and light grassy earthy bitterness coated all around by a peat-like whiskey smokiness distinct from other Schlenkerlas and more like their imitators.  Mild lingering hop bitterness.  Surprisingly medium light drinkable body, dense carbo, perfect mouthfeel for strong lager, no alcohol presence in flavor.  Seems incredibly well-made, a work of art, truly refined.  However, I find I prefer the in-your-face rich aromatic smokiness of the beechwood smoked beers.   Nevertheless, an absolutely awesome brew.  Im trying not to drink the whole growler tonight because it is 8% after all.

[from a barrel at the brewery]
Tangy smoky aroma that is not quite like smoked salmon smoke together with some linseed oil and sherry-like notes. Clear, dark amber with a lacy, dense, flannel blanket of almost white. Oily vanilla oak smoke flavour with melanoidinly spiciness that is balanced by a woody bitterness. Subtle nutty notes. Smooth and with a unique smoke character. Medium body, moderate carbonation, slight woody bitter finish.

Draft.  Off-white head atop crystal clear amber body.  Aroma is medium sweet, smoked cheese, light caramel.  taste is medium sweet, smoke, some caramel/bread.  Soft medium body.  Nose is great, but the flavor is a bit more subdued.  A solid beer, but not at the top of the Schlenkerla ladder.
